<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology"><span id="Etymology"></span> Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG/170px-Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG" width="170" height="266" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG/255px-Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG/340px-Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG 2x" data-file-width="491" data-file-height="768" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Merneptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Merneptah_Stele" title="Merneptah Stele">Merneptah Stele</a> (13th century BC). The majority of <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Archeology" class="mw-redirect" title="Biblical Archeology">biblical archeologists</a> translate a set of hieroglyphs as "Israel," the first instance of the name in the record.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Upon independence in 1948, the country formally adopted the name "State of Israel" (<i>Medinat Yisrael</i>) after other proposed historical and religious names including <i>Eretz Israel</i> ("the <a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>"), <a href="/wiki/Zion" title="Zion">Zion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a>, were considered and rejected.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[36]</a></sup> In the early weeks of independence, the government chose the term "<a href="/wiki/Israelis" title="Israelis">Israeli</a>" to denote a citizen of Israel, with the formal announcement made by <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Affairs_Minister_of_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel">Minister of Foreign Affairs</a> <a href="/wiki/Moshe_Sharett" title="Moshe Sharett">Moshe Sharett</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[37]</a></sup></p>
<p>The names <a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Children_of_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Children of Israel">Children of Israel</a> have historically been used to refer to the biblical <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">Kingdom of Israel</a> and the entire Jewish people respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-levine_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-levine-40">[38]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israel_(name)" title="Israel (name)">name "Israel"</a> (<small><a href="/wiki/Modern_Hebrew" title="Modern Hebrew">Standard</a></small>&#160;<i>Yisraʾel</i>, <i>Isrāʾīl</i>; <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a> <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Ἰσραήλ</span> <i>Israēl</i>; 'El(God) persists/rules' though, after Hosea 12:4 often interpreted as "struggle with God"<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[42]</a></sup>) in these phrases refers to the patriarch <a href="/wiki/Jacob" title="Jacob">Jacob</a> who, according to the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>, was given the name after he successfully wrestled with the angel of the Lord.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[43]</a></sup> Jacob's twelve sons became the ancestors of the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelites</a>, also known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Twelve_Tribes_of_Israel" title="Twelve Tribes of Israel">Twelve Tribes of Israel</a></i> or <i>Children of Israel</i>. Jacob and his sons had lived in <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaan</a> but were forced by famine to go into <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> for four generations, lasting 430 years,<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup> until <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>, a great-great grandson of Jacob,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[45]</a></sup> led the Israelites back into Canaan during the "<a href="/wiki/The_Exodus" title="The Exodus">Exodus</a>". The earliest known archaeological artifact to mention the word "Israel" as a collective is the <a href="/wiki/Merneptah_Stele" title="Merneptah Stele">Merneptah Stele</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> (dated to the late 13th century BCE).<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup></p>
<p>The area is also known as the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>, being holy for all <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a> including <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a>. From 1920, the whole region was known as <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Palestine (under British Mandate)</a><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[note 3]</a></sup> until the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">Israeli Declaration of Independence</a> of 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[47]</a></sup> Through the centuries, the territory was known by a variety of other names, including <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Djahy" title="Djahy">Djahy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samaria" title="Samaria">Samaria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yehud_(Babylonian_province)" title="Yehud (Babylonian province)">Yehud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iudaea" class="mw-redirect" title="Iudaea">Iudaea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coele-Syria" title="Coele-Syria">Coele-Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria_Palaestina" title="Syria Palaestina">Syria Palaestina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Syria" title="Southern Syria">Southern Syria</a>.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Israel" title="History of Israel">History of Israel</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Levant" title="Prehistory of the Levant">Prehistory of the Levant</a></div>
<p>The oldest evidence of <a href="/wiki/Early_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Early humans">early humans</a> in the territory of modern Israel, dating to 1.5 million years ago, was found in <a href="/wiki/Ubeidiya" title="Ubeidiya">Ubeidiya</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[48]</a></sup> Other notable <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> sites include caves <a href="/wiki/Tabun_Cave" title="Tabun Cave">Tabun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qesem_Cave" title="Qesem Cave">Qesem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manot_Cave" title="Manot Cave">Manot</a>. The oldest fossils of <a href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_human" title="Anatomically modern human">anatomically modern humans</a> found <a href="/wiki/Recent_African_origin_of_modern_humans" title="Recent African origin of modern humans">outside Africa</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Skhul_and_Qafzeh_hominids" title="Skhul and Qafzeh hominids">Skhul and Qafzeh hominids</a>, who lived in northern Israel 120,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[49]</a></sup> Around 10th millennium BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Natufian_culture" title="Natufian culture">Natufian culture</a> existed in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[50]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">History of ancient Israel and Judah</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg/170px-Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg.png" width="170" height="259" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg/255px-Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg/340px-Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2168" data-file-height="3300" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kingdom_of_Israel_1020_map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Maps_of_Ancient_Israel" title="Maps of Ancient Israel">Map</a> of the Kingdom of Israel, 1020 BCE–930 BCE as imagined from the Bible narrative<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The notion of the "<a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>", known in <a href="/wiki/Hebrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a> as <i>Eretz Yisrael</i>, has been important and sacred to the Jewish people since Biblical times. According to the <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a>, God <a href="/wiki/Promised_Land" title="Promised Land">promised the land</a> to the three <a href="/wiki/Patriarchs_(Bible)" title="Patriarchs (Bible)">Patriarchs</a> of the Jewish people.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup> On the basis of scripture, the <a href="/wiki/Patriarchal_age" title="Patriarchal age">period of the three Patriarchs</a> has been placed somewhere in the early 2nd millennium&#160;BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[53]</a></sup> The first record of the name Israel (as <i><span lang="egy-Latn">ysrỉꜣr</span></i>) occurs in the <a href="/wiki/Merneptah_Stele" title="Merneptah Stele">Merneptah Stele</a>, erected for Egyptian Pharaoh <a href="/wiki/Merneptah" title="Merneptah">Merneptah</a> c. 1209 BCE, "Israel is laid waste and his seed is not."<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[54]</a></sup> This "Israel" was a cultural and probably political <a href="/wiki/Israelite_highland_settlement" title="Israelite highland settlement">entity of the central highlands</a>, well enough established to be perceived by the Egyptians as a possible challenge to <a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="New Kingdom of Egypt">their hegemony</a>, but an ethnic group rather than an organised state.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup> The Merneptah Stele is one of four known contemporary inscriptions from antiquity containing the name of Israel, the others being the <a href="/wiki/Tel_Dan_Stele" title="Tel Dan Stele">Tel Dan Stele</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mesha_Stele" title="Mesha Stele">Mesha Stele</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Kurkh_Monolith" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurkh Monolith">Kurkh Monolith</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup> The name appears much earlier, <a href="/wiki/Israel_(name)" title="Israel (name)">as a personal name</a>, in material from <a href="/wiki/Ebla" title="Ebla">Ebla</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup></p>
<p>Modern scholars see Israel arising peacefully and internally from existing people in the highlands of <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup> McNutt says, "It is probably safe to assume that sometime during <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Iron Age I">Iron Age I</a> a population began to identify itself as '<a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelite</a>'", differentiating itself from the Canaanites through such markers as the prohibition of intermarriage, an emphasis on family history and genealogy, and religion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199935_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199935-63">[60]</a></sup> Ancestors of the Israelites may have included <a href="/wiki/Semitic_people" title="Semitic people">Semites</a> native to Canaan and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_Peoples" title="Sea Peoples">Sea Peoples</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[61]</a></sup> The archaeological evidence indicates a society of village-like centres, but with more limited resources and a small population.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[62]</a></sup> Villages had populations of up to 300 or 400,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199970_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199970-66">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller201298_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller201298-67">[64]</a></sup> which lived by farming and herding, and were largely self-sufficient;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199972_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199972-68">[65]</a></sup> economic interchange was prevalent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller201299_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller201299-69">[66]</a></sup> Writing was known and available for recording, even in small sites.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller2012105_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller2012105-70">[67]</a></sup> The first <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">Kingdom of Israel</a> was established around the 11th century BCE. Subsequent <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">Israelite kingdoms and states</a> ruled intermittently over the next four hundred years, and are known from various extra-biblical sources.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[71]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG/220px-City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG/330px-City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG/440px-City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Large_Stone_Structure" title="Large Stone Structure">Large Stone Structure</a>, archaeological site of ancient <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Around 930 BCE, the kingdom split into a southern <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a> and a northern <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">Kingdom of Israel</a>. From the middle of the 8th century BCE Israel came into increasing conflict with the expanding <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian Empire</a>. Under <a href="/wiki/Tiglath-Pileser_III" title="Tiglath-Pileser III">Tiglath-Pileser III</a> it first split Israel's territory into several smaller units and then destroyed its capital, <a href="/wiki/Samaria_(ancient_city)" title="Samaria (ancient city)">Samaria</a> (722 BCE). An Israelite revolt (724–722 BCE) was crushed after the siege and capture of <a href="/wiki/Samaria" title="Samaria">Samaria</a> by the Assyrian king <a href="/wiki/Sargon_II" title="Sargon II">Sargon II</a>. Sargon's son, <a href="/wiki/Sennacherib" title="Sennacherib">Sennacherib</a>, tried and failed to conquer Judah. <a href="/wiki/Sennacherib%27s_Annals" title="Sennacherib's Annals">Assyrian records</a> say he leveled 46 walled cities and <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_Siege_of_Jerusalem" title="Assyrian Siege of Jerusalem">besieged Jerusalem</a>, leaving after receiving extensive tribute.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[72]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 586 BCE, King <a href="/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar_II" title="Nebuchadnezzar II">Nebuchadnezzar II</a> of <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Babylon</a> <a href="/wiki/Jewish%E2%80%93Babylonian_war" title="Jewish–Babylonian war">conquered</a> Judah. According to the Hebrew Bible, he <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(587_BC)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (587 BC)">destroyed</a> <a href="/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple" title="Solomon's Temple">Solomon's Temple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">exiled</a> the Jews to Babylon. The defeat was also recorded in the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_Chronicles" title="Babylonian Chronicles">Babylonian Chronicles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[74]</a></sup> In 538 BCE, <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> of <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persia</a> conquered Babylon and took over its empire. Cyrus issued a proclamation granting subjugated nations, including the people of Judah, religious freedom (for the original text, which corroborates the <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great_in_the_Bible" title="Cyrus the Great in the Bible">biblical narrative</a> only in very broad terms, see the <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_Cylinder" title="Cyrus Cylinder">Cyrus Cylinder</a>). According to the Hebrew Bible, 50,000 Judeans, led by <a href="/wiki/Zerubbabel" title="Zerubbabel">Zerubbabel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Return_to_Zion" title="Return to Zion">returned</a> to Judah and <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">rebuilt the temple</a>. A second group of 5,000, led by <a href="/wiki/Ezra" title="Ezra">Ezra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nehemiah" title="Nehemiah">Nehemiah</a>, returned to Judah in 456 BCE although non-Jews wrote to Cyrus to try to prevent their return.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_period">Classical period</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_period" title="Second Temple period">Second Temple period</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hasmonean_dynasty" title="Hasmonean dynasty">Hasmonean dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herodian_dynasty" title="Herodian dynasty">Herodian dynasty</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_wars" title="Jewish–Roman wars">Jewish–Roman wars</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Temple_Scroll.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Temple_Scroll.png/170px-Temple_Scroll.png" width="170" height="187" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Temple_Scroll.png/255px-Temple_Scroll.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Temple_Scroll.png/340px-Temple_Scroll.png 2x" data-file-width="1083" data-file-height="1189" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Temple_Scroll.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Portion of the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Scroll" title="Temple Scroll">Temple Scroll</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a> written during the Second Temple period</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>With successive <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian rule</a>, the autonomous province <a href="/wiki/Yehud_Medinata" title="Yehud Medinata">Yehud Medinata</a> was gradually developing back into urban society, largely dominated by Judeans. The <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Greece" title="Hellenistic Greece">Greek</a> conquests largely skipped the region without any resistance or interest. Incorporated into <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic</a> and finally <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid</a> empires, the southern Levant was heavily <a href="/wiki/Coele-Syria" title="Coele-Syria">hellenized</a>, building the tensions between Judeans and Greeks. The conflict erupted in 167 BCE with the <a href="/wiki/Maccabean_Revolt" title="Maccabean Revolt">Maccabean Revolt</a>, which succeeded in establishing an independent <a href="/wiki/Hasmonean_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Hasmonean Kingdom">Hasmonean Kingdom</a> in Judah, which later expanded over much of modern Israel, as the Seleucids gradually lost control in the region.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg/170px-Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg" width="170" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg/255px-Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg/340px-Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3755" data-file-height="5000" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel-2013-Aerial_21-Masada.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Masada" title="Masada">Masada</a> fortress, location of the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Masada" title="Siege of Masada">final battle</a> in the <a href="/wiki/First_Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_War" title="First Jewish–Roman War">First Jewish–Roman War</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> invaded the region in 63 BCE, first taking control of <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, and then intervening in the <a href="/wiki/Hasmonean_Civil_War" title="Hasmonean Civil War">Hasmonean Civil War</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Parthian_Wars" title="Roman–Parthian Wars">struggle</a> between pro-Roman and pro-Parthian factions in Judea eventually led to the installation of <a href="/wiki/Herod_the_Great" title="Herod the Great">Herod the Great</a> and consolidation of the <a href="/wiki/Herodian_kingdom" title="Herodian kingdom">Herodian kingdom</a> as a vassal Judean state of Rome. With the decline of the <a href="/wiki/Herodian_dynasty" title="Herodian dynasty">Herodian dynasty</a>, Judea, transformed into a <a href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">Roman province</a>, became the site of a violent struggle of <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> against Greco-Romans, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_wars" title="Jewish–Roman wars">Jewish–Roman wars</a>, ending in wide-scale destruction, expulsions, and genocide. Jewish presence in the region significantly dwindled after the failure of the <a href="/wiki/Bar_Kokhba_revolt" title="Bar Kokhba revolt">Bar Kokhba revolt</a> against the Roman Empire in 132 CE.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[75]</a></sup></p>
<p>Nevertheless, there was a continuous small Jewish presence and <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a> became its religious center.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[77]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mishnah" title="Mishnah">Mishnah</a> and part of the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Talmud" title="Jerusalem Talmud">Talmud</a>, central Jewish texts, were composed during the 2nd to 4th centuries CE in <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[78]</a></sup> The region came to be populated predominantly by Greco-Romans on the coast and <a href="/wiki/Samaritans" title="Samaritans">Samaritans</a> in the hill-country. <a href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">Christianity</a> was gradually evolving over Roman paganism, when the area stood under <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_the_East" title="Diocese of the East">Byzantine rule</a>. Through the 5th and 6th centuries, the dramatic events of the repeated <a href="/wiki/Samaritan_revolts" title="Samaritan revolts">Samaritan revolts</a> reshaped the land, with massive destruction to Byzantine Christian and Samaritan societies and a resulting decrease of the population. After the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_conquest_of_Jerusalem" title="Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem">Persian conquest</a> and the installation of a short-lived <a href="/wiki/Jewish_revolt_against_Heraclius" title="Jewish revolt against Heraclius">Jewish Commonwealth</a> in 614 CE, the Byzantine Empire <a href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian_War_of_602%E2%80%93628" title="Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628">reconquered</a> the country in 628.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages_and_modern_history">Middle Ages and modern history</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem_during_the_Middle_Ages" title="History of Jerusalem during the Middle Ages">History of Jerusalem during the Middle Ages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_history_in_Palestine" title="Muslim history in Palestine">Muslim history in Palestine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Old_Yishuv" title="Old Yishuv">Old Yishuv</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg/220px-Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg/330px-Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg/440px-Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4048" data-file-height="3040" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Kfar_Bar%27am" title="Kfar Bar'am">Kfar Bar'am</a>, an ancient Jewish village, abandoned some time between the 7th–13th centuries AD.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 634–641 CE, the region, including Jerusalem, was <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_the_Levant" title="Muslim conquest of the Levant">conquered</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arabs</a> who had just recently adopted <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>. Control of the region transferred between the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun" title="Rashidun">Rashidun</a> <a href="/wiki/Caliph" class="mw-redirect" title="Caliph">Caliphs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Umayyad" class="mw-redirect" title="Umayyad">Umayyads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasids</a>, Fatimids, Seljuks, <a href="/wiki/Crusader_states" title="Crusader states">Crusaders</a>, and Ayyubids throughout the next three centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-MosheGil_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MosheGil-83">[80]</a></sup></p>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(1099)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (1099)">siege of Jerusalem</a> by the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a> in 1099, the Jewish inhabitants of the city fought side by side with the Fatimid garrison and the Muslim population who tried in vain to defend the city against the <a href="/wiki/Crusaders" class="mw-redirect" title="Crusaders">Crusaders</a>. When the city fell, about 60,000 people were massacred, including 6,000 Jews seeking refuge in a synagogue.<sup id="cite_ref-Cooper2009_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cooper2009-84">[81]</a></sup> At this time, a full thousand years after the fall of the Jewish state, there were Jewish communities all over the country. Fifty of them are known and include Jerusalem, <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramla" title="Ramla">Ramleh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashkelon" title="Ashkelon">Ashkelon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caesarea" title="Caesarea">Caesarea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gaza_City" title="Gaza City">Gaza</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[82]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Albert_of_Aachen" class="mw-redirect" title="Albert of Aachen">Albert of Aachen</a>, the Jewish residents of <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a> were the main fighting force of the city, and "mixed with Saracen [Fatimid] troops", they fought bravely for close to a month until forced into retreat by the Crusader fleet and land army.<sup id="cite_ref-634to1099_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-634to1099-86">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Resnick2012_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Resnick2012-87">[84]</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Prawer" title="Joshua Prawer">Joshua Prawer</a> expressed doubt over the story, noting that Albert did not attend the Crusades and that such a prominent role for the Jews is not mentioned by any other source.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[85]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view#Due_and_undue_weight" title="Wikipedia:Neutral point of view"><span title="The material near this tag may be giving undue weight to a viewpoint or idea. (May 2015)">undue weight?</span></a> <span class="metadata">– <a href="/wiki/Talk:Israel#undue" title="Talk:Israel">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg/220px-RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg/330px-RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg/440px-RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RoyLindmanAbuhav1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The 15th-century <a href="/wiki/Abuhav_synagogue" title="Abuhav synagogue">Abuhav synagogue</a>, established by Sephardic Jews in Safed, Northern Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-JVL_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JVL-89">[86]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1165, <a href="/wiki/Maimonides" title="Maimonides">Maimonides</a> visited Jerusalem and prayed on the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a>, in the "great, holy house."<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[87]</a></sup> In 1141 the Spanish-Jewish poet <a href="/wiki/Yehuda_Halevi" class="mw-redirect" title="Yehuda Halevi">Yehuda Halevi</a> issued a call for Jews to migrate to the Land of Israel, a journey he undertook himself. In 1187 Sultan <a href="/wiki/Saladin" title="Saladin">Saladin</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubid dynasty</a>, defeated the Crusaders in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hattin" title="Battle of Hattin">Battle of Hattin</a> and subsequently captured Jerusalem and almost all of Palestine. In time, Saladin issued a proclamation inviting Jews to return and settle in Jerusalem,<sup id="cite_ref-Bloch1987_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bloch1987-91">[88]</a></sup> and according to <a href="/wiki/Yehuda_Alharizi" title="Yehuda Alharizi">Judah al-Harizi</a>, they did: "From the day the Arabs took Jerusalem, the Israelites inhabited it."<sup id="cite_ref-Ben-Gurion1974_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ben-Gurion1974-92">[89]</a></sup> Al-Harizi compared Saladin's decree allowing Jews to re-establish themselves in Jerusalem to the one issued by the Persian king <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> over 1,600 years earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-Hindley2007_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hindley2007-93">[90]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1211, the Jewish community in the country was strengthened by the arrival of a group headed by over 300 rabbis from France and England,<sup id="cite_ref-CarmelSch.C3.A4fer1990_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CarmelSch.C3.A4fer1990-94">[91]</a></sup> among them Rabbi <a href="/wiki/Samson_ben_Abraham_of_Sens" title="Samson ben Abraham of Sens">Samson ben Abraham of Sens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nachmanides" title="Nachmanides">Nachmanides</a>, the 13th-century Spanish rabbi and recognised leader of Jewry greatly praised the land of Israel and viewed its settlement as a positive commandment incumbent on all Jews. He wrote "If the gentiles wish to make peace, we shall make peace and leave them on clear terms; but as for the land, we shall not leave it in their hands, nor in the hands of any nation, not in any generation."<sup id="cite_ref-Lichtman2006_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lichtman2006-96">[93]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1260, control passed to the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_(Cairo)" title="Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)">Mamluk sultans of Egypt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GudrunKramer_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GudrunKramer-97">[94]</a></sup> The country was located between the two centres of Mamluk power, <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>, and only saw some development along the postal road connecting the two cities. Jerusalem, although left without the protection of any <a href="/wiki/Walls_of_Jerusalem" title="Walls of Jerusalem">city walls</a> since 1219, also saw a flurry of new construction projects centred around the <a href="/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque" title="Al-Aqsa Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a> compound on the Temple Mount. In 1266 the Mamluk Sultan <a href="/wiki/Baybars" class="mw-redirect" title="Baybars">Baybars</a> converted the <a href="/wiki/Cave_of_the_Patriarchs" title="Cave of the Patriarchs">Cave of the Patriarchs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a> into an exclusive Islamic sanctuary and banned Christians and Jews from entering, which previously would be able to enter it for a fee. The ban remained in place until Israel took control of the building in 1967.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[96]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils,_1870s.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg/220px-Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg/330px-Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg/440px-Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2978" data-file-height="2313" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils,_1870s.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Jews at the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a>, 1870s</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1470, Isaac b. Meir Latif arrived from Italy and counted 150 Jewish families in Jerusalem.<sup id="cite_ref-Bahat1976_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bahat1976-100">[97]</a></sup> Thanks to <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Saragossi" title="Joseph Saragossi">Joseph Saragossi</a> who had arrived in the closing years of the 15th century, <a href="/wiki/Safed" title="Safed">Safed</a> and its environs had developed into the largest concentration of Jews in Palestine. With the help of the <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">Sephardic</a> immigration from Spain, the Jewish population had increased to 10,000 by the early 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Andrews1976_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Andrews1976-101">[98]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1516, the region was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>; it remained under <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Syria" title="Ottoman Syria">Turkish rule</a> until the end of the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>, when Britain defeated the Ottoman forces and set up a <a href="/wiki/Occupied_Enemy_Territory_Administration" title="Occupied Enemy Territory Administration">military administration</a> across the former Ottoman Syria. In 1920 the territory was divided between Britain and France under the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate" title="League of Nations mandate">mandate system</a>, and the British-administered area which included modern day Israel was named <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Mandatory Palestine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GudrunKramer_97-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GudrunKramer-97">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[100]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Zionism_and_British_mandate">Zionism and British mandate</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yishuv" title="Yishuv">Yishuv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Mandatory Palestine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Balfour_Declaration" title="Balfour Declaration">Balfour Declaration</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Theodor_Herzl.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Black and white portrait of a long-bearded man." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Theodor_Herzl.jpg/170px-Theodor_Herzl.jpg" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Theodor_Herzl.jpg/255px-Theodor_Herzl.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Theodor_Herzl.jpg/340px-Theodor_Herzl.jpg 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="1200" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Theodor_Herzl.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Theodor_Herzl" title="Theodor Herzl">Theodor Herzl</a>, visionary of the Jewish state</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Since the existence of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Jewish_diaspora" title="Jewish diaspora">Jewish diaspora</a>, many Jews have aspired to return to "Zion" and the "Land of Israel",<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[101]</a></sup> though the amount of effort that should be spent towards such an aim was a matter of dispute.<sup id="cite_ref-Return_to_Zion_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Return_to_Zion-105">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[103]</a></sup> The hopes and yearnings of Jews living in exile are an important theme of the Jewish belief system.<sup id="cite_ref-Return_to_Zion_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Return_to_Zion-105">[102]</a></sup> After the Jews were <a href="/wiki/Alhambra_Decree" title="Alhambra Decree">expelled from Spain</a> in 1492, some communities settled in Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[104]</a></sup> During the 16th century, Jewish communities struck roots in the <a href="/wiki/Four_Holy_Cities" title="Four Holy Cities">Four Holy Cities</a>—<a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Safed" title="Safed">Safed</a>—and in 1697, Rabbi Yehuda Hachasid led a group of 1,500 Jews to Jerusalem.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[105]</a></sup> In the second half of the 18th century, Eastern European <a href="/wiki/Misnagdim" title="Misnagdim">opponents</a> of <a href="/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism" title="Hasidic Judaism">Hasidism</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/Perushim" title="Perushim">Perushim</a>, settled in Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[106]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[108]</a></sup></p>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width:240px; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #F9F9F9;">
<div class="" style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"Therefore I believe that a wonderous generation of Jews will spring into existence. The Maccabaeans will rise again. Let me repeat once more my opening words: The Jews wish to have a State, and they shall have one. We shall live at last as free men on our own soil, and die peacefully in our own home. The world will be freed by our liberty, enriched by our wealth, magnified by our greatness. And whatever we attempt there to accomplish for our own welfare will react with beneficent force for the good of humanity."</p>
</div>
</div>
<cite style="display: block; text-align: left;"><span class="citation book">Theodor Herzl (1896). <i><a href="/wiki/File:Wikisource-logo.svg" class="image"><img alt="Wikisource link to" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" /></a>&#160;<a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/A_Jewish_State_(1917_translation)/Conclusion" class="extiw" title="wikisource:A Jewish State (1917 translation)/Conclusion">A Jewish State</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a>.</span><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%5B%5BFile%3AWikisource-logo.svg%7C12px%7Calt%3DWikisource+link+to%5D%5D%26nbsp%3B%5B%5Bwikisource%3AA+Jewish+State+%281917+translation%29%2FConclusion%7CA+Jewish+State%5D%5D&amp;rft.aulast=Theodor+Herzl&amp;rft.au=Theodor+Herzl&amp;rft.date=1896&amp;rft.pub=%5B%5BWikisource%5D%5D&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/en.wikipedia.org:Israel"><span style="display: none;">&#160;</span></span>&#160;<a href="/wiki/File:Wikisource-logo.svg" class="image"><img alt="Wikisource link" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" /></a>&#160;<span style="font-size:90%;"><a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page:A_Jewish_State_1917.djvu/60" class="extiw" title="wikisource:Page:A Jewish State 1917.djvu/60"><span style="font-style:normal;">[scan]</span></a></span></cite></div>
<p>The first wave of modern Jewish migration to <a href="/wiki/Southern_Syria" title="Southern Syria">Ottoman-ruled Palestine</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/First_Aliyah" title="First Aliyah">First Aliyah</a>, began in 1881, as Jews fled <a href="/wiki/Pogrom#Pogroms_against_Jews" title="Pogrom">pogroms</a> in Eastern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-aliyot_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aliyot-112">[109]</a></sup> Although the Zionist movement already existed in practice, <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> journalist <a href="/wiki/Theodor_Herzl" title="Theodor Herzl">Theodor Herzl</a> is credited with founding political <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[110]</a></sup> a movement which sought to establish a Jewish state in the Land of Israel, thus offering a solution to the so-called <a href="/wiki/Jewish_question" title="Jewish question">Jewish question</a> of the European states, in conformity with the goals and achievements of other national projects of the time.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[111]</a></sup> In 1896, Herzl published <i><a href="/wiki/Der_Judenstaat" title="Der Judenstaat">Der Judenstaat</a></i> (<i>The Jewish State</i>), offering his vision of a future Jewish state; the following year he presided over the <a href="/wiki/First_Zionist_Congress" title="First Zionist Congress">First Zionist Congress</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[112]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Aliyah" title="Second Aliyah">Second Aliyah</a> (1904–14), began after the <a href="/wiki/Kishinev_pogrom" title="Kishinev pogrom">Kishinev pogrom</a>; some 40,000 Jews settled in Palestine, although nearly half of them left eventually.<sup id="cite_ref-aliyot_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aliyot-112">[109]</a></sup> Both the first and second waves of migrants were mainly <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Judaism" title="Orthodox Judaism">Orthodox Jews</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[113]</a></sup> although the Second Aliyah included <a href="/wiki/Labor_Zionism" title="Labor Zionism">socialist</a> groups who established the <i><a href="/wiki/Kibbutz" title="Kibbutz">kibbutz</a></i> movement.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[114]</a></sup> During World War I, British Foreign Secretary <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Balfour" title="Arthur Balfour">Arthur Balfour</a> sent the <a href="/wiki/Balfour_Declaration_of_1917" class="mw-redirect" title="Balfour Declaration of 1917">Balfour Declaration of 1917</a> to <a href="/wiki/Walter_Rothschild,_2nd_Baron_Rothschild" title="Walter Rothschild, 2nd Baron Rothschild">Baron Rothschild</a> (Walter Rothschild, 2nd Baron Rothschild), a leader of the British Jewish community, that stated that Britain intended for the creation of a Jewish "<a href="/wiki/Homeland_for_the_Jewish_people" title="Homeland for the Jewish people">national home</a>" within the Palestinian Mandate.<sup id="cite_ref-macintyre_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-macintyre-118">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[116]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Legion" title="Jewish Legion">Jewish Legion</a>, a group primarily of Zionist volunteers, assisted in the British <a href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">conquest of Palestine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[117]</a></sup> Arab opposition to British rule and Jewish immigration led to the <a href="/wiki/1920_Palestine_riots" class="mw-redirect" title="1920 Palestine riots">1920 Palestine riots</a> and the formation of a Jewish militia known as the <a href="/wiki/Haganah" title="Haganah">Haganah</a> (meaning "The Defense" in Hebrew), from which the <a href="/wiki/Irgun" title="Irgun">Irgun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lehi_(group)" title="Lehi (group)">Lehi</a>, or the Stern Gang, paramilitary groups later split off.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[118]</a></sup> In 1922, the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> granted Britain a <a href="/wiki/British_Mandate_for_Palestine_(legal_instrument)" title="British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)">mandate over Palestine</a> under terms which included the Balfour Declaration with its promise to the Jews, and with similar provisions regarding the Arab Palestinians.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[119]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Palestine_(region)" title="Demographic history of Palestine (region)">population of the area</a> at this time was predominantly Arab and Muslim, with Jews accounting for about 11%,<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[120]</a></sup> and Arab Christians at about 9.5% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[121]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Third_Aliyah" title="Third Aliyah">Third</a> (1919–23) and <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Aliyah" title="Fourth Aliyah">Fourth Aliyahs</a> (1924–29) brought an additional 100,000 Jews to Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-aliyot_112-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aliyot-112">[109]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hitler%27s_rise_to_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Hitler's rise to power">rise of Nazism</a> and the increasing persecution of Jews in 1930s Europe led to the <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Aliyah" title="Fifth Aliyah">Fifth Aliyah</a>, with an influx of a quarter of a million Jews. This was a major cause of the <a href="/wiki/1936%E2%80%9339_Arab_revolt_in_Palestine" title="1936–39 Arab revolt in Palestine">Arab revolt of 1936–39</a> during which the British Mandate authorities alongside the Zionist militias of Haganah and Irgun killed 5,032 Arabs and wounded 14,760,<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[123]</a></sup> resulting in over ten percent of the adult male <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian Arab">Palestinian Arab</a> population killed, wounded, imprisoned or exiled.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[124]</a></sup> The British introduced restrictions on Jewish immigration to Palestine with the <a href="/wiki/White_Paper_of_1939" title="White Paper of 1939">White Paper of 1939</a>. With countries around the world turning away <a href="/wiki/Jewish_refugees" title="Jewish refugees">Jewish refugees</a> fleeing <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">the Holocaust</a>, a clandestine movement known as <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_Bet" title="Aliyah Bet">Aliyah Bet</a> was organized to bring Jews to Palestine.<sup id="cite_ref-aliyot_112-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aliyot-112">[109]</a></sup> By the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the Jewish population of Palestine had increased to 33% of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[125]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="After_World_War_II">After World War II</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Intercommunal_conflict_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine">Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">Israeli Declaration of Independence</a></div>
<p>After World War II, Britain found itself in intense <a href="/wiki/Jewish_insurgency_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="Jewish insurgency in Mandatory Palestine">conflict</a> with the Jewish community over Jewish immigration limits, as well as continued conflict with the Arab community over limit levels. The <a href="/wiki/Haganah" title="Haganah">Haganah</a> joined <a href="/wiki/Irgun" title="Irgun">Irgun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lehi_(group)" title="Lehi (group)">Lehi</a> in an armed struggle against British rule.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[126]</a></sup> At the same time, hundreds of thousands of Jewish <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_survivors" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust survivors">Holocaust survivors</a> and refugees sought a new life far from their destroyed communities in Europe. The <a href="/wiki/Yishuv" title="Yishuv">Yishuv</a> attempted to bring these refugees to Palestine but many were turned away or rounded up and placed in detention camps in <a href="/wiki/Atlit_detainee_camp" title="Atlit detainee camp">Atlit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_internment_camps" title="Cyprus internment camps">Cyprus</a> by the British.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg/170px-UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg" width="170" height="352" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg/255px-UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg/340px-UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1370" data-file-height="2838" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/UN" class="mw-redirect" title="UN">UN</a> Map, "Palestine plan of partition with economic union"</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On 22 July 1946, Irgun <a href="/wiki/King_David_Hotel_bombing" title="King David Hotel bombing">attacked</a> the British administrative headquarters for Palestine, which was housed in the southern wing<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[127]</a></sup> of the <a href="/wiki/King_David_Hotel" title="King David Hotel">King David Hotel</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-brtca_irgun_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brtca_irgun-132">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[130]</a></sup> A total of 91 people of various nationalities were killed and 46 were injured.<sup id="cite_ref-tclarke81_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tclarke81-134">[131]</a></sup> The hotel was the site of the Secretariat of the Government of Palestine and the Headquarters of the British Armed Forces in <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Palestine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Transjordan" title="Emirate of Transjordan">Transjordan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tclarke81_134-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tclarke81-134">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bethell_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bethell-135">[132]</a></sup> The attack initially had the approval of the Haganah. It was conceived as a response to <a href="/wiki/Operation_Agatha" title="Operation Agatha">Operation Agatha</a> (a series of widespread raids, including one on the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Agency_for_Israel" title="Jewish Agency for Israel">Jewish Agency</a>, conducted by the British authorities) and was the deadliest directed at the British during the Mandate era.<sup id="cite_ref-tclarke81_134-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tclarke81-134">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bethell_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bethell-135">[132]</a></sup> It was characterized as one of the "most lethal terrorist incidents of the twentieth century."<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[133]</a></sup> In 1947, the British government announced it would withdraw from Palestine, stating it was unable to arrive at a solution acceptable to both Arabs and Jews.</p>
<p>On 15 May 1947, the <a href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_United_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="General Assembly of the United Nations">General Assembly</a> of the newly formed <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> resolved that the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Special_Committee_on_Palestine" title="United Nations Special Committee on Palestine">United Nations Special Committee on Palestine</a> be created "to prepare for consideration at the next regular session of the Assembly a report on the question of Palestine."<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[134]</a></sup> In the Report of the Committee dated 3 September 1947 to the General Assembly,<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[135]</a></sup> the majority of the Committee in Chapter VI proposed a plan to replace the British Mandate with "an independent Arab State, an independent Jewish State, and the City of Jerusalem ... the last to be under an International Trusteeship System."<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[136]</a></sup> On 29 November 1947, the General Assembly adopted <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">Resolution 181 (II)</a> recommending the adoption and implementation of the <i>Plan of Partition with Economic Union</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[137]</a></sup> The plan attached to the resolution was essentially that proposed by the majority of the Committee in the report of 3 September. The <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish Agency">Jewish Agency</a>, which was the recognized representative of the Jewish community, accepted the plan. The <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arab_Higher_Committee" title="Arab Higher Committee">Arab Higher Committee</a> of Palestine rejected it, and indicated that they would reject any other plan of partition.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris2008p66_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2008p66-141">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[139]</a></sup> On the following day, 1 December 1947, the Arab Higher Committee proclaimed a three-day strike, and Arab gangs began attacking Jewish targets.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[140]</a></sup> The Jews were initially on the defensive as <a href="/wiki/1947%E2%80%9348_Civil_War_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="1947–48 Civil War in Mandatory Palestine">civil war</a> broke out, but in early April 1948 moved onto the offensive.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[142]</a></sup> The Arab Palestinian economy collapsed and 250,000 Palestinian Arabs fled or were expelled.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[143]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg/220px-Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg/330px-Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg/440px-Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="872" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a> proclaiming the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">Israeli Declaration of Independence</a> on 14 May 1948</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On 14 May 1948, the day before the expiration of the British Mandate, <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a>, the head of the Jewish Agency, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">declared</a> "the establishment of a Jewish state in <a href="/wiki/Eretz-Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Eretz-Israel">Eretz-Israel</a>, to be known as the State of Israel."<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[145]</a></sup> The only reference in the text of the Declaration to the borders of the new state is the use of the term <i>Eretz-Israel</i> ("<a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>").<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[146]</a></sup> The following day, the armies of four Arab countries—<a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="Kingdom of Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Republic_(1930%E2%80%9358)" title="Syrian Republic (1930–58)">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Transjordan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Iraq" title="Kingdom of Iraq">Iraq</a>—entered what had been British Mandatory Palestine, launching the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[148]</a></sup> contingents from Yemen, Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Sudan joined the war.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[150]</a></sup> The apparent purpose of the invasion was to prevent the establishment of the Jewish state at inception, and some Arab leaders talked about driving the Jews into the sea.<sup id="cite_ref-Tal2004p469_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tal2004p469-154">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Morris2009p396_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2009p396-155">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Morris2009p187_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2009p187-156">[153]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Benny_Morris" title="Benny Morris">Benny Morris</a>, Jews felt that the invading Arab armies aimed to slaughter the Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris2009p198_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2009p198-157">[154]</a></sup> The Arab league stated that the invasion was to restore law and order and to prevent further bloodshed.<sup id="cite_ref-cablegram_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cablegram-158">[155]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_(Eilat).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg/170px-Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg" width="170" height="260" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg/255px-Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg/340px-Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1844" data-file-height="2821" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_(Eilat).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Raising of the <a href="/wiki/Ink_Flag" title="Ink Flag">Ink Flag</a>, marking the end of the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>After a year of fighting, a <a href="/wiki/1949_Armistice_Agreements" title="1949 Armistice Agreements">ceasefire was declared</a> and temporary borders, known as the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a>, were established.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[156]</a></sup> Jordan <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_occupation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian occupation of the West Bank">annexed</a> what became known as the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, including <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, and Egypt <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Gaza_Strip_by_Egypt" title="Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt">took control</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a>. The United Nations estimated that more than 700,000 Palestinians were <a href="/wiki/1948_Palestinian_exodus" title="1948 Palestinian exodus">expelled by or fled from</a> advancing <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israeli forces</a> during the conflict—what would become known in Arabic as the <i>Nakba</i> ("catastrophe").<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[157]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years_of_the_State_of_Israel">Early years of the State of Israel</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">Arab–Israeli conflict</a></div>
<p>Israel <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_273" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 273">was admitted</a> as a member of the United Nations by majority vote on 11 May 1949.<sup id="cite_ref-UN-israel1949_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN-israel1949-161">[158]</a></sup> Both Israel and Jordan were genuinely interested in a peace agreement but the British acted as a brake on the Jordanian effort in order to avoid damaging British interests in Egypt.<sup id="cite_ref-Louis1984p579_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Louis1984p579-162">[159]</a></sup> In the early years of the state, the <a href="/wiki/Labor_Zionism" title="Labor Zionism">Labor Zionist</a> movement led by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion dominated <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel" title="Politics of Israel">Israeli politics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BG-Israel_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BG-Israel-163">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[161]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kibbutzim" class="mw-redirect" title="Kibbutzim">Kibbutzim</a>, or collective farming communities, played a pivotal role in establishing the new state.<sup id="cite_ref-Jewish_Virtual_Library_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jewish_Virtual_Library-165">[162]</a></sup></p>
<p>Immigration to Israel during the late 1940s and early 1950s was aided by the Israeli Immigration Department and the non-government sponsored <a href="/wiki/Mossad_LeAliyah_Bet" title="Mossad LeAliyah Bet">Mossad LeAliyah Bet</a> ("Institution for Illegal Immigration"<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[163]</a></sup>). Both groups facilitated regular immigration logistics like arranging transportation, but the latter also engaged in clandestine operations in countries, particularly in the Middle East and Eastern Europe, where the lives of Jews were believed to be in danger and exit from those places was difficult. Mossad LeAliyah Bet was disbanded in 1953.<sup id="cite_ref-Segev1986p105_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Segev1986p105-167">[164]</a></sup> The immigration was in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/One_Million_Plan" title="One Million Plan">One Million Plan</a>. The immigrants came for differing reasons. Some believed in a Zionist ideology or did it for the promise of a better life in Israel, while others moved to escape persecution or were expelled.<sup id="cite_ref-Shulewitz1_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shulewitz1-168">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Laskier1995p579_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Laskier1995p579-169">[166]</a></sup></p>
<p>An <a href="/wiki/Aliyah#Early_statehood_.281948.E2.80.931960.29" title="Aliyah">influx of Holocaust survivors</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jewish_exodus_from_Arab_and_Muslim_countries" title="Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries">Jews from Arab and Muslim countries</a> to Israel during the first three years increased the number of Jews from 700,000 to 1,400,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Israel-population_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israel-population-170">[167]</a></sup> By 1958, the population of Israel rose to two million.<sup id="cite_ref-Israel-population_170-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israel-population-170">[167]</a></sup> Between 1948 and 1970, approximately 1,150,000 Jewish refugees relocated to Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-bard_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bard-171">[168]</a></sup> Some new immigrants arrived as refugees with no possessions and were housed in temporary camps known as <i><a href="/wiki/Ma%27abarot" title="Ma'abarot">ma'abarot</a></i>; by 1952, over 200,000 people were living in these tent cities.<sup id="cite_ref-immigrants-tents_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-immigrants-tents-172">[169]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Jews of European background</a> were often treated more favorably than Jews from <a href="/wiki/Mizrahi_Jews" title="Mizrahi Jews">Middle Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">North African</a> countries—housing units reserved for the latter were often re-designated for the former, with the result that Jews newly arrived from Arab lands generally ended up staying in transit camps for longer.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[170]</a></sup> Tensions that developed between the two groups over such discrimination persist to the present day.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[171]</a></sup> During this period, food, clothes and furniture had to be rationed in what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Austerity_in_Israel" title="Austerity in Israel">austerity period</a>. The need to solve the crisis led Ben-Gurion to sign a <a href="/wiki/Reparations_Agreement_between_Israel_and_West_Germany" title="Reparations Agreement between Israel and West Germany">reparations agreement with West Germany</a> that triggered mass protests by Jews angered at the idea that Israel could accept monetary compensation for the Holocaust.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[172]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
<div id="mwe_player_1" class="PopUpMediaTransform" style="width:220px;" videopayload="&lt;div class=&quot;mediaContainer&quot; style=&quot;width:400px&quot;&gt;&lt;video id=&quot;mwe_player_2&quot; poster=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv/400px--1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv.jpg&quot; type=&quot;video/ogg; codecs=&amp;quot;theora, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Small Ogg video (240P)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;Ogg 240P&quot; data-transcodekey=&quot;240p.ogv&quot; data-width=&quot;334&quot;
