data-mwprovider=&quot;wikimediacommons&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"><img alt="File:1961-04-13 Tale Of Century - Eichmann Tried For War Crimes.ogv" style="width:220px;height:158px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv/220px--1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv.jpg" /><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/34/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
U.S. newsreel on the trial of <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Eichmann" title="Adolf Eichmann">Adolf Eichmann</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>During the 1950s, Israel was frequently <a href="/wiki/List_of_attacks_against_Israeli_civilians_before_1967" title="List of attacks against Israeli civilians before 1967">attacked</a> by <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_fedayeen" title="Palestinian fedayeen">Palestinian fedayeen</a>, nearly always against civilians,<sup id="cite_ref-Nasr1996p40_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nasr1996p40-176">[173]</a></sup> mainly from the Egyptian-occupied Gaza Strip,<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[174]</a></sup> leading to several Israeli <a href="/wiki/Reprisal_operations" title="Reprisal operations">counter-raids</a>. In 1956, Great Britain and France aimed at regaining control of the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>, which the Egyptians had nationalized. The continued blockade of the Suez Canal and <a href="/wiki/Straits_of_Tiran" title="Straits of Tiran">Straits of Tiran</a> to Israeli shipping, together with the growing amount of Fedayeen attacks against Israel's southern population, and recent Arab grave and threatening statements, prompted Israel to attack Egypt.<sup id="cite_ref-Alteras1993p192_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alteras1993p192-178">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Caraccilo2011p113_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Caraccilo2011p113-179">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dowty2005p102_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dowty2005p102-180">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jvl-nasser1956_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jvl-nasser1956-181">[178]</a></sup> Israel joined <a href="/wiki/Protocol_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Protocol of Sèvres">a secret alliance</a> with Great Britain and France and overran the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> but was pressured to withdraw by the United Nations in return for guarantees of Israeli shipping rights in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> via the Straits of Tiran and the Canal<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="mistake. not the canal (March 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[179]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[180]</a></sup> The war, known as the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a>, resulted in significant reduction of Israeli border infiltration.<sup id="cite_ref-Morris2011p300_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morris2011p300-184">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-killed-hostile_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-killed-hostile-185">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jvl-terror-fatality_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jvl-terror-fatality-186">[183]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jvl-eban-killed_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jvl-eban-killed-187">[184]</a></sup> In the early 1960s, Israel captured Nazi war criminal <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Eichmann" title="Adolf Eichmann">Adolf Eichmann</a> in Argentina and brought him to Israel for trial.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[185]</a></sup> The trial had a major impact on public awareness of the Holocaust.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[186]</a></sup> Eichmann remains the only person executed in Israel by conviction by an <a href="/wiki/Israeli_judicial_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Israeli judicial system">Israeli civilian court</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[187]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Six_Day_War_Territories.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Six_Day_War_Territories.svg/170px-Six_Day_War_Territories.svg.png" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Six_Day_War_Territories.svg/255px-Six_Day_War_Territories.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Six_Day_War_Territories.svg/340px-Six_Day_War_Territories.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1200" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Six_Day_War_Territories.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Territory held by Israel:
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ffffd0; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;before the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a></div>
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #f7d3aa; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;after the war</div>
The <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> was returned to Egypt in 1982.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Since 1964, Arab countries, concerned over Israeli plans to divert waters of the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_coastal_plain" title="Israeli coastal plain">coastal plain</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[188]</a></sup> had been trying to divert the headwaters to deprive Israel of water resources, provoking <a href="/wiki/War_over_Water_(Jordan_river)" title="War over Water (Jordan river)">tensions</a> between Israel on the one hand, and Syria and Lebanon on the other. <a href="/wiki/Arab_nationalism" title="Arab nationalism">Arab nationalists</a> led by Egyptian President <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> refused to recognize Israel, and called for its destruction.<sup id="cite_ref-RoutledgeAtlas_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RoutledgeAtlas-22">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[190]</a></sup> By 1966, Israeli-Arab relations had deteriorated to the point of actual battles taking place between Israeli and Arab forces.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[191]</a></sup> In May 1967, Egypt massed its army near the border with Israel, expelled <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Emergency_Force" title="United Nations Emergency Force">UN peacekeepers</a>, stationed in the Sinai Peninsula since 1957, and blocked Israel's access to the Red Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[193]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[194]</a></sup> Other Arab states mobilized their forces.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[195]</a></sup> Israel reiterated that these actions were a <i><a href="/wiki/Casus_belli" title="Casus belli">casus belli</a></i> and, on 5 June, launched a <a href="/wiki/Operation_Focus" title="Operation Focus">pre-emptive strike</a> against Egypt. Jordan, Syria and Iraq responded and attacked Israel. In a <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, Israel defeated Jordan and captured the West Bank, defeated Egypt and captured the Gaza Strip and Sinai Peninsula, and defeated Syria and captured the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[196]</a></sup> Jerusalem's boundaries were enlarged, incorporating <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, and the 1949 <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a> became the administrative boundary between Israel and the <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">occupied territories</a>.</p>
<p>Following the 1967 war and the <a href="/wiki/Khartoum_Resolution" title="Khartoum Resolution">"three nos"</a> resolution of the Arab League, during the 1967–1970 <a href="/wiki/War_of_Attrition" title="War of Attrition">War of Attrition</a> Israel faced attacks from the Egyptians in the Sinai, and from Palestinian groups targeting Israelis in the occupied territories, in Israel proper, and around the world. Most important among the various Palestinian and Arab groups was the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Liberation_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian Liberation Organization">Palestinian Liberation Organization</a> (PLO), established in 1964, which initially committed itself to "armed struggle as the only way to liberate the homeland".<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[197]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[198]</a></sup> In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Palestinian groups launched a <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_political_violence" title="Palestinian political violence">wave of attacks</a><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[200]</a></sup> against Israeli and Jewish targets around the world,<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[201]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Munich_massacre" title="Munich massacre">a massacre of Israeli athletes</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics" title="1972 Summer Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> in Munich. The Israeli government responded with an <a href="/wiki/Operation_Wrath_of_God" title="Operation Wrath of God">assassination campaign</a> against the organizers of the massacre, a <a href="/wiki/1972_Israeli_air_raid_in_Syria_and_Lebanon" title="1972 Israeli air raid in Syria and Lebanon">bombing</a> and a <a href="/wiki/1973_Israeli_raid_on_Lebanon" title="1973 Israeli raid on Lebanon">raid on the PLO headquarters in Lebanon</a>.</p>
<p>On 6 October 1973, as Jews were observing <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur" title="Yom Kippur">Yom Kippur</a>, the Egyptian and Syrian armies launched <a href="/wiki/Operation_Badr_(1973)" title="Operation Badr (1973)">a surprise attack</a> against Israeli forces in the Sinai Peninsula and Golan Heights, that opened the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a>. The war ended on 25 October with Israel successfully repelling Egyptian and Syrian forces but having suffered over 2,500 soldiers killed in a war which collectively took 10–35,000 lives in about 20 days.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[202]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Agranat_Commission" title="Agranat Commission">internal inquiry</a> exonerated <a href="/wiki/Fifteenth_government_of_Israel" title="Fifteenth government of Israel">the government</a> of responsibility for failures before and during the war, but public anger forced Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Golda_Meir" title="Golda Meir">Golda Meir</a> to resign.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[203]</a></sup> In July 1976 an airliner was hijacked during its flight from Israel to France by Palestinian guerrillas and landed at <a href="/wiki/Entebbe_International_Airport" title="Entebbe International Airport">Entebbe</a>, Uganda. Israeli commandos carried out <a href="/wiki/Operation_Entebbe" title="Operation Entebbe">an operation</a> in which 102 out of 106 Israeli hostages were successfully rescued.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_conflict_and_peace_process">Further conflict and peace process</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_peace_process" title="Israeli–Palestinian peace process">Israeli–Palestinian peace process</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Israeli_legislative_election,_1977" title="Israeli legislative election, 1977">1977 Knesset elections</a> marked a major turning point in Israeli political history as <a href="/wiki/Menachem_Begin" title="Menachem Begin">Menachem Begin</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Likud" title="Likud">Likud</a> party took control from the <a href="/wiki/Labor_Party_(Israel)" class="mw-redirect" title="Labor Party (Israel)">Labor Party</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[204]</a></sup> Later that year, Egyptian President <a href="/wiki/Anwar_El_Sadat" class="mw-redirect" title="Anwar El Sadat">Anwar El Sadat</a> made a trip to Israel and spoke before the <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> in what was the first recognition of Israel by an Arab head of state.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[205]</a></sup> In the two years that followed, Sadat and Begin signed the <a href="/wiki/Camp_David_Accords" title="Camp David Accords">Camp David Accords</a> (1978) and the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Egypt_Peace_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel–Egypt Peace Treaty">Israel–Egypt Peace Treaty</a> (1979).<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[206]</a></sup> In return, Israel withdrew from the Sinai Peninsula and agreed to enter negotiations over an autonomy for Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[207]</a></sup></p>
<p>On 11 March 1978, a PLO guerilla raid from Lebanon led to the <a href="/wiki/Coastal_Road_massacre" title="Coastal Road massacre">Coastal Road massacre</a>. Israel responded by launching an <a href="/wiki/1978_South_Lebanon_conflict" title="1978 South Lebanon conflict">invasion of southern Lebanon</a> to destroy the PLO bases south of the <a href="/wiki/Litani_River" title="Litani River">Litani River</a>. Most PLO fighters withdrew, but Israel was able to secure southern Lebanon until a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon" title="United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon">UN force</a> and the Lebanese army could take over. The PLO soon resumed its <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_insurgency_in_South_Lebanon" title="Palestinian insurgency in South Lebanon">policy of attacks</a> against Israel. In the next few years, the PLO infiltrated the south and kept up a sporadic shelling across the border. Israel carried out numerous retaliatory attacks by air and on the ground.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg/220px-Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg/330px-Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg/440px-Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1264" data-file-height="826" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_from_mt_olives.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Israel's 1980 <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">law</a> declared that "<a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, complete and united, is the capital of Israel."<sup id="cite_ref-Jerusalem_Law_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jerusalem_Law-13">[12]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Meanwhile, Begin's government provided incentives for Israelis to <a href="/wiki/Israeli_settlements" class="mw-redirect" title="Israeli settlements">settle</a> in the occupied West Bank, increasing friction with the Palestinians in that area.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[208]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Basic Law: Jerusalem, Capital of Israel</a>, passed in 1980, was believed by some to reaffirm Israel's 1967 annexation of Jerusalem by government decree, and <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council_Resolution_478" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council Resolution 478">reignited international controversy</a> over the <a href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">status of the city</a>. No Israeli legislation has defined the territory of Israel and no act specifically included East Jerusalem therein.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[209]</a></sup> The position of the majority of UN member states is reflected in numerous resolutions declaring that actions taken by Israel to settle its citizens in the West Bank, and impose its laws and administration on East Jerusalem, are illegal and have no validity.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[210]</a></sup> In 1981 Israel <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights_Law" title="Golan Heights Law">annexed</a> the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>, although annexation was not recognized internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_golan_profile_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_golan_profile-214">[211]</a></sup> Israel's population diversity expanded in the 1980s and 1990s. Several waves of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethiopian Jews">Ethiopian Jews</a> <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_from_Ethiopia" title="Aliyah from Ethiopia">immigrated</a> to Israel since the 1980s, while between 1990 and 1994, <a href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">immigration from the post-Soviet states</a> increased Israel's population by twelve percent.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[212]</a></sup></p>
<p>On 7 June 1981, the Israeli air force <a href="/wiki/Operation_Opera" title="Operation Opera">destroyed</a> Iraq's sole <a href="/wiki/Osirak" class="mw-redirect" title="Osirak">nuclear reactor</a> under construction just outside <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, in order to impede Iraq's nuclear weapons program. Following a series of PLO attacks in 1982, Israel <a href="/wiki/1982_Lebanon_War" title="1982 Lebanon War">invaded</a> Lebanon that year to destroy the bases from which the PLO launched attacks and missiles into northern Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[213]</a></sup> In the first six days of fighting, the Israelis destroyed the military forces of the PLO in Lebanon and decisively defeated the Syrians. An Israeli government inquiry—the <a href="/wiki/Kahan_Commission" title="Kahan Commission">Kahan Commission</a>—would later hold Begin, Sharon and several Israeli generals as indirectly responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Sabra_and_Shatila_massacre" title="Sabra and Shatila massacre">Sabra and Shatila massacre</a>. In 1985, Israel responded to a Palestinian terrorist attack in <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> by <a href="/wiki/Operation_Wooden_Leg" title="Operation Wooden Leg">bombing</a> the PLO headquarters in Tunisia. Israel withdrew from most of Lebanon in 1986, but maintained a <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_Southern_Lebanon" title="Israeli occupation of Southern Lebanon">borderland buffer zone</a> in southern Lebanon until 2000, from where Israeli forces <a href="/wiki/South_Lebanon_conflict_(1985%E2%80%932000)" title="South Lebanon conflict (1985–2000)">engaged in conflict</a> with <a href="/wiki/Hezbollah" title="Hezbollah">Hezbollah</a>. The <a href="/wiki/First_Intifada" title="First Intifada">First Intifada</a>, a Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule,<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[214]</a></sup> broke out in 1987, with waves of uncoordinated demonstrations and violence occurring in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Over the following six years, the Intifada became more organised and included economic and cultural measures aimed at disrupting the Israeli occupation. More than a thousand people were killed in the violence.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[215]</a></sup> During the 1991 <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a>, the PLO supported <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> and Iraqi Scud missile <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War#Iraqi_missile_strikes_on_Israel_and_Saudi_Arabia" title="Gulf War">attacks against Israel</a>. Despite public outrage, Israel heeded <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">American</a> calls to refrain from hitting back and did not participate in that war.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[217]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_(GPO)_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg/330px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg/440px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2048" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_(GPO)_-_PM_YITZHAK_RABIN_AND_KING_HUSSEIN_SHAKING_HANDS.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> watches Israeli Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Yitzhak_Rabin" title="Yitzhak Rabin">Yitzhak Rabin</a> (left) and King <a href="/wiki/Hussein_of_Jordan" title="Hussein of Jordan">Hussein of Jordan</a> (right) shaking hands after the signing of the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_peace_treaty" title="Israel–Jordan peace treaty">Israel–Jordan peace treaty</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1992, <a href="/wiki/Yitzhak_Rabin" title="Yitzhak Rabin">Yitzhak Rabin</a> became Prime Minister following <a href="/wiki/Israeli_legislative_election,_1992" title="Israeli legislative election, 1992">an election</a> in which his party called for compromise with Israel's neighbors.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[219]</a></sup> The following year, <a href="/wiki/Shimon_Peres" title="Shimon Peres">Shimon Peres</a> on behalf of Israel, and <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Abbas" title="Mahmoud Abbas">Mahmoud Abbas</a> for the PLO, signed the <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Accords" title="Oslo Accords">Oslo Accords</a>, which gave the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian National Authority</a> the right to govern parts of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[220]</a></sup> The PLO also <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Palestine_Liberation_Organization_letters_of_recognition" title="Israel–Palestine Liberation Organization letters of recognition">recognized</a> Israel's right to exist and pledged an end to terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[221]</a></sup> In 1994, the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_peace_treaty" title="Israel–Jordan peace treaty">Israel–Jordan peace treaty</a> was signed, making Jordan the second Arab country to normalize relations with Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[222]</a></sup> Arab public support for the Accords was damaged by the continuation of Israeli settlements<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[223]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_checkpoint" title="Israeli checkpoint">checkpoints</a>, and the deterioration of economic conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[224]</a></sup> Israeli public support for the Accords waned as Israel was struck by <a href="/wiki/List_of_Palestinian_suicide_attacks" title="List of Palestinian suicide attacks">Palestinian suicide attacks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[225]</a></sup> In November 1995, while leaving a peace rally, Yitzhak Rabin <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Yitzhak_Rabin" title="Assassination of Yitzhak Rabin">was assassinated</a> by <a href="/wiki/Yigal_Amir" title="Yigal Amir">Yigal Amir</a>, a far-right-wing Jew who opposed the Accords.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[226]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg/220px-DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg/330px-DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg/440px-DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1887" data-file-height="1250" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:DolphinariumNightClub.2012.04.16.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The site of the 2001 Tel Aviv <a href="/wiki/Dolphinarium_discotheque_massacre" title="Dolphinarium discotheque massacre">Dolphinarium discotheque massacre</a>, in which 21 Israelis were killed.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a> at the end of the 1990s, Israel <a href="/wiki/Protocol_Concerning_the_Redeployment_in_Hebron" title="Protocol Concerning the Redeployment in Hebron">withdrew</a> from <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[227]</a></sup> and signed the <a href="/wiki/Wye_River_Memorandum" title="Wye River Memorandum">Wye River Memorandum</a>, giving greater control to the Palestinian National Authority.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[228]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ehud_Barak" title="Ehud Barak">Ehud Barak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_general_election,_1999" title="Israeli general election, 1999">elected</a> Prime Minister in 1999, began the new millennium by withdrawing forces from Southern Lebanon and conducting negotiations with Palestinian Authority Chairman <a href="/wiki/Yasser_Arafat" title="Yasser Arafat">Yasser Arafat</a> and U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2000_Camp_David_Summit" title="2000 Camp David Summit">2000 Camp David Summit</a>. During the summit, Barak offered a plan for the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian state">Palestinian state</a>. The proposed state included the entirety of the Gaza Strip and over 90% of the West Bank with Jerusalem as a shared capital.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[229]</a></sup> Each side blamed the other for the failure of the talks. After a controversial visit by Likud leader <a href="/wiki/Ariel_Sharon" title="Ariel Sharon">Ariel Sharon</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Intifada" title="Second Intifada">Second Intifada</a> began. Some commentators contend that the uprising was pre-planned by Arafat due to the collapse of peace talks.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-jewishweek_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jewishweek-235">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-atlantic_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-atlantic-236">[233]</a></sup> Sharon became prime minister in a <a href="/wiki/Israeli_prime_ministerial_election,_2001" title="Israeli prime ministerial election, 2001">2001 special election</a>. During his tenure, Sharon carried out his plan to <a href="/wiki/Israeli_disengagement_from_Gaza" title="Israeli disengagement from Gaza">unilaterally withdraw</a> from the Gaza Strip and also spearheaded the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[234]</a></sup> ending the Intifada.<sup id="cite_ref-rage_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rage-238">[235]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[236]</a></sup> By this time 1,100 Israelis had been killed, mostly in suicide bombings.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[237]</a></sup> The Palestinian fatalities, from 2000 to 2008, reached 4,791 killed by Israeli security forces, 44 killed by Israeli civilians, and 609 killed by Palestinians.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[238]</a></sup></p>
<p>In July 2006, a Hezbollah artillery assault on Israel's northern border communities and a <a href="/wiki/2006_Hezbollah_cross-border_raid" title="2006 Hezbollah cross-border raid">cross-border abduction</a> of two Israeli soldiers precipitated the month-long <a href="/wiki/Second_Lebanon_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Lebanon War">Second Lebanon War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UN1701_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN1701-242">[239]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HRTZ_Harel_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRTZ_Harel-243">[240]</a></sup> On 6 September 2007, the Israeli Air Force <a href="/wiki/Operation_Orchard" title="Operation Orchard">destroyed</a> a nuclear reactor in Syria. At the end of 2008, Israel entered another conflict as <a href="/wiki/2008_Israel%E2%80%93Hamas_ceasefire" title="2008 Israel–Hamas ceasefire">a ceasefire</a> between <a href="/wiki/Hamas" title="Hamas">Hamas</a> and Israel collapsed. The <a href="/wiki/Gaza_War_(2008%E2%80%9309)" title="Gaza War (2008–09)">2008–09 Gaza War</a> lasted three weeks and ended after Israel announced a unilateral ceasefire.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ravid_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ravid-245">[242]</a></sup> Hamas announced its own ceasefire, with its own conditions of complete withdrawal and opening of <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Blockade of the Gaza Strip">border crossings</a>. Despite neither the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel" title="Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel">rocket launchings</a> nor Israeli <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_attacks_on_the_Gaza_strip" title="List of Israeli attacks on the Gaza strip">retaliatory strikes</a> having completely stopped, the fragile ceasefire remained in order.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[243]</a></sup> In what Israel described as a response to <a href="/wiki/List_of_Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel,_2012" title="List of Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel, 2012">more than a hundred Palestinian rocket attacks</a> on southern Israeli cities,<sup id="cite_ref-pound_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pound-247">[244]</a></sup> Israel began an <a href="/wiki/Operation_Pillar_of_Defense" title="Operation Pillar of Defense">operation</a> in Gaza on 14 November 2012, lasting eight days.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[245]</a></sup> Israel started another <a href="/wiki/Operation_Protective_Edge" class="mw-redirect" title="Operation Protective Edge">operation</a> in Gaza following an <a href="/wiki/List_of_Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel,_2014" title="List of Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel, 2014">escalation of rocket attacks</a> by Hamas in July 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[246]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_environment">Geography and environment</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Israel" title="Geography of Israel">Geography of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Israel" title="Wildlife of Israel">Wildlife of Israel</a></div>
<div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 220px; float: right; clear: right; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative; max-width: 100%; overflow-x: auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_relief_location_map.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Israel_relief_location_map.jpg/220px-Israel_relief_location_map.jpg" width="220" height="409" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Israel_relief_location_map.jpg/330px-Israel_relief_location_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Israel_relief_location_map.jpg/440px-Israel_relief_location_map.jpg 2x" data-file-width="614" data-file-height="1141" /></a>
<div style="position:absolute; left:0.6px; top:7.4px"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Israel" title="Geography of Israel">Geography of Israel</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:2.8px; top:388px">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>

</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:165.6px; top:27.2px"><a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan<br />
Heights</a></div>

plain</a></div>

Mountains</a></div>

Valley</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:82px; top:245px"><a href="/wiki/Negev" title="Negev">Negev</a></div>

(<a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a>)</small></div>

of Eilat</a></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:117.2px; top:124px"><small><i><a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank"><span style="color:gray;">West<br />
Bank</span></a></i></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:42.4px; top:185.6px"><small><i><a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip"><span style="color:gray;">Gaza<br />
Strip</span></a></i></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:134.8px; top:3px"><small><i><a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon"><span style="color:gray;">Lebanon</span></a></i></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:194.2px; top:5.2px"><small><i><a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria"><span style="color:gray;">Syria</span></a></i></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:181px; top:168px"><small><i><a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan"><span style="color:gray;">Jordan</span></a></i></small></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:27px; top:278px"><small><i><a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt"><span style="color:gray;">Egypt</span></a></i></small></div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:100px;max-width:100px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:232px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg/98px-Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg" width="98" height="233" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg/147px-Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg/196px-Satellite_image_of_Israel_in_January_2003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="727" data-file-height="1731" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:108px;max-width:108px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:232px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_at_night.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Israel_at_night.jpg/106px-Israel_at_night.jpg" width="106" height="232" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Israel_at_night.jpg/159px-Israel_at_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Israel_at_night.jpg/212px-Israel_at_night.jpg 2x" data-file-width="274" data-file-height="600" /></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/Satellite_imagery" title="Satellite imagery">Satellite images</a> of Israel and neighboring territories during the day (left) and night (right)</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel is at the eastern end of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>, bounded by Lebanon to the north, Syria to the northeast, Jordan and the West Bank to the east, and Egypt and the Gaza Strip to the southwest. It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/29th_parallel_north" title="29th parallel north">29°</a> and <a href="/wiki/34th_parallel_north" title="34th parallel north">34° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/34th_meridian_east" title="34th meridian east">34°</a> and <a href="/wiki/36th_meridian_east" title="36th meridian east">36° E</a>.</p>
<p>The sovereign territory of Israel (according to the demarcation lines of the <a href="/wiki/1949_Armistice_Agreements" title="1949 Armistice Agreements">1949 Armistice Agreements</a> and excluding all territories captured by Israel during the 1967 <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>) is approximately 20,770 square kilometers (8,019&#160;sq&#160;mi) in area, of which two&#160;percent is water.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> However Israel is so narrow that the <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone" title="Exclusive economic zone">exclusive economic zone</a> in the Mediterranean is double the land area of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[247]</a></sup> The total area under Israeli law, including <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>, is 22,072 square kilometers (8,522&#160;sq&#160;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[248]</a></sup> and the total area under Israeli control, including the military-controlled and partially <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian-governed</a> territory of the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, is 27,799 square kilometers (10,733&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-loc-geo_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-loc-geo-252">[249]</a></sup></p>
<p>Despite its small size, Israel is home to a variety of geographic features, from the <a href="/wiki/Negev" title="Negev">Negev</a> desert in the south to the inland fertile <a href="/wiki/Jezreel_Valley" title="Jezreel Valley">Jezreel Valley</a>, mountain ranges of the <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Carmel" title="Mount Carmel">Carmel</a> and toward the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan</a> in the north. The <a href="/wiki/Israeli_coastal_plain" title="Israeli coastal plain">Israeli coastal plain</a> on the shores of the Mediterranean is home to most of the nation's population.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[250]</a></sup> East of the central highlands lies the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_Rift_Valley" title="Jordan Rift Valley">Jordan Rift Valley</a>, which forms a small part of the 6,500-kilometer (4,039&#160;mi) <a href="/wiki/Great_Rift_Valley" title="Great Rift Valley">Great Rift Valley</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a> runs along the Jordan Rift Valley, from <a href="/wiki/Mount_Hermon" title="Mount Hermon">Mount Hermon</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Hulah_Valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Hulah Valley">Hulah Valley</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea">Dead Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Extreme_points_of_Earth" title="Extreme points of Earth">lowest point</a> on the surface of the Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[251]</a></sup> Further south is the <a href="/wiki/Arabah" title="Arabah">Arabah</a>, ending with the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aqaba" title="Gulf of Aqaba">Gulf of Eilat</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>. Unique to Israel and the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> are <a href="/wiki/Makhtesh" title="Makhtesh">makhteshim</a>, or erosion cirques.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[252]</a></sup> The largest makhtesh in the world is <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Crater" class="mw-redirect" title="Ramon Crater">Ramon Crater</a> in the Negev,<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[253]</a></sup> which measures 40 by 8 kilometers (25 by 5&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[254]</a></sup> A report on the environmental status of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean Basin</a> states that Israel has the largest number of plant species per square meter of all the countries in the basin.<sup id="cite_ref-rinat_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rinat-258">[255]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tectonics_and_seismicity">Tectonics and seismicity</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_the_Levant" title="List of earthquakes in the Levant">List of earthquakes in the Levant</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Jordan_Rift_Valley" title="Jordan Rift Valley">Jordan Rift Valley</a> is the result of tectonic movements within the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Transform" title="Dead Sea Transform">Dead Sea Transform</a> (DSF) fault system. The DSF forms the <a href="/wiki/Transform_fault" title="Transform fault">transform boundary</a> between the <a href="/wiki/African_Plate" title="African Plate">African Plate</a> to the west and the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Plate" title="Arabian Plate">Arabian Plate</a> to the east. The Golan Heights and all of Jordan are part of the Arabian Plate, while the Galilee, West Bank, Coastal Plain, and Negev along with the Sinai Peninsula are on the African Plate. This tectonic disposition leads to a relatively high <a href="/wiki/List_of_earthquakes_in_the_Levant" title="List of earthquakes in the Levant">seismic activity in the region</a>. The entire Jordan Valley segment is thought to have ruptured repeatedly, for instance during the last two major <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Israel#Seismic_activity" title="Geography of Israel">earthquakes</a> along this structure in <a href="/wiki/749_Galilee_earthquake" title="749 Galilee earthquake">749</a> and 1033. The deficit in <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)#Slip.2C_heave.2C_throw" title="Fault (geology)">slip</a> that has built up since the 1033 event is sufficient to cause an earthquake of <a href="/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale" title="Moment magnitude scale">Mw</a>~7.4.<sup id="cite_ref-Ferry_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ferry-259">[256]</a></sup></p>
<p>The most catastrophic earthquakes we know of occurred in 31 BCE, <a href="/wiki/Galilee_earthquake_of_363" title="Galilee earthquake of 363">363</a>, 749, and 1033 CE, that is every ca. 400 years on average.<sup id="cite_ref-MarcoAFTAU_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarcoAFTAU-260">[257]</a></sup> Destructive earthquakes leading to serious loss of life strike about every 80 years.<sup id="cite_ref-IllPreped_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IllPreped-261">[258]</a></sup> While stringent construction regulations are currently in place and recently built structures are earthquake-safe, as of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the majority of the buildings in Israel were older than these regulations and many public buildings as well as 50,000 residential buildings did not meet the new standards and were "expected to collapse" if exposed to a strong quake.<sup id="cite_ref-IllPreped_261-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IllPreped-261">[258]</a></sup> Given the fragile political situation of the Middle East region and the presence there of major holy sites, a quake reaching magnitude 7 on the Richter scale could have dire consequences for world peace.<sup id="cite_ref-MarcoAFTAU_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarcoAFTAU-260">[257]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/260px-Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png" width="260" height="260" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/390px-Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/520px-Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1900" data-file-height="1900" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> map of Israel</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Temperatures in Israel vary widely, especially during the winter. Coastal areas, such as those of <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a>, have a typical <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> with cool, rainy winters and long, hot summers. The area of <a href="/wiki/Beersheba" title="Beersheba">Beersheba</a> and the Northern Negev has a <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a> with hot summers, cool winters and fewer rainy days than the Mediterranean climate. The Southern Negev and the Arava areas have <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">desert climate</a> with very hot and dry summers, and mild winters with few days of rain. The highest temperature in the continent of Asia (54.0&#160;°C or 129.2&#160;°F) was recorded in 1942 at <a href="/wiki/Tirat_Zvi" title="Tirat Zvi">Tirat Zvi</a> kibbutz in the northern Jordan river valley.<sup id="cite_ref-watzman_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-watzman-262">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[260]</a></sup></p>
<p>At the other extreme mountainous regions can be windy, cold, and areas at elevation of 750 meters or more (same elevation as Jerusalem) will usually receive at least one snowfall each year.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[261]</a></sup> From May to September, rain in Israel is rare.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[263]</a></sup> With scarce water resources, Israel has developed various water-saving technologies, including <a href="/wiki/Drip_irrigation" title="Drip irrigation">drip irrigation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[264]</a></sup> Israelis also take advantage of the considerable sunlight available for <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">solar energy</a>, making <a href="/wiki/Solar_power_in_Israel" title="Solar power in Israel">Israel the leading nation in solar energy</a> use per capita (practically every house uses solar panels for water heating).<sup id="cite_ref-Solar_energy_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_energy-268">[265]</a></sup></p>
<p>Four different <a href="/wiki/Phytogeographic" class="mw-redirect" title="Phytogeographic">phytogeographic</a> regions exist in Israel, due to the country's location between the temperate and the tropical zones, bordering the Mediterranean Sea in the west and the desert in the east. For this reason the flora and fauna of Israel is extremely diverse. There are 2,867 known <a href="/wiki/List_of_endemic_flora_of_Israel" title="List of endemic flora of Israel">species of plants found in Israel</a>. Of these, at least 253 species are <a href="/wiki/List_of_adventive_wild_plants_in_Israel" title="List of adventive wild plants in Israel">introduced</a> and non-native.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[266]</a></sup> There are 380 <a href="/wiki/National_parks_and_nature_reserves_of_Israel" title="National parks and nature reserves of Israel">Israeli nature reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[267]</a></sup></p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 217.33333333333px">
<div style="width: 217.33333333333px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 215.33333333333px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dover_tverya17.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dover_tverya17.jpg/323px-Dover_tverya17.jpg" width="216" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dover_tverya17.jpg/484px-Dover_tverya17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dover_tverya17.jpg/646px-Dover_tverya17.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4251" data-file-height="2372" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px">
<div style="width: 162px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg/240px-Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg/360px-Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg/480px-Calaniyot-OrHaner001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Field of <i><a href="/wiki/Anemone_coronaria" title="Anemone coronaria">Anemone coronaria</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Israel" title="National symbols of Israel">national flower of Israel</a></p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 241.33333333333px">
<div style="width: 241.33333333333px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 239.33333333333px;">
<div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg/359px-Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg" width="240" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg/538px-Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg/717px-Israel-2013-Aerial_00-Negev-Makhtesh_Ramon.jpg 2x" data-file-width="10312" data-file-height="5179" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Makhtesh_Ramon" title="Makhtesh Ramon">Makhtesh Ramon</a>, a type of crater unique to Israel and the Sinai Peninsula</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">
<div style="width: 182px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;">

</div>

</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 143.33333333333px">
<div style="width: 143.33333333333px">

</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Israel" title="Demographics of Israel">Demographics of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israelis" title="Israelis">Israelis</a></div>
<div class="mw-stack mobile-float-reset" style="box-sizing: border-box; float:right;">
<div style="overflow: hidden; margin: 1px;">
<div style="text-align:center; position:relative; white-space:nowrap;"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Israel" title="Religion in Israel">Religion in Israel</a>
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="position:absolute; right:0; top:0; margin:0 5px;">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Religion_in_Israel_chart" title="Template:Religion in Israel chart"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Religion_in_Israel_chart" title="Template talk:Religion in Israel chart"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Religion_in_Israel_chart&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div class="mw-graph" style="min-width:400px;min-height:250px"><img class="mw-graph-img" src="/api/rest_v1/page/graph/png/Israel/0/039752deb5e0fb4ebb51385b900d7b6dd14dc000.png" /></div>
<center><small><img alt="Pictogram voting info.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Pictogram_voting_info.svg/16px-Pictogram_voting_info.svg.png" width="16" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Pictogram_voting_info.svg/24px-Pictogram_voting_info.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Pictogram_voting_info.svg/32px-Pictogram_voting_info.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="250" data-file-height="250" />&#160;<b>Note:</b> Until 1995, figures for Christians also included Others.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[268]</a></sup></small></center>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 2017, Israel's population was an estimated 8,643,600&#160;people, of whom 6,459,700 (74.8%) were recorded by the civil government as <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Jews" title="Israeli Jews">Jews</a>. 1,799,400 <a href="/wiki/Arab_citizens_of_Israel" title="Arab citizens of Israel">Arabs</a> comprised 20.8% of the population, while non-Arab Christians and people who have no religion listed in the civil registry made up 4.4%.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[269]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-population_stat_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-population_stat-1">[1]</a></sup> Over the last decade, large numbers of migrant workers from Romania, Thailand, China, Africa, and South America have settled in Israel. Exact figures are unknown, as many of them are living in the country illegally,<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[270]</a></sup> but estimates run in the region of 203,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Adriana_Kemp_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adriana_Kemp-30">[28]</a></sup> By June 2012, approximately 60,000 <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigration_from_Africa_to_Israel" title="Illegal immigration from Africa to Israel">African migrants</a> had entered Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[271]</a></sup> About 92% of Israelis live in urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[272]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Aliyah_1948-2015.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Aliyah_1948-2015.png/300px-Aliyah_1948-2015.png" width="300" height="120" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Aliyah_1948-2015.png/450px-Aliyah_1948-2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Aliyah_1948-2015.png/600px-Aliyah_1948-2015.png 2x" data-file-width="1619" data-file-height="646" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Aliyah_1948-2015.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Immigration to Israel in the years 1948–2015. The two peaks were in 1949 and 1990.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel was established as a <a href="/wiki/Homeland_for_the_Jewish_people" title="Homeland for the Jewish people">homeland for the Jewish people</a> and is often referred to as a <a href="/wiki/Jewish_state" title="Jewish state">Jewish state</a>. The country's <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Return" title="Law of Return">Law of Return</a> grants all Jews and those of Jewish ancestry the right to <a href="/wiki/Israeli_nationality_law" title="Israeli nationality law">Israeli citizenship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[273]</a></sup> Retention of Israel's population since 1948 is about even or greater, when compared to other countries with mass immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[274]</a></sup> Jewish emigration from Israel (called <i><a href="/wiki/Yerida" title="Yerida">yerida</a></i> in Hebrew), primarily to the United States and Canada, is described by demographers as modest,<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[275]</a></sup> but is often cited by Israeli government ministries as a major threat to Israel's future.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[276]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[277]</a></sup></p>
<p>Three quarters, or 74.8%, of the population are Jews from a <a href="/wiki/Jewish_ethnic_divisions" title="Jewish ethnic divisions">diversity of Jewish backgrounds</a>. Approximately 76% of <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Jews" title="Israeli Jews">Israeli Jews</a> are <a href="/wiki/Sabra_(person)" title="Sabra (person)">born in Israel</a>, 16% are immigrants from Europe and the Americas, and 8% are immigrants from Asia and Africa (including the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[278]</a></sup> Jews from Europe and the former Soviet Union and their descendants born in Israel, including <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Ashkenazi Jews</a>, constitute approximately 50% of Jewish Israelis. <a href="/wiki/Jewish_exodus_from_Arab_and_Muslim_countries" title="Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries">Jews who left or fled Arab and Muslim countries</a> and their descendants, including both <a href="/wiki/Mizrahi_Jews" title="Mizrahi Jews">Mizrahi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">Sephardi</a> Jews,<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[279]</a></sup> form most of the rest of the Jewish population.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[280]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[281]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[282]</a></sup> Jewish intermarriage rates run at over 35% and recent studies suggest that the percentage of Israelis descended from both Sephardi and Ashkenazi Jews increases by 0.5 percent every year, with over 25% of school children now originating from both communities.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[283]</a></sup> Around 4% of Israelis (300,000), ethnically defined as "others", are <a href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">Russian descendants</a> of Jewish origin or family who are not Jewish according to rabbinical law, but were eligible for Israeli citizenship under the Law of Return.<sup id="cite_ref-DellaPergola.2C_Sergio_2011_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DellaPergola.2C_Sergio_2011-287">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Israel_people_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israel_people-288">[285]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[286]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2015<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 385,900 Israelis <a href="/wiki/Population_statistics_for_Israeli_settlements_in_the_West_Bank" title="Population statistics for Israeli settlements in the West Bank">lived</a> in <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> <a href="/wiki/Israeli_settlement" title="Israeli settlement">settlements</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-districts_pop_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-districts_pop-290">[287]</a></sup> including those that predated the establishment of the State of Israel and which were re-established after the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, in cities such as <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gush_Etzion" title="Gush Etzion">Gush Etzion</a> bloc. In addition, there were more than 200,000 Jews living in <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-jerusalem_pop_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jerusalem_pop-291">[288]</a></sup> and 20,000 in the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-districts_pop_290-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-districts_pop-290">[287]</a></sup> The total number of Israeli settlers is over 600,000 (~10% of the Jewish Israeli population). Approximately 7,800 Israelis <a href="/wiki/Population_statistics_for_Israeli_Gaza_Strip_settlements" title="Population statistics for Israeli Gaza Strip settlements">lived in settlements</a> in the Gaza Strip, known as <a href="/wiki/Gush_Katif" title="Gush Katif">Gush Katif</a>, until they were evacuated by the government as part of its 2005 <a href="/wiki/Israel%27s_unilateral_disengagement_plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel's unilateral disengagement plan">disengagement plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[289]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Major_urban_areas">Major urban areas</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Israel" title="List of cities in Israel">List of cities in Israel</a></div>
<p>There are four metropolitan areas: <a href="/wiki/Gush_Dan" title="Gush Dan">Gush Dan</a> (Tel Aviv metropolitan area; population 3,785,000), <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_metropolitan_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Jerusalem metropolitan area">Jerusalem metropolitan area</a> (population 1,223,800), <a href="/wiki/Haifa_metropolitan_area" title="Haifa metropolitan area">Haifa metropolitan area</a> (population 913,700), and <a href="/wiki/Beersheba_metropolitan_area" title="Beersheba metropolitan area">Beersheba metropolitan area</a> (population 369,200).<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[290]</a></sup> Israel's largest <a href="/wiki/City_council_(Israel)" title="City council (Israel)">municipality</a>, in population and area, is <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> with 865,721 residents in an area of 125 square kilometres (48&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-Israelpopulations_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israelpopulations-294">[291]</a></sup> Israeli government statistics on Jerusalem include the population and area of <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, which is widely recognized as part of the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_territories" title="Palestinian territories">Palestinian territories</a> under <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">Israeli occupation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[292]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a> rank as Israel's next most populous <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Israel" title="List of cities in Israel">cities</a>, with populations of 432,892 and 278,903, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-Israelpopulations_294-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israelpopulations-294">[291]</a></sup></p>
<table class="navbox">

<td style="text-align:right;">207,946</td>
<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">17</td>

</tr>
