<p><small><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_jerusalem"><b><a href="#ref_jerusalem">^a</a></b>&#160;This number includes <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> areas. Israeli sovereignty over East Jerusalem is <a href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">internationally unrecognized</a>.</span></small></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Israel" title="Languages of Israel">Languages of Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_(3777232251).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg/220px-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg/330px-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg/440px-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_(3777232251).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Road_signs_in_Israel" title="Road signs in Israel">Road sign</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel has two official languages, <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language_in_Israel" title="Arabic language in Israel">Arabic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> Hebrew is the primary language of the state and is spoken every day by the majority of the population. Arabic is spoken by the Arab minority, with Hebrew taught in Arab schools.</p>
<p>As a country of <a href="/wiki/Aliyah" title="Aliyah">immigrants</a>, many languages can be heard on the streets. Due to mass immigration from the former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_from_Ethiopia" title="Aliyah from Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> (some 130,000 <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews_in_Israel" title="Ethiopian Jews in Israel">Ethiopian Jews live in Israel</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Ethiopian_Population_In_Israel_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Ethiopian_Population_In_Israel-296">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[294]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Israel" title="Russian language in Israel">Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a> are widely spoken.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[295]</a></sup> More than one million Russian-speaking immigrants <a href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">arrived</a> in Israel from the post-Soviet states between 1990 and 2004.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[296]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> is spoken by around 700,000 Israelis,<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[297]</a></sup> mostly originating <a href="/wiki/French_Jews_in_Israel" title="French Jews in Israel">from France</a> and North Africa (see <a href="/wiki/Maghrebi_Jews" title="Maghrebi Jews">Maghrebi Jews</a>). <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> was an official language during the Mandate period; it lost this status after the establishment of Israel, but retains a role comparable to that of an official language,<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[299]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[300]</a></sup> as may be seen in <a href="/wiki/Road_signs_in_Israel" title="Road signs in Israel">road signs</a> and official documents. Many Israelis communicate reasonably well in English, as many television programs are broadcast in English with <a href="/wiki/Subtitles" class="mw-redirect" title="Subtitles">subtitles</a> and the language is taught from the early grades in elementary school. In addition, Israeli universities offer courses in the English language on various subjects.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[301]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Israel" title="Religion in Israel">Religion in Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Westernwall2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A large open area with people bounded by old stone walls. To the left is a mosque with large golden dome." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Westernwall2.jpg/220px-Westernwall2.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Westernwall2.jpg/330px-Westernwall2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Westernwall2.jpg/440px-Westernwall2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Westernwall2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a>, Jerusalem.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel comprises a major part of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>, a region of significant importance to all <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Jewish_religious_movements" title="Jewish religious movements">religious affiliation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Jews" title="Israeli Jews">Israeli Jews</a> varies widely: a social survey indicates that 49% self-identify as <a href="/wiki/Hiloni" title="Hiloni">Hiloni</a> (secular), 29% as <a href="/wiki/Masortim" title="Masortim">Masorti</a> (traditional), 13% as <a href="/wiki/Dati" class="mw-redirect" title="Dati">Dati</a> (Orthodox) and 9% as <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredi</a> (ultra-Orthodox).<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[302]</a></sup> Haredi Jews are expected to represent more than 20% of Israel's Jewish population by 2028.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[303]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG/170px-Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG/255px-Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG/340px-Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2338" data-file-height="3507" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jerusalem_Holy_Sepulchre_BW_22.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
9th <a href="/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross" title="Stations of the Cross">Station of the Cross</a> on the <i><a href="/wiki/Via_Dolorosa" title="Via Dolorosa">Via Dolorosa</a></i> street in Jerusalem. The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a> in the background is venerated by Christians as the site of the <a href="/wiki/Burial_of_Jesus" title="Burial of Jesus">Burial of Jesus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[304]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Making up 17.6% of the population, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Israel" title="Islam in Israel">Muslims</a> constitute Israel's largest religious minority. About 2% of the population is <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Israel" title="Christianity in Israel">Christian</a> and 1.6% is <a href="/wiki/Druze_in_Israel" title="Druze in Israel">Druze</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> The Christian population primarily comprises <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Arab Christians</a>, but also includes post-Soviet immigrants, the foreign laborers of multinational origins, and followers of <a href="/wiki/Messianic_Judaism" title="Messianic Judaism">Messianic Judaism</a>, considered by most Christians and Jews to be a form of Christianity.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[305]</a></sup> Members of many other religious groups, including <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Israel" title="Hinduism in Israel">Hindus</a>, maintain a presence in Israel, albeit in small numbers.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[306]</a></sup> Out of more than one million <a href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">immigrants</a> from the former Soviet Union, about 300,000 are considered not Jewish by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Rabbinate_of_Israel" title="Chief Rabbinate of Israel">Chief Rabbinate of Israel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[307]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city of <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> is of <a href="/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem" title="Religious significance of Jerusalem">special importance</a> to Jews, Muslims and Christians as it is the home of <a href="/wiki/List_of_places_in_Jerusalem" title="List of places in Jerusalem">sites</a> that are pivotal to their religious beliefs, such as the <a href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a> that incorporates the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Mosque" title="Al-Aqsa Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[308]</a></sup> Other locations of religious importance in Israel are <a href="/wiki/Nazareth" title="Nazareth">Nazareth</a> (holy in Christianity as the site of the <a href="/wiki/Annunciation" title="Annunciation">Annunciation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mary_(mother_of_Jesus)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mary (mother of Jesus)">Mary</a>), <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Safed" title="Safed">Safed</a> (two of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Holy_Cities" title="Four Holy Cities">Four Holy Cities</a> in Judaism), the <a href="/wiki/White_Mosque,_Ramla" title="White Mosque, Ramla">White Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ramla" title="Ramla">Ramla</a> (holy in Islam as the shrine of the prophet <a href="/wiki/Saleh" title="Saleh">Saleh</a>), and the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Saint_George,_Lod" title="Church of Saint George, Lod">Church of Saint George</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lod" title="Lod">Lod</a> (holy in Christianity and Islam as the tomb of <a href="/wiki/Saint_George" title="Saint George">Saint George</a> or <a href="/wiki/Al_Khidr" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Khidr">Al Khidr</a>). A number of other religious landmarks are located in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, among them <a href="/wiki/Joseph%27s_Tomb" title="Joseph's Tomb">Joseph's Tomb</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nablus" title="Nablus">Nablus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Nativity" title="Church of the Nativity">birthplace of Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rachel%27s_Tomb" title="Rachel's Tomb">Rachel's Tomb</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Cave_of_the_Patriarchs" title="Cave of the Patriarchs">Cave of the Patriarchs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Arc_(Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD)" title="Arc (Bahá'í)">administrative center</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_B%C3%A1b" title="Shrine of the Báb">Shrine of the Báb</a> are located at the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_World_Centre" title="Bahá'í World Centre">Bahá'í World Centre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a>; the leader of the faith is <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_Bah%C3%A1%27u%27ll%C3%A1h" title="Shrine of Bahá'u'lláh">buried</a> in <a href="/wiki/Acre,_Israel" title="Acre, Israel">Acre</a>. Apart from maintenance staff, there is no Bahá'í community in Israel, although it is a destination for <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_pilgrimage" title="Bahá'í pilgrimage">pilgrimages</a>. Bahá'í staff in Israel do not teach their faith to Israelis following strict policy.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[309]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[311]</a></sup> A few miles south of the Bahá'í World Centre is <a href="/wiki/Mahmood_Mosque,_Haifa" title="Mahmood Mosque, Haifa">Mahmood Mosque</a> affiliated with the reformist <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya_in_Israel" title="Ahmadiyya in Israel">Ahmadiyya</a> movement. <a href="/wiki/Kababir" title="Kababir">Kababir</a>, Haifa's mixed neighbourhood of Jews and Ahmadi Arabs is the only one of its kind in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[313]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Israel" title="Education in Israel">Education in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg/220px-Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg/330px-Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg/440px-Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="463" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University#Leslie_and_Susan_Gonda_Multidisciplinary_Brain_Research_Center" title="Bar-Ilan University">Multidisciplinary Brain Research Center</a> at <a href="/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University" title="Bar-Ilan University">Bar-Ilan University</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Education is highly valued in the Israeli culture and was viewed as a <a href="/wiki/History_of_education_in_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of education in ancient Israel and Judah">fundamental block of ancient Israelites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[314]</a></sup> Jewish communities in the Levant were the first to introduce <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> for which the organized community, not less than the parents, was responsible.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[315]</a></sup> Many international business leaders and organizations such as Microsoft founder <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">Bill Gates</a> have praised Israel for its high quality of education in helping spur Israel's economic development and technological boom.<sup id="cite_ref-David_Adler_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David_Adler-319">[316]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[318]</a></sup> In 2015, the country <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tertiary_education_attainment" title="List of countries by tertiary education attainment">ranked</a> third among <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> members (after Canada and Japan) for the percentage of 25–64 year-olds that have attained <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a> with 49% compared with the OECD average of 35%.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_education_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_education-36">[34]</a></sup> In 2012, the country ranked third in the world in the number of academic degrees per capita (20 percent of the population).<sup id="cite_ref-consulate_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-consulate-322">[319]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[320]</a></sup></p>
<p>Israel has a <a href="/wiki/School_life_expectancy" title="School life expectancy">school life expectancy</a> of 16 years and a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_literacy_rate" title="List of countries by literacy rate">literacy rate</a> of 97.8%.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> The State Education Law, passed in 1953, established five types of schools: state secular, state religious, ultra orthodox, communal settlement schools, and Arab schools. The public secular is the largest school group, and is attended by the majority of Jewish and non-Arab pupils in Israel. Most Arabs send their children to schools where Arabic is the language of instruction.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[321]</a></sup> Education is compulsory in Israel for children between the ages of three and eighteen.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[322]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[323]</a></sup> Schooling is divided into three tiers&#160;– primary school (grades 1–6), <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">middle school</a> (grades 7–9), and high school (grades 10–12)&#160;– culminating with <i><a href="/wiki/Bagrut" title="Bagrut">Bagrut</a></i> matriculation exams. Proficiency in core subjects such as mathematics, the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew language</a>, Hebrew and general literature, the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English language</a>, history, Biblical scripture and civics is necessary to receive a Bagrut certificate.<sup id="cite_ref-moia_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moia-327">[324]</a></sup> In Arab, Christian and <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> schools, the exam on Biblical studies is replaced by an exam on Muslim, Christian or Druze heritage.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[325]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Maariv_(newspaper)" title="Maariv (newspaper)">Maariv</a></i> described the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Arabs" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian Arabs">Christian Arabs</a> sectors as "the most successful in education system",<sup id="cite_ref-.D7.94.D7.9E.D7.92.D7.96.D7.A8_.D7.94.D7.A2.D7.A8.D7.91.D7.99_.D7.A0.D7.95.D7.A6.D7.A8.D7.99_.D7.94.D7.9B.D7.99_.D7.9E.D7.A6.D7.9C.D7.99.D7.97_.D7.91.D7.9E.D7.A2.D7.A8.D7.9B.D7.AA_.D7.94.D7.97.D7.99.D7.A0.D7.95.D7.9A_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.D7.94.D7.9E.D7.92.D7.96.D7.A8_.D7.94.D7.A2.D7.A8.D7.91.D7.99_.D7.A0.D7.95.D7.A6.D7.A8.D7.99_.D7.94.D7.9B.D7.99_.D7.9E.D7.A6.D7.9C.D7.99.D7.97_.D7.91.D7.9E.D7.A2.D7.A8.D7.9B.D7.AA_.D7.94.D7.97.D7.99.D7.A0.D7.95.D7.9A-329">[326]</a></sup> since Christians fared the best in terms of education in comparison to any other religion in Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-Christians_in_Israel:_Strong_in_education_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christians_in_Israel:_Strong_in_education-330">[327]</a></sup> Israeli children from Russian-speaking families have a higher bagrut pass rate at high-school level.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[328]</a></sup> Although amongst immigrant children born in the <a href="/wiki/Former_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Former Soviet Union">Former Soviet Union</a>, the bagrut pass rate is highest amongst those families from European FSU states at 62.6%, and lower amongst those from Central Asian and Caucasian FSU states.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[329]</a></sup> In 2014, 61.5% of all Israeli twelfth graders earned a matriculation certificate.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[330]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG/220px-Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG/330px-Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG/440px-Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="750" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel has <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_universities_and_colleges" title="List of Israeli universities and colleges">nine public universities that are subsidized by the state and 49 private colleges</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-moia_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moia-327">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[332]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>, Israel's second-oldest university after the <a href="/wiki/Technion" class="mw-redirect" title="Technion">Technion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[333]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[334]</a></sup> houses the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel" title="National Library of Israel">National Library of Israel</a>, the world's largest repository of Judaica and Hebraica.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[335]</a></sup> The Technion and the Hebrew University consistently ranked among world's 100 top universities by the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">ARWU</a> academic ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-ARWU_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU-339">[336]</a></sup> Other major universities in the country include the <a href="/wiki/Weizmann_Institute_of_Science" title="Weizmann Institute of Science">Weizmann Institute of Science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University" title="Tel Aviv University">Tel Aviv University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben-Gurion_University_of_the_Negev" title="Ben-Gurion University of the Negev">Ben-Gurion University of the Negev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University" title="Bar-Ilan University">Bar-Ilan University</a>, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Haifa" title="University of Haifa">University of Haifa</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Open_University_of_Israel" title="Open University of Israel">Open University of Israel</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ariel_University" title="Ariel University">Ariel University</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, is the newest university institution, upgraded from college status, and the first in over thirty years.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel" title="Politics of Israel">Politics of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_system_of_government" title="Israeli system of government">Israeli system of government</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Israeli_government" title="Criticism of the Israeli government">Criticism of the Israeli government</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg/330px-PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg/440px-PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> chamber, home to the Israeli parliament</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel operates under a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> as a democratic republic with <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> A member of parliament supported by a parliamentary majority becomes the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">prime minister</a>—usually this is the chair of the largest party. The prime minister is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and head of the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">cabinet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia2_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia2-340">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[338]</a></sup> Israel is governed by a 120-member parliament, known as the <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a>. Membership of the Knesset is based on <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Israel" title="List of political parties in Israel">political parties</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[339]</a></sup> with a 3.25% electoral threshold, which in practice has resulted in coalition governments. Parliamentary <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Israel" title="Elections in Israel">elections</a> are scheduled every four years, but unstable coalitions or a <a href="/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence" title="Motion of no confidence">no-confidence vote</a> by the Knesset can dissolve a government earlier. The <a href="/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel" title="Basic Laws of Israel">Basic Laws of Israel</a> function as an <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">uncodified constitution</a>. In 2003, the Knesset began to draft an official <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Israel" title="Constitution of Israel">constitution</a> based on these laws.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[340]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">president of Israel</a> is <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, with limited and largely ceremonial duties.<sup id="cite_ref-cia2_340-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia2-340">[337]</a></sup></p>
<p>Israel has no official religion,<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[342]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[343]</a></sup> but the definition of the state as "<a href="/wiki/Jewish_and_democratic_state" title="Jewish and democratic state">Jewish and democratic</a>" creates a strong connection with Judaism, as well as a conflict between state law and religious law. Interaction between the political parties keeps <a href="/wiki/Status_quo_(Israel)" title="Status quo (Israel)">the balance</a> between state and religion largely as it existed during the British Mandate.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[344]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Israel" title="Judiciary of Israel">Judiciary of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_law" title="Israeli law">Israeli law</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/220px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/330px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/440px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4217" data-file-height="2767" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court of Israel</a>, Givat Ram, Jerusalem</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel has a <a href="/wiki/Israeli_judicial_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Israeli judicial system">three-tier court system</a>. At the lowest level are <a href="/wiki/Magistrate" title="Magistrate">magistrate</a> courts, situated in most cities across the country. Above them are <a href="/wiki/District_court" title="District court">district courts</a>, serving as both <a href="/wiki/Appeal" title="Appeal">appellate</a> courts and <a href="/wiki/Trial_court" title="Trial court">courts of first instance</a>; they are situated in five of Israel's six <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">districts</a>. The third and highest tier is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court</a>, located in Jerusalem; it serves a dual role as the highest court of appeals and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel#High_Court_of_Justice" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Court of Israel">High Court of Justice</a>. In the latter role, the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, allowing individuals, both citizens and non-citizens, to petition against the decisions of state authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-judiciary_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-judiciary-348">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[346]</a></sup> Although Israel supports the goals of the <a href="/wiki/International_Criminal_Court" title="International Criminal Court">International Criminal Court</a>, it has not ratified the <a href="/wiki/Rome_Statute_of_the_International_Criminal_Court" title="Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court">Rome Statute</a>, citing concerns about the ability of the court to remain free from political impartiality.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[347]</a></sup></p>
<p>Israel's legal system combines three legal traditions: <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">English</a> <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Halakha" title="Halakha">Jewish law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> It is based on the principle of <i><a href="/wiki/Stare_decisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Stare decisis">stare decisis</a></i> (precedent) and is an <a href="/wiki/Adversarial_system" title="Adversarial system">adversarial system</a>, where the parties in the suit bring evidence before the court. Court cases are decided by professional judges rather than juries.<sup id="cite_ref-judiciary_348-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-judiciary-348">[345]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_Israel" title="Marriage in Israel">Marriage</a> and divorce are under the jurisdiction of the religious courts: <a href="/wiki/Beth_din" title="Beth din">Jewish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Muslim</a>, Druze, and Christian. The election of judges is carried out by a <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Selection_Committee_(Israel)" title="Judicial Selection Committee (Israel)">committee</a> of two Knesset members, three Supreme Court justices, two <a href="/wiki/Israel_Bar_Association" title="Israel Bar Association">Israeli Bar</a> members and two ministers (one of which, Israel's <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Justice (Israel)">justice minister</a>, is the committee's chairman). The committee's members of the Knesset are <a href="/wiki/Secret_ballot" title="Secret ballot">secretly elected</a> by the Knesset, and one of them is traditionally a member of the opposition, the committee's Supreme Court justices are chosen by tradition from all Supreme Court justices by seniority, the Israeli Bar members are elected by the bar, and the second minister is appointed by the Israeli cabinet. The current justice minister and committee's chairwoman is <a href="/wiki/Ayelet_Shaked" title="Ayelet Shaked">Ayelet Shaked</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[349]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[350]</a></sup> Administration of Israel's courts (both the "General" courts and the <a href="/wiki/Labor_Courts_of_Israel" title="Labor Courts of Israel">Labor Courts</a>) is carried by the Administration of Courts, situated in Jerusalem. Both General and Labor courts are paperless courts: the storage of court files, as well as court decisions, are conducted electronically. Israel's <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law:_Human_Dignity_and_Liberty" title="Basic Law: Human Dignity and Liberty">Basic Law: Human Dignity and Liberty</a> seeks to defend <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Israel" title="Human rights in Israel">human rights and liberties in Israel</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">Districts of Israel</a></div>
<div role="img" class="noresize" style="width: 220px; float: right; clear: right; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative; max-width: 100%; overflow-x: auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_location_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Israel_location_map.svg/220px-Israel_location_map.svg.png" width="220" height="409" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Israel_location_map.svg/330px-Israel_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Israel_location_map.svg/440px-Israel_location_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="614" data-file-height="1141" /></a>
<div style="position:absolute; left:0.6px; top:7.4px"><a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">Districts of Israel</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:126px; top:49.2px"><a href="/wiki/Northern_District_(Israel)" title="Northern District (Israel)">North</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:93px; top:69px"><a href="/wiki/Haifa_District" title="Haifa District">Haifa</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:73.2px; top:113px"><a href="/wiki/Central_District_(Israel)" title="Central District (Israel)">Center</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:55.6px; top:132.8px"><a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_District" title="Tel Aviv District">Tel Aviv</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:110.6px; top:121.8px"><a href="/wiki/Judea_and_Samaria_District" class="mw-redirect" title="Judea and Samaria District">Judea<br />
and<br />
Samaria</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:86.4px; top:163.6px"><a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:86.4px; top:216.4px"><a href="/wiki/Southern_District_(Israel)" title="Southern District (Israel)">South</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:2.8px; top:388px">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Israel_Labelled_Map" title="Template:Israel Labelled Map"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Israel_Labelled_Map" title="Template talk:Israel Labelled Map"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Israel_Labelled_Map&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The State of Israel is divided into six main administrative <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">districts</a>, known as <i>mehozot</i> (מחוזות; singular: <i>mahoz</i>)&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Central_District_(Israel)" title="Central District (Israel)">Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haifa_District" title="Haifa District">Haifa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northern_District_(Israel)" title="Northern District (Israel)">North</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southern_District_(Israel)" title="Southern District (Israel)">South</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_District" title="Tel Aviv District">Tel Aviv</a> districts, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Judea_and_Samaria_Area" title="Judea and Samaria Area">Judea and Samaria Area</a> in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>. All of the Judea and Samaria Area and parts of the Jerusalem and Northern districts are not recognized internationally as part of Israel. Districts are further divided into fifteen sub-districts known as <i>nafot</i> (נפות; singular: <i>nafa</i>), which are themselves partitioned into fifty natural regions.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[351]</a></sup></p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center">

<dl>
<dd><small><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_jerusalemdistrict"><b><a href="#ref_jerusalemdistrict">^a</a></b></span> Including 201,170 Jews and 313,350 Arabs in <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-jerusalem_pop_291-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jerusalem_pop-291">[288]</a></sup></small></dd>
<dd><small><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_judeaandsamaria"><b><a href="#ref_judeaandsamaria">^b</a></b></span> Israeli citizens only.</small></dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Israeli-occupied_territories">Israeli-occupied territories</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">Israeli-occupied territories</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Israel,_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg/300px-Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg.png" width="300" height="387" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg/450px-Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg/600px-Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="559" data-file-height="721" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Israel,_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Map of Israel showing the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, and the Golan Heights</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1967, as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, Israel captured and <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">occupied</a> the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, including <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>. Israel also captured the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a>, but returned it to Egypt as part of the 1979 <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_Peace_Treaty" title="Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty">Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[352]</a></sup> Between 1982 and 2000, Israel occupied part of <a href="/wiki/Southern_Lebanon" title="Southern Lebanon">southern Lebanon</a>, in what was known as the <a href="/wiki/South_Lebanon_Security_Belt" class="mw-redirect" title="South Lebanon Security Belt">Security Belt</a>. Since Israel's capture of these territories, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_settlement" title="Israeli settlement">Israeli settlements</a> and military installations have been built within each of them, except Lebanon. Israel has applied civilian law to the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights_Law" title="Golan Heights Law">Golan Heights</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">East Jerusalem</a> and granted their inhabitants permanent residency status and the ability to <a href="/wiki/Israeli_nationality_law" title="Israeli nationality law">apply for citizenship</a>. The West Bank, outside of the Israeli settlements within the territory, has remained under direct military rule, and Palestinians in this area cannot become Israeli citizens. Israel withdrew its military forces and dismantled the Israeli settlements in the Gaza Strip as part of its <a href="/wiki/Israeli_disengagement_from_Gaza" title="Israeli disengagement from Gaza">disengagement from Gaza</a> though it continues to maintain <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Blockade of the Gaza Strip">control</a> of its airspace and waters.</p>
<p>The UN Security Council has declared the annexation of the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem to be "null and void" and continues to view the territories as occupied.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[353]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[354]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a>, principal judicial organ of the United Nations, asserted, in its <a href="/wiki/International_law_and_the_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict#Ruling_of_the_ICJ" title="International law and the Arab–Israeli conflict">2004 advisory opinion</a> on the legality of the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a>, that the lands captured by Israel in the Six-Day War, including East Jerusalem, are occupied territory.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[355]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">status</a> of East Jerusalem in any future peace settlement has at times been a difficult issue in <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_peace_process" title="Israeli–Palestinian peace process">negotiations</a> between Israeli governments and representatives of the Palestinians, as Israel views it as its sovereign territory, as well as part of its capital. Most negotiations relating to the territories have been on the basis of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_242" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 242">United Nations Security Council Resolution 242</a>, which emphasises "the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war", and calls on Israel to withdraw from occupied territories in return for normalization of relations with Arab states, a principle known as "<a href="/wiki/Land_for_peace" title="Land for peace">Land for peace</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[356]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[357]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[358]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg/220px-Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg" width="220" height="103" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg/330px-Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg/440px-Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2826" data-file-height="1327" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Raffaespo_-_2938624838.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a> separating Israel and the West Bank</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The West Bank <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_occupation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian occupation of the West Bank">was occupied and annexed</a> by Jordan in 1950, following the Arab rejection of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">UN decision</a> to create two states in Palestine. Only Britain recognized this annexation and Jordan has since <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_disengagement_from_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian disengagement from the West Bank">ceded</a> its claim to the territory to the <a href="/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization" title="Palestine Liberation Organization">PLO</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Palestinian_territories" title="Demographics of the Palestinian territories">population</a> are mainly <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_refugee" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian refugee">refugees</a> of the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[359]</a></sup> From their occupation in 1967 until 1993, the Palestinians living in these territories were under <a href="/wiki/Coordinator_of_Government_Activities_in_the_Territories" title="Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories">Israeli military administration</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Palestine_Liberation_Organization_letters_of_recognition" title="Israel–Palestine Liberation Organization letters of recognition">Israel–PLO letters of recognition</a>, most of the Palestinian population and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_administered_by_the_State_of_Palestine" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities administered by the State of Palestine">cities</a> have been under the internal jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian Authority</a>, and only partial Israeli military control, although Israel has on several occasions redeployed its <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">troops</a> and reinstated full military administration during periods of unrest. In response to increasing attacks during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Intifada" title="Second Intifada">Second Intifada</a>, the Israeli government started to construct the Israeli West Bank barrier.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[360]</a></sup> When completed, approximately 13% of the barrier will be constructed on the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a> or in Israel with 87% inside the West Bank.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[361]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[362]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Gaza Strip was <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Gaza_Strip_by_Egypt" title="Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt">occupied by Egypt</a> from 1948 to 1967 and then by Israel after 1967. In 2005, as part of <a href="/wiki/Israel%27s_unilateral_disengagement_plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel's unilateral disengagement plan">Israel's unilateral disengagement plan</a>, Israel removed all of its settlers and forces from the territory. Israel does not consider the Gaza Strip to be occupied territory and declared it a "foreign territory". That view has been disputed by numerous international humanitarian organizations and various bodies of the United Nations.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[363]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[364]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[366]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[367]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gaza_(2007)" title="Battle of Gaza (2007)">2007 Battle of Gaza</a>, when <a href="/wiki/Governance_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Governance of the Gaza Strip">Hamas assumed power in the Gaza Strip</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-gaza_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gaza-371">[368]</a></sup> Israel tightened its control of the Gaza crossings along <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Gaza_barrier" title="Israel–Gaza barrier">its border</a>, as well as by sea and air, and prevented persons from entering and exiting the area except for isolated cases it deemed humanitarian.<sup id="cite_ref-gaza_371-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gaza-371">[368]</a></sup> Gaza has a <a href="/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Egypt_border" title="Gaza–Egypt border">border with Egypt</a> and an agreement between Israel, the European Union and the PA governed how border crossing would take place (it was monitored by European observers).<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[369]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Israel" title="Foreign relations of Israel">Foreign relations of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/International_recognition_of_Israel" title="International recognition of Israel">International recognition of Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG/300px-Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG" width="300" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG/450px-Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG/600px-Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="628" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Foreign_relations_of_Israel_Map_July_2011.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #0000ff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Diplomatic relations</div>
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #80ffff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Diplomatic relations suspended</div>
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #00ff00; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Former diplomatic relations</div>
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ff00ff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;No diplomatic relations, but former trade relations</div>
<div class="legend"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ff8040; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;No diplomatic relations</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel maintains diplomatic relations with 158 countries and has 107 <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Israel" title="List of diplomatic missions of Israel">diplomatic missions</a> around the world;<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[370]</a></sup> countries with whom they have no diplomatic relations include most Muslim countries.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[371]</a></sup> Only three members of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> have normalized relations with Israel: <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Egypt–Israel relations">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_relations" title="Israel–Jordan relations">Jordan</a> signed peace treaties in <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Egypt_Peace_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel–Egypt Peace Treaty">1979</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_Treaty_of_Peace" class="mw-redirect" title="Israel–Jordan Treaty of Peace">1994</a>, respectively, and Mauritania opted for full diplomatic relations with Israel in 1999. Despite the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, Israel is still widely considered an enemy country among Egyptians.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[372]</a></sup> Under Israeli law, Lebanon, Syria, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Iran, Sudan, and Yemen are enemy countries,<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[373]</a></sup> and Israeli citizens may not visit them without permission from the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Interior (Israel)">Ministry of the Interior</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[374]</a></sup> Iran <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Iran–Israel relations">had diplomatic relations</a> with Israel under the <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty" title="Pahlavi dynasty">Pahlavi dynasty</a><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[375]</a></sup> but withdrew its recognition of Israel during the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic Revolution">Islamic Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[376]</a></sup> As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_War_(2008%E2%80%9309)" title="Gaza War (2008–09)">2008–09 Gaza War</a>, Mauritania, Qatar, Bolivia, and Venezuela suspended political and economic ties with Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-al-jaz-eng_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-al-jaz-eng-380">[377]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[378]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Israel–United States relations">United States</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="Israel–Russia relations">Soviet Union</a> were the first two countries to recognize the State of Israel, having declared recognition roughly simultaneously.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[379]</a></sup> The United States regards Israel as its "most reliable partner in the Middle East,"<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[380]</a></sup> based on "common democratic values, religious affinities, and security interests".<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[381]</a></sup> The United States has provided $68&#160;billion in <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_military_relations" title="Israel–United States military relations">military assistance</a> and $32&#160;billion in grants to Israel since 1967, under the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Assistance_Act" title="Foreign Assistance Act">Foreign Assistance Act</a> (period beginning 1962),<sup id="cite_ref-PNADR900_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNADR900-385">[382]</a></sup> more than any other country for that period until 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-PNADR900_385-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PNADR900-385">[382]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[384]</a></sup> The United Kingdom is seen as having a "natural" <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="Israel–United Kingdom relations">relationship</a> with Israel on account of the <a href="/wiki/British_Mandate_for_Palestine_(legal_instrument)" title="British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)">British Mandate for Palestine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[385]</a></sup> Relations between the two countries were also made stronger by former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a>'s efforts for a two state resolution. By 2007<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Germany–Israel relations">Germany</a> had paid 25&#160;billion euros in <a href="/wiki/Reparations_Agreement_between_Israel_and_West_Germany" title="Reparations Agreement between Israel and West Germany">reparations</a> to the Israeli state and individual Israeli Holocaust survivors.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[386]</a></sup> Israel is included in the European Union's <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_Policy" title="European Neighbourhood Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a> (ENP), which aims at bringing the EU and its neighbours closer.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[387]</a></sup></p>
<p>Although Turkey and Israel did not establish full diplomatic relations until 1991,<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[388]</a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Israel–Turkey relations">cooperated</a> with the Jewish state since its recognition of Israel in 1949. Turkey's ties to the other Muslim-majority nations in the region have at times resulted in pressure from Arab and Muslim states to temper its relationship with Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[389]</a></sup> Relations between Turkey and Israel took a downturn after the 2008–09 Gaza War and Israel's <a href="/wiki/Gaza_flotilla_raid" title="Gaza flotilla raid">raid of the Gaza flotilla</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[390]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greece%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Greece–Israel relations">Relations between Greece and Israel</a> have improved since 1995 due to the decline of Israeli-Turkish relations.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[391]</a></sup> The two countries have a defense cooperation agreement and in 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force" title="Israeli Air Force">Israeli Air Force</a> hosted Greece's <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Air_Force" title="Hellenic Air Force">Hellenic Air Force</a> in a joint exercise at the <a href="/wiki/Ovda_Airport" title="Ovda Airport">Uvda base</a>. The joint Cyprus-Israel oil and gas explorations centered on the <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_gas_field" title="Leviathan gas field">Leviathan gas field</a> are an important factor for Greece, given its strong links with Cyprus.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[392]</a></sup> Cooperation in the world's longest sub-sea electric power cable, the <a href="/wiki/EuroAsia_Interconnector" title="EuroAsia Interconnector">EuroAsia Interconnector</a>, has strengthened <a href="/wiki/Cyprus%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Cyprus–Israel relations">relations between Cyprus and Israel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[393]</a></sup></p>
<p>Azerbaijan is one of the few majority Muslim countries to develop bilateral strategic and economic <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Azerbaijan–Israel relations">relations</a> with Israel. Azerbaijan supplies Israel with a substantial amount of its oil needs, and Israel has helped modernize the Armed Forces of Azerbaijan. India established full <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="India–Israel relations">diplomatic ties</a> with Israel in 1992 and has fostered a strong military, technological and cultural partnership with the country since then.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[394]</a></sup> According to an international opinion survey conducted in 2009 on behalf of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)">Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>, India is the most pro-Israel country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[395]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[396]</a></sup> India is the largest customer of the <a href="/wiki/Military_equipment_of_Israel" title="Military equipment of Israel">Israeli military equipment</a> and Israel is the second-largest military partner of India after Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[397]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Ethiopia–Israel relations">Ethiopia</a> is Israel's main ally in Africa due to common political, religious and security interests.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[398]</a></sup> Israel provides expertise to Ethiopia on irrigation projects and thousands of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews_in_Israel" title="Ethiopian Jews in Israel">Ethiopian Jews live in Israel</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_humanitarian_efforts">International humanitarian efforts</span></h3>
<p>Israeli foreign aid <a href="/wiki/List_of_development_aid_country_donors" title="List of development aid country donors">ranks</a> low among <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> nations, spending less than 0.1% of its <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">GNI</a> on development assistance, as opposed to the recommended 0.7%. The country also ranked 43rd in the 2016 <a href="/wiki/World_Giving_Index" title="World Giving Index">World Giving Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[399]</a></sup> However, Israel has a history of providing emergency aid and humanitarian response teams to disasters across the world.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[400]</a></sup> Israel's humanitarian efforts officially began in 1957, with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Mashav" title="Mashav">Mashav</a>, the Israel's Agency for International Development Cooperation.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[401]</a></sup> There are additional Israeli humanitarian and emergency response groups that work with the Israel government, including <a href="/wiki/IsraAid" title="IsraAid">IsraAid</a>, a joint programme run by 14 Israeli organizations and North American Jewish groups,<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[402]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/ZAKA" title="ZAKA">ZAKA</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[403]</a></sup> The Fast Israeli Rescue and Search Team (FIRST),<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[404]</a></sup> Israeli Flying Aid (IFA),<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[405]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Save_a_Child%27s_Heart" title="Save a Child's Heart">Save a Child's Heart</a> (SACH)<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[406]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Latet" title="Latet">Latet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[407]</a></sup></p>
<p>Between 1985 and 2015, Israel sent 24 delegations of IDF search and rescue unit, the <a href="/wiki/Home_Front_Command" title="Home Front Command">Home Front Command</a>, to 22 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[408]</a></sup> In Haiti, immediately following the <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">2010 earthquake</a>, Israel was the first country to set up a field hospital capable of performing surgical operations.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[409]</a></sup> Israel sent over 200 medical doctors and personnel to start treating injured Haitians at the scene.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[410]</a></sup> At the conclusion of its humanitarian mission 11 days later,<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[411]</a></sup> the Israeli delegation had treated more than 1,110 patients, conducted 319 successful surgeries, delivered 16 births and rescued or assisted in the rescue of four individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[412]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[413]</a></sup> Despite radiation concerns, Israel was one of the first countries to send a medical delegation to Japan following the <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami">2011 earthquake and tsunami</a> disaster.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[414]</a></sup> Israel dispatched a medical team to the <a href="/wiki/April_2011_Miyagi_earthquake" title="April 2011 Miyagi earthquake">tsunami-stricken</a> city of <a href="/wiki/Kurihara" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurihara">Kurihara</a> in 2011. A medical clinic run by an IDF team of some 50 members featured pediatric, surgical, maternity and gynecological, and otolaryngology wards, together with an optometry department, a laboratory, a pharmacy and an intensive care unit. After treating 200 patients in two weeks, the departing emergency team donated its equipment to the Japanese.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[415]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_security_forces" title="Israeli security forces">Israeli security forces</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Israel" title="List of wars involving Israel">List of wars involving Israel</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_Israel_Defense_Forces_operations" title="List of the Israel Defense Forces operations">List of the Israel Defense Forces operations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Israel_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Israel and weapons of mass destruction">Israel and weapons of mass destruction</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> is the sole military wing of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_security_forces" title="Israeli security forces">Israeli security forces</a>, and is headed by its <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_General_Staff_(Israel)" title="Chief of General Staff (Israel)">Chief of General Staff</a>, the <i>Ramatkal</i>, subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">Cabinet</a>. The IDF consist of the <a href="/wiki/GOC_Army_Headquarters" title="GOC Army Headquarters">army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force" title="Israeli Air Force">air force</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Navy" title="Israeli Navy">navy</a>. It was founded during the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a> by consolidating paramilitary organizations—chiefly the <a href="/wiki/Haganah" title="Haganah">Haganah</a>—that preceded the establishment of the state.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[416]</a></sup> The IDF also draws upon the resources of the <a href="/wiki/Military_Intelligence_Directorate_(Israel)" title="Military Intelligence Directorate (Israel)">Military Intelligence Directorate</a> (<i>Aman</i>), which works with <a href="/wiki/Mossad" title="Mossad">Mossad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shin_Bet" title="Shin Bet">Shabak</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[417]</a></sup> The Israel Defense Forces have been involved in several <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Israel" title="List of wars involving Israel">major wars</a> and border conflicts in its short history, making it one of the most battle-trained armed forces in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[418]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[419]</a></sup></p>
<p>Most Israelis are <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Israel" title="Conscription in Israel">drafted into the military</a> at the age of 18. Men serve two years and eight months and <a href="/wiki/Women_in_the_Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Women in the Israel Defense Forces">women</a> two years.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[420]</a></sup> Following mandatory service, Israeli men join the reserve forces and usually do up to several weeks of <a href="/wiki/Reserve_duty_(Israel)" title="Reserve duty (Israel)">reserve duty</a> every year until their forties. Most women are exempt from reserve duty. <a href="/wiki/Arab_citizens_of_Israel" title="Arab citizens of Israel">Arab citizens of Israel</a> (except the <a href="/wiki/Druze_in_Israel" title="Druze in Israel">Druze</a>) and those engaged in full-time religious studies are <a href="/wiki/Exemption_from_military_service_in_Israel" title="Exemption from military service in Israel">exempt from military service</a>, although the <a href="/wiki/Tal_committee" title="Tal committee">exemption of yeshiva students</a> has been a source of contention in Israeli society for many years.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[421]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[422]</a></sup> An alternative for those who receive exemptions on various grounds is <i><a href="/wiki/Sherut_Leumi" title="Sherut Leumi">Sherut Leumi</a></i>, or national service, which involves a program of service in hospitals, schools and other social welfare frameworks.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[423]</a></sup> As a result of its conscription program, the IDF maintains approximately 176,500 active troops and an additional 445,000 reservists.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[424]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg/330px-Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg/440px-Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="533" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Israel_Defense_Forces_-_Iron_Dome_Intercepts_Rockets_from_the_Gaza_Strip.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Iron_Dome" title="Iron Dome">Iron Dome</a> is the world's first operational anti-<a href="/wiki/Rocket_artillery" title="Rocket artillery">artillery rocket</a> defense system.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The nation's military relies heavily on high-tech <a href="/wiki/Military_equipment_of_Israel" title="Military equipment of Israel">weapons</a> systems <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Israel" title="Defense industry of Israel">designed and manufactured in Israel</a> as well as some foreign imports. The <a href="/wiki/Arrow_(Israeli_missile)" title="Arrow (Israeli missile)">Arrow</a> missile is one of the world's few operational <a href="/wiki/Anti-ballistic_missile" title="Anti-ballistic missile">anti-ballistic missile</a> systems.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[425]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Python_(missile)" title="Python (missile)">Python</a> air-to-air missile series is often considered one of the most crucial weapons in its military history.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[426]</a></sup> Israel's <a href="/wiki/Spike_(missile)" title="Spike (missile)">Spike</a> missile is one of the most widely exported <a href="/wiki/Anti-tank_missile" title="Anti-tank missile">ATGMs</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[427]</a></sup> Israel's <a href="/wiki/Iron_Dome" title="Iron Dome">Iron Dome</a> anti-missile air defense system gained worldwide acclaim after intercepting hundreds of <a href="/wiki/Qassam_rocket" title="Qassam rocket">Qassam</a>, <a href="/wiki/BM-21_Grad" title="BM-21 Grad">122 mm Grad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fajr-5" title="Fajr-5">Fajr-5</a> artillery <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel" title="Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel">rockets fire by Palestinian militants</a> from the Gaza Strip.<sup id="cite_ref-Johnson_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson-431">[428]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Tory_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tory-432">[429]</a></sup> Since the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a>, Israel has developed a network of <a href="/wiki/Reconnaissance_satellites" class="mw-redirect" title="Reconnaissance satellites">reconnaissance satellites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[430]</a></sup> The success of the <i><a href="/wiki/Ofeq" title="Ofeq">Ofeq</a></i> program has made Israel <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">one of seven countries</a> capable of launching such satellites.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[431]</a></sup></p>
