<p>Israel is widely believed to <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Israel" title="Nuclear weapons and Israel">possess nuclear weapons</a><sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[432]</a></sup> as well as chemical and biological <a href="/wiki/Israel_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Israel and weapons of mass destruction">weapons of mass destruction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[433]</a></sup> Israel has not signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons</a><sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[434]</a></sup> and maintains a <a href="/wiki/Policy_of_deliberate_ambiguity" title="Policy of deliberate ambiguity">policy of deliberate ambiguity</a> toward its nuclear capabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[435]</a></sup> The Israeli Navy's <a href="/wiki/Dolphin-class_submarine" title="Dolphin-class submarine">Dolphin submarines</a> are believed to be armed with nuclear <a href="/wiki/Popeye_(missile)#Popeye_Turbo_Submarine_Launched_Cruise_Missile" title="Popeye (missile)">Popeye Turbo missiles</a>, offering <a href="/wiki/Second_strike" title="Second strike">second-strike</a> capability.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[436]</a></sup> Since the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> in 1991, when Israel was attacked by <a href="/wiki/Al_Hussein_(missile)" title="Al Hussein (missile)">Iraqi Scud missiles</a>, all homes in Israel are required to have a reinforced security room, <a href="/wiki/Merkhav_Mugan" title="Merkhav Mugan">Merkhav Mugan</a>, impermeable to chemical and biological substances.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[437]</a></sup></p>
<p>As of 2015, Israel has the 15th <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">largest military expenditure</a> in the world<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[438]</a></sup> and the 7th highest as a percentage of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[439]</a></sup> The country also ranked 8th globally for <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">arms exports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[440]</a></sup> The majority of Israel's arms exports are unreported for security reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[441]</a></sup> Since 1967, the United States has been a particularly notable foreign contributor of <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_military_relations#Military_aid" title="Israel–United States military relations">military aid to Israel</a>: the US is expected to provide the country with $3.15&#160;billion per year from 2013 to 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[442]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nyt_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-446">[443]</a></sup> Israel is consistently rated low in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>, ranking 144th out of 163 nations for peacefulness in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[444]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Israel" title="Economy of Israel">Economy of Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Money_IL_WV.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Money_IL_WV.JPG/220px-Money_IL_WV.JPG" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Money_IL_WV.JPG/330px-Money_IL_WV.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Money_IL_WV.JPG/440px-Money_IL_WV.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="750" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Money_IL_WV.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Israeli_new_shekel" title="Israeli new shekel">Israeli new shekel</a> banknotes and coins (currently being replaced)</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel is considered the most advanced country in <a href="/wiki/Southwest_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Southwest Asia">Southwest Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> in economic and industrial development.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[445]</a></sup> Israel's quality <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Israel" class="mw-redirect" title="List of universities and colleges in Israel">university education</a> and the establishment of a highly motivated and educated populace is largely responsible for spurring the country's high technology boom and rapid economic development.<sup id="cite_ref-David_Adler_319-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-David_Adler-319">[316]</a></sup> In 2010, it joined the <a href="/wiki/OECD" class="mw-redirect" title="OECD">OECD</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-35">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[446]</a></sup> The country is ranked 24th in the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">Global Competitiveness Report</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[447]</a></sup> and 52nd on the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Ease_of_doing_business_index" title="Ease of doing business index"><i>Doing Business</i> index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[448]</a></sup> It has the second-largest number of <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup companies</a> in the world after the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[449]</a></sup> and the third-largest number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_companies_quoted_on_the_Nasdaq" title="List of Israeli companies quoted on the Nasdaq">NASDAQ-listed companies</a> after the U.S. and China.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[450]</a></sup> In 2016, Israel ranked 21st among the world's most competitive nations, according to the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_for_Management_Development" title="International Institute for Management Development">IMD</a>'s <a href="/wiki/World_Competitiveness_Yearbook" title="World Competitiveness Yearbook">World Competitiveness Yearbook</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[451]</a></sup> Israel was also ranked 4th in the world by share of people in high-skilled employment.<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[452]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BursaTelAviv-1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/BursaTelAviv-1.jpg/170px-BursaTelAviv-1.jpg" width="170" height="307" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/BursaTelAviv-1.jpg/255px-BursaTelAviv-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/BursaTelAviv-1.jpg/340px-BursaTelAviv-1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1660" data-file-height="3000" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BursaTelAviv-1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange" title="Tel Aviv Stock Exchange">Tel Aviv Stock Exchange</a>. Its building is optimized for computer trading, with systems located in an underground bunker to keep the exchange active during emergencies.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[453]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Despite limited natural resources, intensive development of the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Israel" title="Agriculture in Israel">agricultural</a> and industrial sectors over the past decades has made Israel largely self-sufficient in food production, apart from grains and beef. Imports to Israel, totaling $57.9&#160;billion in 2016, include raw materials, military equipment, investment goods, rough diamonds, fuels, grain, and consumer goods.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> Leading exports include machinery and equipment, software, <a href="/wiki/Diamond_industry_in_Israel" title="Diamond industry in Israel">cut diamonds</a>, agricultural products, chemicals, and textiles and apparel; in 2016, Israeli exports reached $51.61&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Israel" title="Bank of Israel">Bank of Israel</a> holds $97.22 billion of <a href="/wiki/Foreign-exchange_reserves" title="Foreign-exchange reserves">foreign-exchange reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_2-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-2">[2]</a></sup> Since the 1970s, Israel has received <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_military_relations" title="Israel–United States military relations">military aid</a> from the United States, as well as economic assistance in the form of loan guarantees, which now account for roughly half of Israel's <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">external debt</a>. Israel has <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_external_debt" title="List of countries by external debt">one of the lowest</a> external debts in the developed world, and is a lender in terms of net external debt (<a href="/wiki/Net_international_investment_position" title="Net international investment position">assets vs. liabilities abroad</a>), which in 2015<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> stood at a surplus of $69&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[454]</a></sup> Israel has an impressive record for creating profit driven technologies making the country a top choice for many business leaders and high technology industry giants. <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a><sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[455]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a><sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[456]</a></sup> built their first overseas <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> facilities in Israel, and other high-tech multi-national corporations, such as <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hewlett-Packard" title="Hewlett-Packard">HP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cisco_Systems" title="Cisco Systems">Cisco Systems</a>, <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a> and <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a> have opened <a href="/wiki/List_of_multinational_companies_with_research_and_development_centres_in_Israel" title="List of multinational companies with research and development centres in Israel">R&amp;D centres in the country</a>. In 2007, American investor <a href="/wiki/Warren_Buffett" title="Warren Buffett">Warren Buffett</a>'s holding company <a href="/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway" title="Berkshire Hathaway">Berkshire Hathaway</a> bought an Israeli company, <a href="/wiki/Iscar" class="mw-redirect" title="Iscar">Iscar</a>, its first <a href="/wiki/List_of_assets_owned_by_Berkshire_Hathaway" title="List of assets owned by Berkshire Hathaway">acquisition</a> outside the United States, for $4&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[457]</a></sup></p>
<p>Days of working time in Israel are Sunday through Thursday (for a five-day <a href="/wiki/Workweek" class="mw-redirect" title="Workweek">workweek</a>), or Friday (for a six-day workweek). In observance of <i><a href="/wiki/Shabbat" title="Shabbat">Shabbat</a></i>, in places where Friday is a work day and the majority of population is Jewish, Friday is a "short day", usually lasting till 14:00 in the winter, or 16:00 in the summer. Several proposals have been raised to adjust the work week with the majority of the world, and make Sunday a non-working day, while extending working time of other days or replacing Friday with Sunday as a work day.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[458]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Israel" title="Science and technology in Israel">Science and technology in Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Israeli inventions and discoveries">List of Israeli inventions and discoveries</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dan_Shechtman.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dan_Shechtman.jpg/170px-Dan_Shechtman.jpg" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dan_Shechtman.jpg/255px-Dan_Shechtman.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Dan_Shechtman.jpg/340px-Dan_Shechtman.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="933" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Dan_Shechtman.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Materials_science" title="Materials science">Materials science</a> professor <a href="/wiki/Dan_Shechtman" title="Dan Shechtman">Dan Shechtman</a> is one of six <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Israeli Nobel laureates">Israelis to win</a> the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> in under a decade.<sup id="cite_ref-nobel_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nobel-462">[459]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel's development of cutting-edge technologies in software, communications and the life sciences have <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Wadi" title="Silicon Wadi">evoked comparisons</a> with <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[460]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[461]</a></sup> Israel ranks 10th in the <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Innovation_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Bloomberg Innovation Index">Bloomberg Innovation Index</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[462]</a></sup> and is 2nd in the world in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of countries by research and development spending">expenditure on research and development</a> as a percentage of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[463]</a></sup> Israel boasts 140 scientists, technicians, and engineers per 10,000 employees, the highest number in the world (in comparison, the same is 85 for the U.S.).<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[464]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[465]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[466]</a></sup> Israel has produced six <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Israeli Nobel laureates">Nobel Prize-winning</a> scientists since 2004<sup id="cite_ref-nobel_462-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nobel-462">[459]</a></sup> and has been frequently ranked as one of the countries with the highest ratios of <a href="/wiki/Scientific_papers" class="mw-redirect" title="Scientific papers">scientific papers</a> per capita in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[467]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[469]</a></sup> Israel has led the world in <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">stem-cell</a> research papers per capita since 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-scell_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scell-473">[470]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_universities_and_colleges" title="List of Israeli universities and colleges">Israeli universities</a> are ranked among the top 50 world universities in computer science (<a href="/wiki/Technion" class="mw-redirect" title="Technion">Technion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University" title="Tel Aviv University">Tel Aviv University</a>), mathematics (<a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>) and chemistry (<a href="/wiki/Weizmann_Institute_of_Science" title="Weizmann Institute of Science">Weizmann Institute of Science</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-ARWU_339-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU-339">[336]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2012 Israel was ranked ninth in the world by the Futron's <a href="/wiki/Space_Competitiveness_Index" title="Space Competitiveness Index">Space Competitiveness Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[471]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Space_Agency" title="Israel Space Agency">Israel Space Agency</a> coordinates all Israeli space research programs with scientific and commercial goals, and have indigenously designed and built at least 13 commercial, research and spy satellites.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[472]</a></sup> Some of Israel's satellites are ranked among the world's most advanced space systems.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[473]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shavit" title="Shavit">Shavit</a> is a space <a href="/wiki/Launch_vehicle" title="Launch vehicle">launch vehicle</a> produced by Israel to launch small <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellites</a> into <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[474]</a></sup> It was first launched in 1988, making Israel the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">eighth nation</a> to have a space launch capability. In 2003, <a href="/wiki/Ilan_Ramon" title="Ilan Ramon">Ilan Ramon</a> became Israel's first astronaut, serving as payload specialist of <a href="/wiki/STS-107" title="STS-107">STS-107</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Columbia_disaster" title="Space Shuttle Columbia disaster">fatal mission</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Columbia" title="Space Shuttle Columbia">Space Shuttle <i>Columbia</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[475]</a></sup></p>
<p>The ongoing shortage of <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Israel" title="Water supply and sanitation in Israel">water in the country</a> has spurred innovation in <a href="/wiki/Water_conservation" title="Water conservation">water conservation</a> techniques, and a substantial <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_research_in_Israel" title="Agricultural research in Israel">agricultural modernization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drip_irrigation" title="Drip irrigation">drip irrigation</a>, was <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Israeli inventions and discoveries">invented in Israel</a>. Israel is also at the technological forefront of <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalination</a> and <a href="/wiki/Water_recycling" class="mw-redirect" title="Water recycling">water recycling</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Sorek_desalination_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Sorek desalination plant">Sorek desalination plant</a> is the largest seawater <a href="/wiki/Reverse_osmosis" title="Reverse osmosis">reverse osmosis</a> (SWRO) <a href="/wiki/Desalination_facilities" title="Desalination facilities">desalination facility</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[476]</a></sup> By 2014, Israel's desalination programs provided roughly 35% of Israel's drinking water and it is expected to supply 40% by 2015 and 70% by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[477]</a></sup> As of 2015, more than 50 percent of the water for Israeli households, agriculture and industry is artificially produced.<sup id="cite_ref-Kershner_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kershner-481">[478]</a></sup> The country hosts an annual Water Technology and Environmental Control Exhibition &amp; Conference (WATEC) that attracts thousands of people from across the world.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-483" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-483">[480]</a></sup> In 2011, Israel's <a href="/wiki/Water_industry" title="Water industry">water technology industry</a> was worth around $2 billion a year with annual exports of products and services in the tens of millions of dollars. As a result of innovations in reverse osmosis technology, Israel is set to become a net <a href="/wiki/Water_export" title="Water export">exporter of water</a> in the coming years.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[481]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A horizontal parabolic dish, with a triangular structure on its top." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg/220px-Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg/330px-Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg/440px-Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3340" data-file-height="2504" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The world's largest solar parabolic dish at the <a href="/wiki/Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center" title="Ben-Gurion National Solar Energy Center">Ben-Gurion National Solar Energy Center</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Register_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Register-485">[482]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel has embraced <a href="/wiki/Solar_power_in_Israel" title="Solar power in Israel">solar energy</a>; its engineers are on the cutting edge of solar energy technology<sup id="cite_ref-NPR_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-486">[483]</a></sup> and its solar companies work on projects around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-CBC_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBC-487">[484]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BW_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BW-488">[485]</a></sup> Over 90% of Israeli homes use solar energy for hot water, the highest per capita in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Solar_energy_268-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_energy-268">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Environment_California_SWH_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Environment_California_SWH-489">[486]</a></sup> According to government figures, the country saves 8% of its electricity consumption per year because of its solar energy use in heating.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[487]</a></sup> The high annual incident <a href="/wiki/Irradiance" title="Irradiance">solar irradiance</a> at its geographic <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitude</a> creates ideal conditions for what is an internationally renowned solar research and development industry in the <a href="/wiki/Negev_Desert" class="mw-redirect" title="Negev Desert">Negev Desert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NPR_486-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-486">[483]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CBC_487-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBC-487">[484]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BW_488-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BW-488">[485]</a></sup> Israel had a modern <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_network" title="Electric vehicle network">electric car infrastructure</a> involving a countrywide network of <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">charging stations</a> to facilitate the charging and exchange of car batteries. It was thought that this would have lowered Israel's oil dependency and lowered the fuel costs of hundreds of Israel's motorists that use cars powered only by electric batteries.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[488]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[489]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">[490]</a></sup> The Israeli model was being studied by several countries and being implemented in Denmark and Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494">[491]</a></sup> However, Israel's trailblazing electric car company <a href="/wiki/Better_Place" title="Better Place">Better Place</a> shut down in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-495" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-495">[492]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Israel" title="Transport in Israel">Transport in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg/220px-Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg/330px-Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg/440px-Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1500" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ben_Gurion_Airport_terminal_3_reception_hall.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Reception hall at <a href="/wiki/Ben_Gurion_Airport" title="Ben Gurion Airport">Ben Gurion Airport</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Israel has 19,224 kilometres (11,945&#160;mi) of paved <a href="/wiki/Roads_in_Israel" title="Roads in Israel">roads</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-496" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-496">[493]</a></sup> and 3&#160;million motor vehicles.<sup id="cite_ref-vehicles_497-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vehicles-497">[494]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_vehicles_per_capita" title="List of countries by vehicles per capita">number of motor vehicles per 1,000 persons</a> is 365, relatively low with respect to developed countries.<sup id="cite_ref-vehicles_497-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vehicles-497">[494]</a></sup> Israel has 5,715 buses on scheduled routes,<sup id="cite_ref-498" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-498">[495]</a></sup> operated by several carriers, the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Egged_(company)" title="Egged (company)">Egged</a>, serving most of the country. <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Israel" title="Rail transport in Israel">Railways</a> stretch across 1,277 kilometres (793&#160;mi) and are operated solely by government-owned <a href="/wiki/Israel_Railways" title="Israel Railways">Israel Railways</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cbs_rails_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbs_rails-499">[496]</a></sup> Following major investments beginning in the early to mid-1990s, the number of train passengers per year has grown from 2.5&#160;million in 1990, to 53&#160;million in 2015; railways are also transporting 7.5&#160;million tons of cargo, per year.<sup id="cite_ref-cbs_rails_499-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbs_rails-499">[496]</a></sup></p>
<p>Israel is served by two international <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Israel" title="List of airports in Israel">airports</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben_Gurion_Airport" title="Ben Gurion Airport">Ben Gurion Airport</a>, the country's main hub for international air travel near Tel Aviv, and <a href="/wiki/Ovda_Airport" title="Ovda Airport">Ovda Airport</a>, which serves the southernmost port city of Eilat. There are several small domestic airports as well.<sup id="cite_ref-Transportation_in_Israel_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Transportation_in_Israel-500">[497]</a></sup> Ben Gurion, Israel's largest airport, handled over 15&#160;million passengers in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-501" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-501">[498]</a></sup> On the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> coast, the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Haifa" title="Port of Haifa">Port of Haifa</a> is the country's oldest and largest port, while <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Ashdod" title="Port of Ashdod">Ashdod Port</a> is one of the few deep water ports in the world built on the open sea.<sup id="cite_ref-Transportation_in_Israel_500-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Transportation_in_Israel-500">[497]</a></sup> In addition to these, the smaller <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Eilat" title="Port of Eilat">Port of Eilat</a> is situated on the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>, and is used mainly for trading with Far East countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Transportation_in_Israel_500-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Transportation_in_Israel-500">[497]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Israel" title="Tourism in Israel">Tourism in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg/220px-Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg/330px-Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg/440px-Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5288" data-file-height="3552" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Ein_Bokek" title="Ein Bokek">Ein Bokek</a> resort on the shore of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea">Dead Sea</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Tourism, especially <a href="/wiki/Religious_tourism" title="Religious tourism">religious tourism</a>, is an important industry in Israel, with the country's temperate climate, <a href="/wiki/List_of_beaches_in_Israel" title="List of beaches in Israel">beaches</a>, <a href="/wiki/Archaeology_of_Israel" title="Archaeology of Israel">archaeological</a>, other <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Israel" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Israel">historical</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_biblical_places" title="List of biblical places">biblical</a> sites, and unique geography also drawing tourists. Israel's security problems have taken their toll on the industry, but the number of incoming tourists is on the rebound.<sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">[499]</a></sup> In 2013, a record of 3.54 million tourists visited Israel with the most popular site of attraction being the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a> with 68% of tourists visiting there.<sup id="cite_ref-503" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-503">[500]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-504" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-504">[501]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Israel" title="Energy in Israel">Energy in Israel</a></div>
<p>In 2009, a natural gas reserve, <a href="/wiki/Tamar_gas_field" title="Tamar gas field">Tamar</a> was found near the coast of Israel. A second reserve, <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_gas_field" title="Leviathan gas field">Leviathan</a>, was discovered in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">[502]</a></sup> In 2015, Israel located massive oil reserves in the occupied <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">[503]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">[504]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-508" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-508">[505]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Israel" title="Culture of Israel">Culture of Israel</a></div>
<p>Israel's diverse culture stems from the diversity of its population: Jews from diaspora communities around the world have brought their cultural and religious traditions back with them, creating a melting pot of Jewish customs and beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[506]</a></sup> Israel is the only country in the world where life revolves around the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_calendar" title="Hebrew calendar">Hebrew calendar</a>. <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Israel" title="Public holidays in Israel">Work and school holidays</a> are determined by the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_holiday" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish holiday">Jewish holidays</a>, and the official day of rest is Saturday, the <a href="/wiki/Shabbat" title="Shabbat">Jewish Sabbath</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">[507]</a></sup> Israel's substantial Arab minority has also left its imprint on Israeli culture in such spheres as <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Israel" title="Architecture of Israel">architecture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[508]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Israel" title="Music of Israel">music</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">[509]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_cuisine" title="Israeli cuisine">cuisine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[510]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Israeli_literature" title="Israeli literature">Israeli literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Agnon.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Agnon.jpg/170px-Agnon.jpg" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Agnon.jpg/255px-Agnon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Agnon.jpg/340px-Agnon.jpg 2x" data-file-width="651" data-file-height="868" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Agnon.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Shmuel_Yosef_Agnon" title="Shmuel Yosef Agnon">Shmuel Yosef Agnon</a>, laureate of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG/170px-Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG/255px-Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG/340px-Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="480" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Amos_Oz_by_Kubik.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Amos_Oz" title="Amos Oz">Amos Oz</a>'s works have been translated into 36 languages, more than any other Israeli writer.<sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514">[511]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Israeli_literature" title="Israeli literature">Israeli literature</a> is primarily <a href="/wiki/Modern_Hebrew_poetry" title="Modern Hebrew poetry">poetry</a> and prose written in Hebrew, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Revival_of_the_Hebrew_language" title="Revival of the Hebrew language">renaissance</a> of <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a> as a spoken language since the mid-19th century, although a small body of literature is published in other languages, such as English. By law, two copies of all printed matter published in Israel must be deposited in the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel" title="National Library of Israel">National Library of Israel</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>. In 2001, the law was amended to include audio and video recordings, and other non-print media.<sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">[512]</a></sup> In 2015, 85&#160;percent of the 7,843 books transferred to the library were in Hebrew.<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[513]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Book_Week" title="Hebrew Book Week">Hebrew Book Week</a> is held each June and features book fairs, public readings, and appearances by Israeli authors around the country. During the week, Israel's top literary award, the <a href="/wiki/Sapir_Prize" title="Sapir Prize">Sapir Prize</a>, is presented.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>In 1966, <a href="/wiki/Shmuel_Yosef_Agnon" title="Shmuel Yosef Agnon">Shmuel Yosef Agnon</a> shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> with German Jewish author <a href="/wiki/Nelly_Sachs" title="Nelly Sachs">Nelly Sachs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-517" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-517">[514]</a></sup> Leading Israeli poets have been <a href="/wiki/Yehuda_Amichai" title="Yehuda Amichai">Yehuda Amichai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathan_Alterman" title="Nathan Alterman">Nathan Alterman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Bluwstein" title="Rachel Bluwstein">Rachel Bluwstein</a>. Internationally famous contemporary Israeli novelists include <a href="/wiki/Amos_Oz" title="Amos Oz">Amos Oz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Etgar_Keret" title="Etgar Keret">Etgar Keret</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Grossman" title="David Grossman">David Grossman</a>. The Israeli-Arab satirist <a href="/wiki/Sayed_Kashua" title="Sayed Kashua">Sayed Kashua</a> (who writes in Hebrew) is also internationally known.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Israel has also been the home of two leading Palestinian poets and writers: <a href="/wiki/Emile_Habibi" title="Emile Habibi">Emile Habibi</a>, whose novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_Secret_Life_of_Saeed:_The_Pessoptimist" title="The Secret Life of Saeed: The Pessoptimist">The Secret Life of Saeed: The Pessoptimist</a></i>, and other writings, won him the Israel prize for Arabic literature; and <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Darwish" title="Mahmoud Darwish">Mahmoud Darwish</a>, considered by many to be "the Palestinian national poet."<sup id="cite_ref-518" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-518">[515]</a></sup> Darwish was born and raised in northern Israel, but lived his adult life abroad after joining the <a href="/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization" title="Palestine Liberation Organization">Palestine Liberation Organization</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Israel" title="Music of Israel">Music of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_Israel" title="Dance in Israel">Dance in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Several dozen musicians in formal dress, holding their instruments, behind a conductor" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg/220px-Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg/330px-Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg/440px-Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1824" data-file-height="1368" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Israel Philharmonic Orchestra">Israel Philharmonic Orchestra</a> conducted by <a href="/wiki/Zubin_Mehta" title="Zubin Mehta">Zubin Mehta</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Israel" title="Music of Israel">Israeli music</a> contains musical influences from all over the world; <a href="/wiki/Mizrahi_music" title="Mizrahi music">Mizrahi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sephardic_music" title="Sephardic music">Sephardic music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism" title="Hasidic Judaism">Hasidic</a> melodies, <a href="/wiki/Greek_music_in_Israel" title="Greek music in Israel">Greek music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pop_rock" title="Pop rock">pop rock</a> are all part of the music scene.<sup id="cite_ref-519" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-519">[516]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-520" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-520">[517]</a></sup> Among Israel's world-renowned<sup id="cite_ref-521" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-521">[518]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">[519]</a></sup> orchestras is the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Israel Philharmonic Orchestra">Israel Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, which has been in operation for over seventy years and today performs more than two hundred concerts each year.<sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523">[520]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Itzhak_Perlman" title="Itzhak Perlman">Itzhak Perlman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pinchas_Zukerman" title="Pinchas Zukerman">Pinchas Zukerman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ofra_Haza" title="Ofra Haza">Ofra Haza</a> are among the internationally acclaimed musicians born in Israel.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Israel_in_the_Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Israel in the Eurovision Song Contest">Israel has participated</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Eurovision Song Contest">Eurovision Song Contest</a> nearly every year since 1973, winning the competition three times and hosting it twice.<sup id="cite_ref-524" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-524">[521]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-525" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-525">[522]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eilat" title="Eilat">Eilat</a> has hosted its own international music festival, the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea_Jazz_Festival" title="Red Sea Jazz Festival">Red Sea Jazz Festival</a>, every summer since 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-526" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-526">[523]</a></sup> Israel is home to many Palestinian musicians, including an <a href="/wiki/Oud" title="Oud">oud</a> group <a href="/wiki/Le_Trio_Joubran" title="Le Trio Joubran">Le Trio Joubran</a> and singer <a href="/wiki/Amal_Murkus" title="Amal Murkus">Amal Murkus</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Academy_of_Music_and_Dance" title="Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance">Jerusalem Academy of Music and Dance</a> has an advanced degree program in Arabic music, headed by oud virtuoso Taiseer Elias.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_(GPO)_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg/170px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg/255px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg/340px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1952" data-file-height="2603" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_(GPO)_-_Afternoon_of_a_Faun.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Celebrated Israeli ballet dancers <a href="/wiki/Valery_Panov" title="Valery Panov">Valery and Galina Panov</a>, who founded the Ballet Panov, in <a href="/wiki/Ashdod" title="Ashdod">Ashdod</a><sup id="cite_ref-527" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-527">[524]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The nation's canonical <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk songs</a>, known as "Songs of the Land of Israel," deal with the experiences of the pioneers in building the Jewish homeland.<sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">[525]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hora_(dance)" title="Hora (dance)">Hora</a> circle dance introduced by early Jewish settlers was originally popular in the <a href="/wiki/Kibbutz" title="Kibbutz">kibbutzim</a> and outlying communities. It became a symbol of the Zionist reconstruction and of the ability to experience joy amidst austerity. It now plays a significant role in modern <a href="/wiki/Israeli_folk_dancing" title="Israeli folk dancing">Israeli folk dancing</a> and is regularly performed at weddings and other celebrations, and in group dances throughout Israel.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Modern dance in Israel is a flourishing field, and several Israeli choreographers such as <a href="/wiki/Ohad_Naharin" title="Ohad Naharin">Ohad Naharin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barak_Marshall" title="Barak Marshall">Barak Marshall</a> and many others, are considered<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (March 2016)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup> to be among the most versatile and original international creators working today. Famous Israeli companies include the <a href="/wiki/Batsheva_Dance_Company" title="Batsheva Dance Company">Batsheva Dance Company</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kibbutz_Contemporary_Dance_Company" title="Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company">Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema_and_theatre">Cinema and theatre</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Israel" title="Cinema of Israel">Cinema of Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg/220px-Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg/330px-Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg/440px-Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3120" data-file-height="2386" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Habima_Theatre_building-Tel_Aviv-3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Habima_Theatre" title="Habima Theatre">Habima Theatre</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Ten Israeli films <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_submissions_for_the_Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="List of Israeli submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">have been final nominees</a> for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Best Foreign Language Film</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">Academy Awards</a> since the establishment of Israel. The 2009 movie <i><a href="/wiki/Ajami_(film)" title="Ajami (film)">Ajami</a></i> was the third consecutive nomination of an Israeli film.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">[526]</a></sup> Palestinian Israeli filmmakers have made a number of films dealing with the Arab-Israel conflict and the status of Palestinians within Israel, such as <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Bakri" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohammed Bakri">Mohammed Bakri</a>'s 2002 film <i><a href="/wiki/Jenin,_Jenin" title="Jenin, Jenin">Jenin, Jenin</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Syrian_Bride" title="The Syrian Bride">The Syrian Bride</a></i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>Continuing the strong theatrical traditions of the <a href="/wiki/Yiddish_theatre" title="Yiddish theatre">Yiddish theatre</a> in Eastern Europe, Israel maintains a vibrant theatre scene. Founded in 1918, <a href="/wiki/Habima_Theatre" title="Habima Theatre">Habima Theatre</a> in Tel Aviv is Israel's oldest <a href="/wiki/Repertory_theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Repertory theater">repertory theater</a> company and national theater.<sup id="cite_ref-530" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-530">[527]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Israel" title="Media of Israel">Media of Israel</a></div>
<p>The 2016 <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)">Freedom of the Press</a></i> annual report by <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> ranked Israel as the <a href="/wiki/MENA" title="MENA">Middle East and North Africa</a>'s most free country, and 65th globally.<sup id="cite_ref-531" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-531">[528]</a></sup> In the 2016 <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> by <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>, Israel (including "Israel extraterritorial" since 2013 ranking)<sup id="cite_ref-532" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-532">[529]</a></sup> was placed 101st of 180 countries, and 3rd below <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> (at 96) and <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> (at 98) in the Middle East and North Africa region.<sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">[530]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_museums" title="List of Israeli museums">List of Israeli museums</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_(14755133799).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/220px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/330px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/440px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4752" data-file-height="3168" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_(14755133799).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Book" title="Shrine of the Book">Shrine of the Book</a>, repository of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a> in Jerusalem</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Museum" title="Israel Museum">Israel Museum</a> in Jerusalem is one of Israel's most important cultural institutions<sup id="cite_ref-imj_534-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imj-534">[531]</a></sup> and houses the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-535" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-535">[532]</a></sup> along with an extensive collection of <a href="/wiki/Judaica" class="mw-redirect" title="Judaica">Judaica</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_art" class="mw-redirect" title="European art">European art</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-imj_534-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imj-534">[531]</a></sup> Israel's national <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">Holocaust</a> museum, <a href="/wiki/Yad_Vashem" title="Yad Vashem">Yad Vashem</a>, is the world central archive of Holocaust-related information.<sup id="cite_ref-536" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-536">[533]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Beit_Hatfutsot" title="Beit Hatfutsot">Beit Hatfutsot</a> ("The Diaspora House"), on the campus of <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University" title="Tel Aviv University">Tel Aviv University</a>, is an interactive museum devoted to the history of Jewish communities around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-537" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-537">[534]</a></sup> Apart from the major museums in large cities, there are high-quality artspaces in many towns and <a href="/wiki/Kibbutz" title="Kibbutz">kibbutzim</a>. Mishkan LeOmanut in kibbutz <a href="/wiki/Ein_Harod_(Meuhad)" title="Ein Harod (Meuhad)">Ein Harod Meuhad</a> is the largest art museum in the north of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538">[535]</a></sup></p>
<p>Israel has the highest number of museums per capita in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-539" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-539">[536]</a></sup> Several Israeli museums are devoted to Islamic culture, including the <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Museum" title="Rockefeller Museum">Rockefeller Museum</a> and the <a href="/wiki/L._A._Mayer_Institute_for_Islamic_Art" title="L. A. Mayer Institute for Islamic Art">L. A. Mayer Institute for Islamic Art</a>, both in Jerusalem. The Rockefeller specializes in archaeological remains from the Ottoman and other periods of Middle East history. It is also the home of the first <a href="/wiki/Hominid" class="mw-redirect" title="Hominid">hominid</a> fossil skull found in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> called <a href="/wiki/Galilee_Man" class="mw-redirect" title="Galilee Man">Galilee Man</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540">[537]</a></sup> A cast of the skull is on display at the Israel Museum.<sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541">[538]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Israeli_cuisine" title="Israeli cuisine">Israeli cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Food_in_Israel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Food_in_Israel.jpg/220px-Food_in_Israel.jpg" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Food_in_Israel.jpg/330px-Food_in_Israel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Food_in_Israel.jpg/440px-Food_in_Israel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2390" data-file-height="1620" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Food_in_Israel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A meal including <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_fries" title="French fries">French fries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_salad" title="Israeli salad">Israeli salad</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Israeli_cuisine" title="Israeli cuisine">Israeli cuisine</a> includes local dishes as well as <a href="/wiki/Jewish_cuisine" title="Jewish cuisine">Jewish cuisine</a> brought to the country by immigrants from the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_diaspora" title="Jewish diaspora">diaspora</a>. Since the establishment of the state in 1948, and particularly since the late 1970s, an Israeli <a href="/wiki/Fusion_cuisine" title="Fusion cuisine">fusion cuisine</a> has developed.<sup id="cite_ref-raviv_542-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-raviv-542">[539]</a></sup> Israeli cuisine has adopted, and continues to adapt, elements of the <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_Mizrahi_Jews" title="Cuisine of the Mizrahi Jews">Mizrahi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_Sephardic_Jews" title="Cuisine of the Sephardic Jews">Sephardi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_cuisine" class="mw-redirect" title="Ashkenazi cuisine">Ashkenazi</a> styles of cooking. It incorporates many foods traditionally eaten in the <a href="/wiki/Levantine_cuisine" title="Levantine cuisine">Levantine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine" title="Middle Eastern cuisine">Middle Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">Mediterranean</a> cuisines, such as <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shakshouka" title="Shakshouka">shakshouka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Couscous" title="Couscous">couscous</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Za%27atar" title="Za'atar">za'atar</a>. <a href="/wiki/Schnitzel" title="Schnitzel">Schnitzel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pizza" title="Pizza">pizza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamburger" title="Hamburger">hamburgers</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_fries" title="French fries">French fries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salad" title="Salad">salad</a> are also common in Israel.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>Roughly half of the Israeli-Jewish population attests to keeping <a href="/wiki/Kosher" class="mw-redirect" title="Kosher">kosher</a> at home.<sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543">[540]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bernstein_544-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bernstein-544">[541]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kosher_restaurant" title="Kosher restaurant">Kosher restaurants</a>, though rare in the 1960s, make up around 25% of the total as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, perhaps reflecting the largely secular values of those who dine out.<sup id="cite_ref-raviv_542-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-raviv-542">[539]</a></sup> Hotel restaurants are much more likely to serve kosher food.<sup id="cite_ref-raviv_542-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-raviv-542">[539]</a></sup> The non-kosher retail market was traditionally sparse, but grew rapidly and considerably following <a href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">the influx of immigrants from the post-Soviet states</a> during the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-bernstein_545-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bernstein-545">[542]</a></sup> Together with non-kosher fish, rabbits and ostriches, <a href="/wiki/Pork" title="Pork">pork</a>—often called "white meat" in Israel<sup id="cite_ref-bernstein_545-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bernstein-545">[542]</a></sup>—is produced and consumed, though <a href="/wiki/Religious_restrictions_on_the_consumption_of_pork" title="Religious restrictions on the consumption of pork">it is forbidden</a> by both Judaism and Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-546">[543]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Israel" title="Sport in Israel">Sport in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Teddy_Stadium,_Jerusalem.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/220px-Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem.jpg" width="220" height="91" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/330px-Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/440px-Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="2479" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Teddy_Stadium,_Jerusalem.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Teddy_Stadium" title="Teddy Stadium">Teddy Stadium</a> of Jerusalem</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The most popular spectator sports in Israel are <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">[544]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Premier_League" title="Israeli Premier League">Israeli Premier League</a> is the country's premier football league, and the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Basketball_Premier_League" title="Israeli Basketball Premier League">Israeli Basketball Premier League</a> is the premier basketball league.<sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">[545]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maccabi_Haifa_F.C." title="Maccabi Haifa F.C.">Maccabi Haifa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maccabi_Tel_Aviv_F.C." title="Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.">Maccabi Tel Aviv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hapoel_Tel_Aviv_F.C." title="Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C.">Hapoel Tel Aviv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beitar_Jerusalem_F.C." title="Beitar Jerusalem F.C.">Beitar Jerusalem</a> are the largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_football_clubs_in_Israel" title="List of football clubs in Israel">football clubs</a>. Maccabi Tel Aviv, Maccabi Haifa and Hapoel Tel Aviv have competed in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">UEFA Champions League</a> and Hapoel Tel Aviv reached the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Cup">UEFA Cup</a> quarter-finals. Israel hosted and won the <a href="/wiki/1964_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="1964 AFC Asian Cup">1964 AFC Asian Cup</a>; in 1970 the <a href="/wiki/Israel_national_football_team" title="Israel national football team">Israel national football team</a> qualified for the <a href="/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1970 FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>, the only time it participated in the World Cup. The <a href="/wiki/1974_Asian_Games" title="1974 Asian Games">1974 Asian Games</a> held in Tehran, were the last Asian Games in which Israel <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_Asian_Games" title="Israel at the Asian Games">participated</a>, and was plagued by the Arab countries which <a href="/wiki/Boycotts_of_Israel_in_sports" title="Boycotts of Israel in sports">refused</a> to compete with Israel. Israel was excluded from the <a href="/wiki/1978_Asian_Games" title="1978 Asian Games">1978 Asian Games</a> and since then has not competed in Asian sport events.<sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">[546]</a></sup> In 1994, <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a> agreed to admit Israel and its soccer teams now compete in Europe.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Maccabi_Tel_Aviv_B.C." title="Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.">Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.</a> has won the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_European_Champions_Cup_and_EuroLeague_records_and_statistics" title="FIBA European Champions Cup and EuroLeague records and statistics">European championship</a> in basketball six times.<sup id="cite_ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550">[547]</a></sup> In 2016, the country was chosen as a host for the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2017" title="EuroBasket 2017">EuroBasket 2017</a>.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg/220px-BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg" width="220" height="203" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg/330px-BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg/440px-BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2943" data-file-height="2722" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Boris_Gelfand" title="Boris Gelfand">Boris Gelfand</a>, chess Grandmaster</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is a leading sport in Israel and is enjoyed by people of all ages. There are many Israeli grandmasters and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_chess_players" title="List of Israeli chess players">Israeli chess players</a> have won a number of youth world championships.<sup id="cite_ref-551" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-551">[548]</a></sup> Israel stages an annual international <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Chess_Championship" title="Israeli Chess Championship">championship</a> and hosted the <a href="/wiki/World_Team_Chess_Championship" title="World Team Chess Championship">World Team Chess Championship</a> in 2005. The Ministry of Education and the <a href="/wiki/FIDE" title="FIDE">World Chess Federation</a> agreed upon a project of teaching chess within Israeli schools, and it has been introduced into the curriculum of some schools.<sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552">[549]</a></sup> The city of <a href="/wiki/Beersheba" title="Beersheba">Beersheba</a> has become a national chess center, with the game being taught in the city's kindergartens. Owing partly to Soviet immigration, it is home to the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">chess grandmasters</a> of any city in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">[550]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">[551]</a></sup> The Israeli chess team won the silver medal at the <a href="/wiki/38th_Chess_Olympiad" title="38th Chess Olympiad">2008 Chess Olympiad</a><sup id="cite_ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555">[552]</a></sup> and the bronze, coming in third among 148 teams, at the <a href="/wiki/39th_Chess_Olympiad" title="39th Chess Olympiad">2010 Olympiad</a>. Israeli grandmaster <a href="/wiki/Boris_Gelfand" title="Boris Gelfand">Boris Gelfand</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup_2009" title="Chess World Cup 2009">Chess World Cup 2009</a><sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556">[553]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2012#Candidates_tournament" title="World Chess Championship 2012">2011 Candidates Tournament</a> for the right to challenge the world champion. He only lost the <a href="/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2012" title="World Chess Championship 2012">World Chess Championship 2012</a> to reigning world champion <a href="/wiki/Viswanathan_Anand" title="Viswanathan Anand">Anand</a> after a speed-chess tie breaker.</p>
<p>Israel has won <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_Olympics" title="Israel at the Olympics">nine Olympic medals</a> since its first win <a href="/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics" title="1992 Summer Olympics">in 1992</a>, including a gold medal in <a href="/wiki/Sailing_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Mistral_One_Design" title="Sailing at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's Mistral One Design">windsurfing</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557">[554]</a></sup> Israel has won <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_Paralympics" title="Israel at the Paralympics">over 100</a> gold medals in the <a href="/wiki/Paralympic_Games" title="Paralympic Games">Paralympic Games</a> and is ranked 20th in the <a href="/wiki/All-time_Paralympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Paralympic Games medal table">all-time medal count</a>. The <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Paralympics" title="1968 Summer Paralympics">1968 Summer Paralympics</a> were hosted by Israel.<sup id="cite_ref-558" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-558">[555]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Maccabiah_Games" title="Maccabiah Games">Maccabiah Games</a>, an Olympic-style event for <a href="/wiki/List_of_Jews_in_sports" title="List of Jews in sports">Jewish</a> and Israeli athletes, was inaugurated in the 1930s, and has been held every four years since then. Israeli tennis champion <a href="/wiki/Shahar_Pe%27er" title="Shahar Pe'er">Shahar Pe'er</a> ranked 11th in the world on 31 January 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-559" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-559">[556]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Krav_Maga" title="Krav Maga">Krav Maga</a>, a martial art developed by Jewish ghetto defenders during the struggle against fascism in Europe, is used by the Israeli security forces and police. Its effectiveness and practical approach to self-defense, have won it widespread admiration and adherence around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-560" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-560">[557]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
