<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Jerusalem Law</a> states that "Jerusalem, complete and united, is the capital of Israel" and the city serves as the seat of the government, home to the President's residence, government offices, supreme court, and <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">parliament</a>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_478" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 478">United Nations Security Council Resolution 478</a> (20 August 1980; 14–0, U.S. abstaining) declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem. The United Nations and all member nations refuse to accept the Jerusalem Law (see <a href="#CITEREFKellerman1993">Kellerman 1993</a>, p.&#160;140) and maintain their embassies in other cities such as Tel Aviv, <a href="/wiki/Ramat_Gan" title="Ramat Gan">Ramat Gan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Herzliya" title="Herzliya">Herzliya</a> (see the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/is.html">CIA Factbook</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/israel.pdf">Map of Israel</a>). The U.S. Congress subsequently adopted the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Embassy_Act" title="Jerusalem Embassy Act">Jerusalem Embassy Act</a>, which said that the U.S. embassy should be relocated to Jerusalem and that it should be recognized as the capital of Israel. However, the US Justice Department Office of Legal Counsel concluded that the provisions of the act "invade exclusive presidential authorities in the field of foreign affairs and are unconstitutional". Since passage of the act, all presidents serving in office have determined that moving forward with the relocation would be detrimental to U.S. national security concerns and opted to issue waivers suspending any action on this front. The <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_Authority" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian Authority">Palestinian Authority</a> sees <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> as the capital of a <a href="/wiki/Proposals_for_a_Palestinian_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Proposals for a Palestinian state">future Palestinian state</a>. The city's final status awaits future negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority (see <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pij.org/details.php?id=460">"Negotiating Jerusalem," Palestine–Israel Journal</a>). See <a href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">Positions on Jerusalem</a> for more information.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-note2-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-note2_23-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-note2_23-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">The majority of the international community (including the UN General Assembly, the United Nations Security Council, the European Union, the International Criminal Court, and the vast majority of human rights organizations) considers Israel to be occupying Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem. Gaza is still considered to be "<a href="/wiki/Military_occupation" title="Military occupation">occupied</a>" by the United Nations, international human rights organisations, and the majority of governments and legal commentators, despite the 2005 <a href="/wiki/Israeli_disengagement_from_Gaza" title="Israeli disengagement from Gaza">Israeli disengagement from Gaza</a>, due to various forms of ongoing military and economic control.<sup id="cite_ref-occ_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-occ-28">[26]</a></sup><br />
The government of Israel and some supporters have, at times, disputed this position of the international community. For more details of this terminology dispute, including with respect to the current status of the Gaza Strip, see <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories#International_views" title="Israeli-occupied territories">International views on the Israeli-occupied territories</a> and <a href="/wiki/Status_of_territories_captured_by_Israel" title="Status of territories captured by Israel">Status of territories captured by Israel</a>.<br />
For an explanation of the differences between an annexed but disputed territory (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a>) and a militarily occupied territory, please see the article <a href="/wiki/Military_occupation" title="Military occupation">Military occupation</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(פלשתינה (א״י in Hebrew (translation: Palestine (Eretz Israel))</span></li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-population_stat-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-population_stat_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-population_stat_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-population_stat_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/latest-population-statistics-for-israel">"Latest Population Statistics for Israel"</a>. <i>Jewish Virtual Library</i>. Central Intelligence Agency<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 January</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Israel&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Flibrary%2Fpublications%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Fgeos%2Fis.html&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Factbook&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-cbs_main-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cbs_main_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cbs_main_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/cw_usr_view_Folder?ID=141">"Home page"</a>. <li id="cite_note-occ-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-occ_28-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Sanger, Andrew (2011). M.N. Schmitt, Louise Arimatsu, Tim McCormack, eds. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hYiIWVlpFzEC&amp;pg=PA429#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false">"The Contemporary Law of Blockade and the Gaza Freedom Flotilla"</a>. <i>Yearbook of International Humanitarian Law 2010</i>. Springer Science &amp; Business Media. <b>13</b>: 429. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.1007%2F978-90-6704-811-8_14">10.1007/978-90-6704-811-8_14</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9789067048118" title="Special:BookSources/9789067048118">9789067048118</a>. <q>Israel claims it no longer occupies the Gaza Strip, maintaining that it is neither a Stale nor a territory occupied or controlled by Israel, but rather it has 'sui generis' status. Pursuant to the Disengagement Plan, Israel dismantled all military institutions and settlements in Gaza and there is no longer a permanent Israeli military or civilian presence in the territory. However the Plan also provided that Israel will guard and monitor the external land perimeter of the Gaza Strip, will continue to maintain exclusive authority in Gaza air space, and will continue to exercise security activity in the sea off the coast of the Gaza Strip as well as maintaining an Israeli military presence on the Egyptian-Gaza border. and reserving the right to reenter Gaza at will.<br />
Israel continues to control six of Gaza's seven land crossings, its maritime borders and airspace and the movement of goods and persons in and out of the territory. Egypt controls one of Gaza's land crossings. Troops from the Israeli Defence Force regularly enter pans of the territory and/or deploy missile attacks, drones and sonic bombs into Gaza. Israel has declared a no-go buffer zone that stretches deep into Gaza: if Gazans enter this zone they are shot on sight. Gaza is also dependent on israel for inter alia electricity, currency, telephone networks, issuing IDs, and permits to enter and leave the territory. Israel also has sole control of the Palestinian Population Registry through which the Israeli Army regulates who is classified as a Palestinian and who is a Gazan or West Banker. Since 2000 aside from a limited number of exceptions Israel has refused to add people to the Palestinian Population Registry.<br />
It is this direct external control over Gaza and indirect control over life within Gaza that has led the United Nations, the UN General Assembly, the UN Fact Finding Mission to Gaza, International human rights organisations, US Government websites, the UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office and a significant number of legal commentators, to reject the argument that Gaza is no longer occupied.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=The+Contemporary+Law+of+Blockade+and+the+Gaza+Freedom+Flotilla&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Sanger&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DhYiIWVlpFzEC%26pg%3DPA429%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1007%2F978-90-6704-811-8_14&amp;rft.isbn=9789067048118&amp;rft.jtitle=Yearbook+of+International+Humanitarian+Law+2010&amp;rft.pages=429&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=13" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span> <span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33">CS1 maint: Uses editors parameter (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Uses_editors_parameter" title="Category:CS1 maint: Uses editors parameter">link</a>)</span><br />
* <cite class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Iain_Scobbie" title="Iain Scobbie">Scobbie, Iain</a> (2012). Elizabeth Wilmshurst, ed. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GM90Xp03uuEC&amp;pg=PA295#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>International Law and the Classification of Conflicts</i></a>. Oxford University Press. p.&#160;295. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780199657759" title="Special:BookSources/9780199657759">9780199657759</a>. <q>Even after the accession to power of Hamas, Israel's claim that it no longer occupies Gaza has not been accepted by UN bodies, most States, nor the majority of academic commentators because of its exclusive control of its border with Gaza and crossing points including the effective control it exerted over the Rafah crossing until at least May 2011, its control of Gaza's maritime zones and airspace which constitute what Aronson terms the 'security envelope' around Gaza, as well as its ability to intervene forcibly at will in Gaza.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Iain&amp;rft.aulast=Scobbie&amp;rft.btitle=International+Law+and+the+Classification+of+Conflicts&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DGM90Xp03uuEC%26pg%3DPA295%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780199657759&amp;rft.pages=295&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span><br />
* <cite class="citation book">Gawerc, Michelle (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Hka8FZ4UdWUC&amp;pg=PA44#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Prefiguring Peace: Israeli-Palestinian Peacebuilding Partnerships</i></a>. Lexington Books. p.&#160;44. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780739166109" title="Special:BookSources/9780739166109">9780739166109</a>. <q>While Israel withdrew from the immediate territory, Israel still controlled all access to and from Gaza through the border crossings, as well as through the coastline and the airspace. ln addition, Gaza was dependent upon Israel for water electricity sewage communication networks and for its trade (Gisha 2007. Dowty 2008). ln other words, while Israel maintained that its occupation of Gaza ended with its unilateral disengagement Palestinians – as well as many human right organizations and international bodies – argued that Gaza was by all intents and purposes still occupied.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.aulast=Gawerc&amp;rft.btitle=Prefiguring+Peace%3A+Israeli-Palestinian+Peacebuilding+Partnerships&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DHka8FZ4UdWUC%26pg%3DPA44%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780739166109&amp;rft.pages=44&amp;rft.pub=Lexington+Books&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See for example:<br />
* <cite class="citation book">Hajjar, Lisa (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=mcjoHq2wqdUC&amp;pg=PA96#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Courting Conflict: The Israeli Military Court System in the West Bank and Gaza</i></a>. University of California Press. p.&#160;96. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0520241940" title="Special:BookSources/0520241940">0520241940</a>. <q>The Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza is the longest military occupation in modern times.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=Hajjar&amp;rft.btitle=Courting+Conflict%3A+The+Israeli+Military+Court+System+in+the+West+Bank+and+Gaza&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DmcjoHq2wqdUC%26pg%3DPA96%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=0520241940&amp;rft.pages=96&amp;rft.pub=University+of+California+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span><br />
* <cite class="citation journal"><a href="/wiki/Perry_Anderson" title="Perry Anderson">Anderson, Perry</a> (July–August 2001). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://newleftreview.org/article/download_pdf?id=2330">"Editorial: Scurrying Towards Bethlehem"</a>. <i>New Left Review</i>. <b>10</b>. <q>...longest official military occupation of modern history—currently entering its thirty-fifth year</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Editorial%3A+Scurrying+Towards+Bethlehem&amp;rft.aufirst=Perry&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.date=2001-07%2F2001-08&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fnewleftreview.org%2Farticle%2Fdownload_pdf%3Fid%3D2330&amp;rft.jtitle=New+Left+Review&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=10" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span><br />
* <cite class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Saree_Makdisi" title="Saree Makdisi">Makdisi, Saree</a> (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2dBM3Ago2BAC&amp;pg=PA299#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Palestine Inside Out: An Everyday Occupation</i></a>. W. W. Norton &amp; Company. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780393338447" title="Special:BookSources/9780393338447">9780393338447</a>. <q>...longest-lasting military occupation of the modern age</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Saree&amp;rft.aulast=Makdisi&amp;rft.btitle=Palestine+Inside+Out%3A+An+Everyday+Occupation&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D2dBM3Ago2BAC%26pg%3DPA299%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780393338447&amp;rft.pub=W.+W.+Norton+%26+Company&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span><br />
* <cite class="citation journal"><a href="/wiki/David_Kretzmer" title="David Kretzmer">Kretzmer, David</a> (Spring 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.icrc.org/eng/assets/files/review/2012/irrc-885-kretzmer.pdf">"The law of belligerent occupation in the Supreme Court of Israel"</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF)</span>. <i>International Review of the Red Cross</i>. <b>94</b> (885): 207–236. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.1017%2FS1816383112000446">10.1017/S1816383112000446</a>. <q>This is probably the longest occupation in modern international relations, and it holds a central place in all literature on the law of belligerent occupation since the early 1970s</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=The+law+of+belligerent+occupation+in+the+Supreme+Court+of+Israel&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.aulast=Kretzmer&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.icrc.org%2Feng%2Fassets%2Ffiles%2Freview%2F2012%2Firrc-885-kretzmer.pdf&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS1816383112000446&amp;rft.issue=885&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Review+of+the+Red+Cross&amp;rft.pages=207-236&amp;rft.ssn=spring&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=94" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span><br />
* <cite id="CITEREFAlexandrowicz2012" class="citation">Alexandrowicz, Ra'anan (24 January 2012), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/25/opinion/the-justice-of-occupation.html?_r=0"><i>The Justice of Occupation</i></a>, The New York Times, <q>Israel is the only modern state that has held territories under military occupation for over four decades</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Ra%27anan&amp;rft.aulast=Alexandrowicz&amp;rft.btitle=The+Justice+of+Occupation&amp;rft.date=2012-01-24&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2012%2F01%2F25%2Fopinion%2Fthe-justice-of-occupation.html%3F_r%3D0&amp;rft.pub=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span><br />
* <cite class="citation book">Weill, Sharon (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bDnnAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA22#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>The Role of National Courts in Applying International Humanitarian Law</i></a>. Oxford University Press. p.&#160;22. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780199685424" title="Special:BookSources/9780199685424">9780199685424</a>. <q>Although the basic philosophy behind the law of military occupation is that it is a temporary situation modem occupations have well demonstrated that <i>rien ne dure comme le provisoire</i> A significant number of post-1945 occupations have lasted more than two decades such as the occupations of Namibia by South Africa and of East Timor by Indonesia as well as the ongoing occupations of Northern Cyprus by Turkey and of Western Sahara by Morocco. The Israeli occupation of the Palestinian territories, <u>which is the longest in all occupation's history</u> has already entered its fifth decade.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Sharon&amp;rft.aulast=Weill&amp;rft.btitle=The+Role+of+National+Courts+in+Applying+International+Humanitarian+Law&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.uk%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DbDnnAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA22%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780199685424&amp;rft.pages=22&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Adriana_Kemp-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Adriana_Kemp_30-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Adriana_Kemp_30-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Adriana Kemp, "Labour migration and racialisation: labour market mechanisms and labour migration control policies in Israel", <i>Social Identities</i> 10:2, 267–292, 2004</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-OECD_education-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-OECD_education_36-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-OECD_education_36-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation report"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.keepeek.com/Digital-Asset-Management/oecd/education/education-at-a-glance-2016/israel_eag-2016-63-en">Education at a Glance: Israel</a> (Report). <li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.haaretz.com/news/who-life-expectancy-in-israel-among-highest-in-the-world-1.276618">"WHO: Life expectancy in Israel among highest in the world"</a>. <i>Haaretz</i>. 24 May 2009.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=WHO%3A+Life+expectancy+in+Israel+among+highest+in+the+world&amp;rft.date=2009-05-24&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.haaretz.com%2Fnews%2Fwho-life-expectancy-in-israel-among-highest-in-the-world-1.276618&amp;rft.jtitle=Haaretz&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jpress.org.il/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToSaveGifMSIE_TAUEN&amp;Type=text/html&amp;Locale=english-skin-custom&amp;Path=PLS/1947/12/07&amp;ChunkNum=-1&amp;ID=Ar00105&amp;PageLabel=1">"Popular Opinion"</a>. <i>The Palestine Post</i>. <li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Dever, William G. (2003). <i>Who Were the Early Israelites and Where Did They Come From?</i>. Grand Rapids, MI: Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co. p.&#160;206.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=William+G.&amp;rft.aulast=Dever&amp;rft.btitle=Who+Were+the+Early+Israelites+and+Where+Did+They+Come+From%3F&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=206&amp;rft.place=Grand+Rapids%2C+MI&amp;rft.pub=Wm.+B.+Eerdmans+Publishing+Co.&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">FLEMING, DANIEL E. (1998-01-01). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/23282083">"MARI AND THE POSSIBILITIES OF BIBLICAL MEMORY"</a>. <i>Revue d'Assyriologie et d'archéologie orientale</i>. <b>92</b> (1): 41–78. <q>The Assyrian royal annals, along with the Mesha and Dan inscriptions, show a thriving northern state called Israël in the mid—9th century, and the continuity of settlement back to the early Iron Age suggests that the establishment of a sedentary identity should be associated with this population, whatever their origin. In the mid—14th century, the Amarna letters mention no Israël, nor any of the biblical tribes, while the Merneptah stele places someone called Israël in hill-country Palestine toward the end of the Late Bronze Age. The language and material culture of emergent Israël show strong local continuity, in contrast to the distinctly foreign character of early Philistine material culture.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=MARI+AND+THE+POSSIBILITIES+OF+BIBLICAL+MEMORY&amp;rft.aufirst=DANIEL+E.&amp;rft.aulast=FLEMING&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F23282083&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.jtitle=Revue+d%27Assyriologie+et+d%27arch%C3%A9ologie+orientale&amp;rft.pages=41-78&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=92" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Hasel, Michael G. (1994-01-01). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/1357179">"Israel in the Merneptah Stela"</a>. <i>Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research</i> (296): 45–61. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.2307%2F1357179">10.2307/1357179</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Israel+in+the+Merneptah+Stela&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+G.&amp;rft.aulast=Hasel&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F1357179&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F1357179&amp;rft.issue=296&amp;rft.jtitle=Bulletin+of+the+American+Schools+of+Oriental+Research&amp;rft.pages=45-61&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Bertman, Stephen (2005-07-14). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1C4NKp4zgIQC&amp;lpg=PA317&amp;dq=ebla%20israel%20ishmael%20abraham&amp;pg=PA317#v=onepage&amp;q=ebla%20israel%20ishmael%20abraham&amp;f=false"><i>Handbook to Life in Ancient Mesopotamia</i></a>. OUP USA. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780195183641" title="Special:BookSources/9780195183641">9780195183641</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Bertman&amp;rft.btitle=Handbook+to+Life+in+Ancient+Mesopotamia&amp;rft.date=2005-07-14&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1C4NKp4zgIQC%26lpg%3DPA317%26dq%3Debla%2520israel%2520ishmael%2520abraham%26pg%3DPA317%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Debla%2520israel%2520ishmael%2520abraham%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780195183641&amp;rft.pub=OUP+USA&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gnuse 1997, pp.28,31<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="">title&#160;missing</span></a></i>]</sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199935-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199935_63-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMcNutt1999">McNutt 1999</a>, p.&#160;35.</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-MosheGil-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MosheGil_83-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFGil1997" class="citation book">Gil, Moshe (1997). <i>A History of Palestine, 634–1099</i>. <li id="cite_note-Cooper2009-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cooper2009_84-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Allan D. Cooper (2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Uyh8kdcuA1kC&amp;pg=PA132"><i>The geography of genocide</i></a>. University Press of America. p.&#160;132. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7618-4097-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7618-4097-8">978-0-7618-4097-8</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Carmel, Alex. <i>The History of Haifa Under Turkish Rule</i>. Haifa: Pardes, 2002 (<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9657171059" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 965-7171-05-9</a>), pp. 16–17</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-634to1099-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-634to1099_86-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Moshe Gil (1992). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=tSM4AAAAIAAJ&amp;pg=PA829&amp;lpg=PA829&amp;dq=1100+%22haifa%22+fatimid+jews#v=onepage&amp;q=Albericus&amp;f=false"><i>A History of Palestine, 634–1099</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;829. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780521404372" title="Special:BookSources/9780521404372">9780521404372</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 May</span> 2015</span>. <q>Haifa was taken [...] in August 1100 or June 1101, according to Muslim sources which contradict one another. Albert of Aachen does not mention the date in a clear manner either. From what he says, it appears that it was mainly the Jewish inhabitants of the city who defended the fortress of Haifa. In his rather strange Latin style, he mentions that there was a Jewish population in Haifa, and that they fought bravely on the walls of the city. He explains that the Jews there were protected people of the Muslims (the Fatimids). They fought side by side with units of the Fatimid army, striking back at Tancred's army from above the walls of the citadel (... <i>Judaei civis comixtis Sarracenorum turmis</i>) until the Crusaders overcame them and they were forced to abandon the walls. The Muslims and the Jews then managed to escape from the fortress with their lives, while the rest of the population fled the city <i>en masse</i>. Whoever remained was slaughtered, and huge quantities of spoils were taken. [...] [Note #3: Albert of Aachen (Albericus, Albertus Aquensis), <i>Historia Hierosolymitanae Expeditionis</i>, in: <a href="/wiki/Recueil_des_historiens_des_croisades" title="Recueil des historiens des croisades"><i>RHC</i></a> (Occ.), IV. p. 523; etc.]</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Moshe+Gil&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Palestine%2C+634%931099&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DtSM4AAAAIAAJ%26pg%3DPA829%26lpg%3DPA829%26dq%3D1100%2B%2522haifa%2522%2Bfatimid%2Bjews%23v%3Donepage%26q%3DAlbericus%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780521404372&amp;rft.pages=829&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Resnick2012-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Resnick2012_87-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Irven M. Resnick (1 June 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LarC4PG9osUC&amp;pg=PA49"><i>Marks of Distinctions: Christian Perceptions of Jews in the High Middle Ages</i></a>. CUA Press. pp.&#160;48–49. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-1969-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-1969-1">978-0-8132-1969-1</a>. <q>citizens of the Jewish race, who lived in the city by the favour and consent of the king of Egypt in return for payment of tribute, got on the walls bearing arms and put up a very stubborn defence, until the Christians, weighed down by various blows over the period of two weeks, absolutely despaired and held back their hands from any attack. [...] the Jewish citizens, mixed with Saracen troops, at once fought back manfully,... and counter-attacked. [Albert of Aachen, <i>Historia Ierosolimitana</i> 7.23, ed. and transl. Susan B. Edgington (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2007), 516 and 521.]</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Irven+M.+Resnick&amp;rft.btitle=Marks+of+Distinctions%3A+Christian+Perceptions+of+Jews+in+the+High+Middle+Ages&amp;rft.date=2012-06-01&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLarC4PG9osUC%26pg%3DPA49&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8132-1969-1&amp;rft.pages=48-49&amp;rft.pub=CUA+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Joshua Prawer. <i>The Jews of the Latin Kingdom of Jerusalem</i>. pp.&#160;34–40.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Joshua+Prawer&amp;rft.btitle=The+Jews+of+the+Latin+Kingdom+of+Jerusalem&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=34-40&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-JVL-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-JVL_89-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Judaism/AbuhavSyn.html">The Abuhav Synagogue</a>, Jewish Virtual Library.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sefer HaCharedim Mitzvat Tshuva Chapter 3. Maimonides established a yearly holiday for himself and his sons, 6 <a href="/wiki/Cheshvan" title="Cheshvan">Cheshvan</a>, commemorating the day he went up to pray on the Temple Mount, and another, 9 Cheshvan, commemorating the day he merited to pray at the <a href="/wiki/Cave_of_the_Patriarchs" title="Cave of the Patriarchs">Cave of the Patriarchs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Bloch1987-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Bloch1987_91-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Abraham P. Bloch (1987). "Sultan Saladin Opens Jerusalem to Jews". <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=mjxJAFawRasC&amp;pg=PA277"><i>One a day: an anthology of Jewish historical anniversaries for every day of the year</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/KTAV_Publishing_House,_Inc." class="mw-redirect" title="KTAV Publishing House, Inc.">KTAV Publishing House, Inc.</a> p.&#160;277. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-88125-108-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-88125-108-1">978-0-88125-108-1</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 December</span> 2011</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Sultan+Saladin+Opens+Jerusalem+to+Jews&amp;rft.au=Abraham+P.+Bloch&amp;rft.btitle=One+a+day%3A+an+anthology+of+Jewish+historical+anniversaries+for+every+day+of+the+year&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DmjxJAFawRasC%26pg%3DPA277&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-88125-108-1&amp;rft.pages=277&amp;rft.pub=KTAV+Publishing+House%2C+Inc.&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Ben-Gurion1974-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ben-Gurion1974_92-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Benzion Dinur (1974). "From Bar Kochba's Revolt to the Turkish Conquest". In David Ben-Gurion. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5sVtAAAAMAAJ"><i>The Jews in their Land</i></a>. Aldus Books. p.&#160;217<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120524094913/http://domino.un.org/unispal.nsf/0/7f0af2bd897689b785256c330061d253">"A/RES/181(II) of 29 November 1947"</a>. United Nations. 1947. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://domino.un.org/unispal.nsf/0/7f0af2bd897689b785256c330061d253">the original</a> on 24 May 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 May</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=A%2FRES%2F181%28II%29+of+29+November+1947&amp;rft.date=1947&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdomino.un.org%2Funispal.nsf%2F0%2F7f0af2bd897689b785256c330061d253&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Morris2008p66-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Morris2008p66_141-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Benny Morris (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=J5jtAAAAMAAJ"><i>1948: a history of the first Arab-Israeli war</i></a>. Yale University Press. pp.&#160;66, 67, 72<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 July</span> 2013</span>. <q>p.66, at 1946 "The League demanded independence for Palestine as a "unitary" state, with an Arab majority and minority rights for the Jews."&#160;; p.67, at 1947 "The League's Political Committee met in Sofar, Lebanon, on 16–19 September, and urged the Palestine Arabs to fight partition, which it called "aggression," "without mercy." The League promised them, in line with Bludan, assistance "in manpower, money and equipment" should the United Nations endorse partition."&#160;; p. 72, at Dec 1947 "The League vowed, in very general language, "to try to stymie the partition plan and prevent the establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Benny+Morris&amp;rft.btitle=1948%3A+a+history+of+the+first+Arab-Israeli+war&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DJ5jtAAAAMAAJ&amp;rft.pages=66%2C+67%2C+72&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-152"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-152">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Morris, 2008, p. 205<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="">title&#160;missing</span></a></i>]</sup></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-153"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-153">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFRabinovichReinharz.2C_Jehuda2007" class="citation book">Rabinovich, Itamar; Reinharz, Jehuda (2007). <i>Israel in the Middle East: Documents and Readings on Society, Politics, and Foreign Relations, Pre-1948 to the Present</i>. Brandeis. p.&#160;74. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-87451-962-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-87451-962-4">978-0-87451-962-4</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Itamar&amp;rft.aulast=Rabinovich&amp;rft.au=Reinharz%2C+Jehuda&amp;rft.btitle=Israel+in+the+Middle+East%3A+Documents+and+Readings+on+Society%2C+Politics%2C+and+Foreign+Relations%2C+Pre-1948+to+the+Present&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-87451-962-4&amp;rft.pages=74&amp;rft.pub=Brandeis&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Tal2004p469-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Tal2004p469_154-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">David Tal (24 June 2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Vs2PAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PR4"><i>War in Palestine, 1948: Israeli and Arab Strategy and Diplomacy</i></a>. Routledge. p.&#160;469. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-135-77513-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-135-77513-1">978-1-135-77513-1</a>. <q>some of the Arab armies invaded Palestine in order to prevent the establishment of a Jewish state, Transjordan...</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=David+Tal&amp;rft.btitle=War+in+Palestine%2C+1948%3A+Israeli+and+Arab+Strategy+and+Diplomacy&amp;rft.date=2004-06-24&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DVs2PAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPR4&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-135-77513-1&amp;rft.pages=469&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Morris2009p396-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Morris2009p396_155-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Benny Morris (1 April 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=W1eVPwAACAAJ"><i>1948: A History of the First Arab-Israeli War</i></a>. Yale University Press. p.&#160;396. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-15112-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-15112-1">978-0-300-15112-1</a>. <q>The Arab war aim, in both stages of the hostilities, was, at a minimum, to abort the emergence of a Jewish state or to destroy it at inception. The Arab states hoped to accomplish this by conquering all or large parts of the territory allotted to the Jews by the United Nations. And some Arab leaders spoke of driving the Jews into the sea19 and ridding Palestine "of the Zionist plague."20 The struggle, as the Arabs saw it, was about the fate of Palestine/ the Land of Israel, all of it, not over this or that part of the country. But, in public, official Arab spokesmen often said that the aim of the May 1948 invasion was to "save" Palestine or "save the Palestinians," definitions more agreeable to Western ears.</q></cite> <span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Benny+Morris&amp;rft.btitle=1948%3A+A+History+of+the+First+Arab-Israeli+War&amp;rft.date=2009-04-01&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DW1eVPwAACAAJ&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-15112-1&amp;rft.pages=396&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Morris2009p187-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Morris2009p187_156-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Benny Morris (1 April 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=W1eVPwAACAAJ"><i>1948: A History of the First Arab-Israeli War</i></a>. Yale University Press. p.&#160;187. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-15112-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-15112-1">978-0-300-15112-1</a>. <q>A week before the armies marched, Azzam told Kirkbride: "It does not matter how many [ Jews] there are. We will sweep them into the sea." ... Ahmed Shukeiry, one of Haj Amin al-Husseini's aides (and, later, the founding chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization), simply described the aim as "the elimination of the Jewish state." ...al-Quwwatli told his people: "Our army has entered ... we shall win and we shall eradicate Zionism)</q></cite> <span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Benny+Morris&amp;rft.btitle=1948%3A+A+History+of+the+First+Arab-Israeli+War&amp;rft.date=2009-04-01&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DW1eVPwAACAAJ&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-15112-1&amp;rft.pages=187&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Morris2009p198-157"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Morris2009p198_157-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Benny Morris (1 April 2009). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=W1eVPwAACAAJ"><i>1948: A History of the First Arab-Israeli War</i></a>. Yale University Press. p.&#160;198. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-15112-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-15112-1">978-0-300-15112-1</a>. <q>the Jews felt that the Arabs aimed to reenact the Holocaust and that they faced certain personal and collective slaughter should they lose</q></cite> <span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Benny+Morris&amp;rft.btitle=1948%3A+A+History+of+the+First+Arab-Israeli+War&amp;rft.date=2009-04-01&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DW1eVPwAACAAJ&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-15112-1&amp;rft.pages=198&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-cablegram-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-cablegram_158-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140107030419/http://www.un.org/Docs/journal/asp/ws.asp?m=S%2F745">"PDF copy of Cablegram from the Secretary-General of the League of Arab States to the Secretary-General of the United Nations: S/745: 15 May 1948"</a>. <li id="cite_note-159"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-159">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFKarsh2002" class="citation book">Karsh, Efraim (2002). <i>The Arab–Israeli conflict: The Palestine War 1948</i>. Osprey Publishing. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84176-372-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84176-372-9">978-1-84176-372-9</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Efraim&amp;rft.aulast=Karsh&amp;rft.btitle=The+Arab%93Israeli+conflict%3A+The+Palestine+War+1948&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84176-372-9&amp;rft.pub=Osprey+Publishing&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-160">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFMorris" class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Benny_Morris" title="Benny Morris">Morris, Benny</a>. <i>The Birth of the Palestinian Refugee Problem Revisited</i>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;602. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-00967-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-00967-6">978-0-521-00967-6</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Benny&amp;rft.aulast=Morris&amp;rft.btitle=The+Birth+of+the+Palestinian+Refugee+Problem+Revisited&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-00967-6&amp;rft.pages=602&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-UN-israel1949-161"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UN-israel1949_161-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://domino.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/1ce874ab1832a53e852570bb006dfaf6/0b3ab8d2a7c0273d8525694b00726d1b">"Two Hundred and Seventh Plenary Meeting"</a>. The United Nations. 11 May 1949<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 July</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Two+Hundred+and+Seventh+Plenary+Meeting&amp;rft.date=1949-05-11&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdomino.un.org%2FUNISPAL.NSF%2F1ce874ab1832a53e852570bb006dfaf6%2F0b3ab8d2a7c0273d8525694b00726d1b&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Louis1984p579-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Louis1984p579_162-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">William Roger Louis (1984). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ATQQ0FMS1FQC&amp;pg=PA579"><i>The British Empire in the Middle East, 1945–1951: Arab Nationalism, the United States, and Postwar Imperialism</i></a>. Clarendon Press. p.&#160;579. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-822960-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-822960-5">978-0-19-822960-5</a>. <q>The transcript makes it clear that British policy acted as a brake on Jordan." "King Abdullah was personally anxious to come to agreement with Israel", Kirkbride stated, and in fact it was our restraining influence which had so far prevented him from doing so." Knox Helm confirmed that the Israelis hoped to have a settlement with Jordan, and that they now genuinely wished to live peacefully within their frontiers, if only for economic reasons</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=William+Roger+Louis&amp;rft.btitle=The+British+Empire+in+the+Middle+East%2C+1945%931951%3A+Arab+Nationalism%2C+the+United+States%2C+and+Postwar+Imperialism&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DATQQ0FMS1FQC%26pg%3DPA579&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-822960-5&amp;rft.pages=579&amp;rft.pub=Clarendon+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-BG-Israel-163"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-BG-Israel_163-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLustick1988">Lustick 1988</a>, pp.&#160;37–39</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-164"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-164">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/iltoc.html">"Israel (Labor Zionism)"</a>. <i>Country Studies</i>. <li id="cite_note-Israel-population-170"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Israel-population_170-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Israel-population_170-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www1.cbs.gov.il/shnaton57/st02_01.pdf">"Population, by Religion and Population Group"</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(PDF)</span>. <li id="cite_note-bard-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-bard_171-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Bard, Mitchell (2003). <i>The Founding of the State of Israel</i>. <li id="cite_note-immigrants-tents-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-immigrants-tents_172-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFHakohen2003" class="citation book">Hakohen, Devorah (2003). <i>Immigrants in Turmoil: Mass Immigration to Israel and Its Repercussions in the 1950s and After</i>. Syracuse University Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8156-2969-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8156-2969-6">978-0-8156-2969-6</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Devorah&amp;rft.aulast=Hakohen&amp;rft.btitle=Immigrants+in+Turmoil%3A+Mass+Immigration+to+Israel+and+Its+Repercussions+in+the+1950s+and+After&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8156-2969-6&amp;rft.pub=Syracuse+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span>; for ma'abarot population, see p. 269.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-173"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-173">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Clive Jones, Emma Murphy, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.it/books?id=A144y7qwRJMC&amp;pg=PA37"><i>Israel: Challenges to Identity, Democracy, and the State,</i></a> <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a> 2002 p. 37: "Housing units earmarked for the Oriental Jews were often reallocated to European Jewish immigrants; Consigning Oriental Jews to the privations of <i>ma'aborot</i> (transit camps) for longer periods."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-174"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-174">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSegev2007">Segev 2007</a>, pp.&#160;155–157</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-175">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFShindler2002">Shindler 2002</a>, pp.&#160;49–50</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Nasr1996p40-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nasr1996p40_176-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Kameel B. Nasr (1 December 1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QRXURzwdXS4C&amp;pg=PA40"><i>Arab and Israeli Terrorism: The Causes and Effects of Political Violence, 1936–1993</i></a>. McFarland. pp.&#160;40–. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7864-3105-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7864-3105-2">978-0-7864-3105-2</a>. <q>Fedayeen to attack...almost always against civilians</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Kameel+B.+Nasr&amp;rft.btitle=Arab+and+Israeli+Terrorism%3A+The+Causes+and+Effects+of+Political+Violence%2C+1936%931993&amp;rft.date=1996-12-01&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQRXURzwdXS4C%26pg%3DPA40&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7864-3105-2&amp;rft.pages=40-&amp;rft.pub=McFarland&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-177"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-177">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGilbert2005">Gilbert 2005</a>, p.&#160;58</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Alteras1993p192-178"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Alteras1993p192_178-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Isaac Alteras (1993). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ydRHCPWngioC&amp;pg=PA192"><i>Eisenhower and Israel: U.S.-Israeli Relations, 1953–1960</i></a>. University Press of Florida. pp.&#160;192–. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8130-1205-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8130-1205-6">978-0-8130-1205-6</a>. <q>the removal of the Egyptian blockade of the Straits of Tiran at the entrance of the Gulf of Aqaba. The blockade closed Israel's sea lane to East Africa and the Far East, hindering the development of Israel's southern port of Eilat and its hinterland, the Nege. Another important objective of the Israeli war plan was the elimination of the terrorist bases in the Gaza Strip, from which daily fedayeen incursions into Israel made life unbearable for its southern population. And last but not least, the concentration of the Egyptian forces in the Sinai Peninsula, armed with the newly acquired weapons from the Soviet bloc, prepared for an attack on Israel. Here, Ben-Gurion believed, was a time bomb that had to be defused before it was too late. Reaching the Suez Canal did not figure at all in Israel's war objectives.</q></cite> <span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Isaac+Alteras&amp;rft.btitle=Eisenhower+and+Israel%3A+U.S.-Israeli+Relations%2C+1953%931960&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DydRHCPWngioC%26pg%3DPA192&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8130-1205-6&amp;rft.pages=192-&amp;rft.pub=University+Press+of+Florida&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Caraccilo2011p113-179"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Caraccilo2011p113_179-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Dominic Joseph Caraccilo (January 2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FDA8dQyaQ9MC&amp;pg=PA113"><i>Beyond Guns and Steel: A War Termination Strategy</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. pp.&#160;113–. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-39149-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-39149-1">978-0-313-39149-1</a>. <q>The escalation continued with the Egyptian blockade of the Straits of Tiran, and Nasser's nationalization of the Suez Canal in July 1956. On October 14, Nasser made clear his intent:"I am not solely fighting against Israel itself. My task is to deliver the Arab world from destruction through Israel's intrigue, which has its roots abroad. Our hatred is very strong. There is no sense in talking about peace with Israel. There is not even the smallest place for negotiations." Less than two weeks later, on October 25, Egypt signed a tripartite agreement with Syria and Jordan placing Nasser in command of all three armies. The continued blockade of the Suez Canal and Gulf of Aqaba to Israeli shipping, combined with the increased fedayeen attacks and the bellicosity of recent Arab statements, prompted Israel, with the backing of Britain and France, to attack Egypt on October 29, 1956.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Dominic+Joseph+Caraccilo&amp;rft.btitle=Beyond+Guns+and+Steel%3A+A+War+Termination+Strategy&amp;rft.date=2011-01&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFDA8dQyaQ9MC%26pg%3DPA113&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-39149-1&amp;rft.pages=113-&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Dowty2005p102-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dowty2005p102_180-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Alan Dowty (20 June 2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=9iFxq6NPPgEC&amp;pg=PA102"><i>Israel/Palestine</i></a>. Polity. pp.&#160;102–. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7456-3202-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7456-3202-5">978-0-7456-3202-5</a>. <q>Gamal Abdel Nasser, who declared in one speech that "Egypt has decided to dispatch her heroes, the disciples of Pharaoh and the sons of Islam and they will cleanse the land of Palestine....There will be no peace on Israel's border because we demand vengeance, and vengeance is Israel's death."...The level of violence against Israelis, soldiers and civilians alike, seemed to be rising inexorably.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Alan+Dowty&amp;rft.btitle=Israel%2FPalestine&amp;rft.date=2005-06-20&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D9iFxq6NPPgEC%26pg%3DPA102&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7456-3202-5&amp;rft.pages=102-&amp;rft.pub=Polity&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-jvl-nasser1956-181"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-jvl-nasser1956_181-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/Suez_War.html">"The Jewish Virtual Library, The Sinai-Suez Campaign: Background &amp; Overview"</a>. <q>In 1955, Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser began to import arms from the Soviet Bloc to build his arsenal for the confrontation with Israel. In the short-term, however, he employed a new tactic to prosecute Egypt's war with Israel. He announced it on August 31, 1955: Egypt has decided to dispatch her heroes, the disciples of Pharaoh and the sons of Islam and they will cleanse the land of Palestine....There will be no peace on Israel's border because we demand vengeance, and vengeance is Israel's death. These "heroes" were Arab terrorists, or fedayeen, trained and equipped by Egyptian Intelligence to engage in hostile action on the border and infiltrate Israel to commit acts of sabotage and murder.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=The+Jewish+Virtual+Library%2C+The+Sinai-Suez+Campaign%3A+Background+%26+Overview&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jewishvirtuallibrary.org%2Fjsource%2FHistory%2FSuez_War.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-182"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-182">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Schoenherr, Steven (15 December 2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sunnycv.com/steve/20th/suez.html">"The Suez Crisis"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 May</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven&amp;rft.aulast=Schoenherr&amp;rft.btitle=The+Suez+Crisis&amp;rft.date=2005-12-15&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsunnycv.com%2Fsteve%2F20th%2Fsuez.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-183"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-183">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFGorstJohnman.2C_Lewis1997" class="citation book">Gorst, Anthony; Johnman, Lewis (1997). <i>The Suez Crisis</i>. Routledge. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-11449-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-11449-3">978-0-415-11449-3</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.au=Johnman%2C+Lewis&amp;rft.aulast=Gorst&amp;rft.btitle=The+Suez+Crisis&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-11449-3&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Morris2011p300-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Morris2011p300_184-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Benny Morris (25 May 2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jGtVsBne7PgC"><i>Righteous Victims: A History of the Zionist-Arab Conflict, 1881–1998</i></a>. Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. pp.&#160;300, 301. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-307-78805-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-307-78805-4">978-0-307-78805-4</a>. <q>(p. 300) In exchange (for Israeli withdrawal) the United states had indirectly promised to guarantee Israel's right of passage through the straits (to the Red sea) and its right to self defense if the Egyptian closed them....(p 301) The 1956 war resulted in a significant reduction of...Israeli border tension. Egypt refrained from reactivating the Fedaeen, and...Egypt and Jordan made great effort to curb infiltration</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Benny+Morris&amp;rft.btitle=Righteous+Victims%3A+A+History+of+the+Zionist-Arab+Conflict%2C+1881%931998&amp;rft.date=2011-05-25&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DjGtVsBne7PgC&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-307-78805-4&amp;rft.pages=300%2C+301&amp;rft.pub=Knopf+Doubleday+Publishing+Group&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-killed-hostile-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-killed-hostile_185-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.btl.gov.il/English%20Homepage/Benefits/Benefits%20for%20Victims%20of%20Hostilities/Pages/default.aspx">"National insurance institute of Israel, Hostile Action Casualties"</a> (in Hebrew). <q>list of people who were kiled in hostile action: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://laad.btl.gov.il/Web/He/Victims/112.aspx?lastName=&amp;firstName=&amp;fatherName=&amp;motherName=&amp;place=&amp;year=1956&amp;month=&amp;day=&amp;region=&amp;period=3&amp;grave=">53 In 1956</a>,<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://laad.btl.gov.il/Web/He/Victims/112.aspx?lastName=&amp;firstName=&amp;fatherName=&amp;motherName=&amp;place=&amp;year=1957&amp;month=&amp;day=&amp;region=&amp;period=3&amp;grave=">19 in 1957</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://laad.btl.gov.il/Web/He/Victims/112.aspx?lastName=&amp;firstName=&amp;fatherName=&amp;motherName=&amp;place=&amp;year=1958&amp;month=&amp;day=&amp;region=&amp;period=3&amp;grave=">15 in 1958</a></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=National+insurance+institute+of+Israel%2C+Hostile+Action+Casualties&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.btl.gov.il%2FEnglish%2520Homepage%2FBenefits%2FBenefits%2520for%2520Victims%2520of%2520Hostilities%2FPages%2Fdefault.aspx&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-jvl-terror-fatality-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-jvl-terror-fatality_186-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Peace/osloterr.html">"jewish virtual library, Terrorism Against Israel: Number of Fatalities"</a>. <q>53 at 1956, 19 at 1957, 15 at 1958</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=jewish+virtual+library%2C+Terrorism+Against+Israel%3A+Number+of+Fatalities&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jewishvirtuallibrary.org%2Fjsource%2FPeace%2Fosloterr.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-jvl-eban-killed-187"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-jvl-eban-killed_187-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/myths3/MF1956.html">"Jewish virtual library,MYTH "Israel's military strike in 1956 was unprovoked.<span style="padding-right:0.2em;">"</span>"</a>. <q>Israeli Ambassador to the UN Abba Eban explained ... In 1956 alone, as a result of this aspect of Egyptian aggression, 28 Israelis were killed and 127 wounded.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=Jewish+virtual+library%2CMYTH+%22Israel%27s+military+strike+in+1956+was+unprovoked.%22&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jewishvirtuallibrary.org%2Fjsource%2Fmyths3%2FMF1956.html&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-197">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Samir A. Mutawi (18 July 2002). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=g9bBJusRJIMC"><i>Jordan in the 1967 War</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;93. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-52858-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-52858-0">978-0-521-52858-0</a>. <q>Although Eshkol denounced the Egyptians, his response to this development was a model of moderation. His speech on 21 May demanded that Nasser withdraw his forces from Sinai but made no mention of the removal of UNEF from the Straits nor of what Israel would do if they were closed to Israeli shipping. The next day Nasser announced to an astonished world that henceforth the Straits were, indeed, closed to all Israeli ships</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.au=Samir+A.+Mutawi&amp;rft.btitle=Jordan+in+the+1967+War&amp;rft.date=2002-07-18&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dg9bBJusRJIMC&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-52858-0&amp;rft.pages=93&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-rinat-258"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-rinat_258-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Rinat, Zafrir (29 May 2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/features/more-endangered-than-rain-forests-1.246839">"More endangered than rain forests?"</a>. <i>Haaretz</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 March</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=More+endangered+than+rain+forests%3F&amp;rft.aufirst=Zafrir&amp;rft.aulast=Rinat&amp;rft.date=2008-05-29&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.haaretz.com%2Fprint-edition%2Ffeatures%2Fmore-endangered-than-rain-forests-1.246839&amp;rft.jtitle=Haaretz&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Ferry-259"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ferry_259-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Ferry M.; Meghraoui M.; Karaki A.A.; Al-Taj M.; Amoush H.; Al-Dhaisat S.; Barjous M. (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012821X0700324X">"A 48-kyr-long slip rate history for the Jordan Valley segment of the Dead Sea Fault"</a>. <i>Earth and Planetary Science Letters</i>. <b>260</b> (3–4): 394–406. <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">Bibcode</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2007E&amp;PSL.260..394F">2007E&amp;PSL.260..394F</a>. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.1016%2Fj.epsl.2007.05.049">10.1016/j.epsl.2007.05.049</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=A+48-kyr-long+slip+rate+history+for+the+Jordan+Valley+segment+of+the+Dead+Sea+Fault&amp;rft.au=Al-Dhaisat+S.&amp;rft.au=Al-Taj+M.&amp;rft.au=Amoush+H.&amp;rft.au=Barjous+M.&amp;rft.au=Ferry+M.&amp;rft.au=Karaki+A.A.&amp;rft.au=Meghraoui+M.&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sciencedirect.com%2Fscience%2Farticle%2Fpii%2FS0012821X0700324X&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2007E%26PSL.260..394F&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2Fj.epsl.2007.05.049&amp;rft.issue=3%934&amp;rft.jtitle=Earth+and+Planetary+Science+Letters&amp;rft.pages=394-406&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=260" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-MarcoAFTAU-260"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MarcoAFTAU_260-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MarcoAFTAU_260-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">American Friends of the Tel Aviv University, <i>Earthquake Experts at Tel Aviv University Turn to History for Guidance</i> (October 4, 2007). Quote: The major ones were recorded along the Jordan Valley in the years 31 B.C.E., 363 C.E., 749 C.E., and 1033 C.E. "So roughly, we are talking about an interval of every 400 years. If we follow the patterns of nature, a major quake should be expected any time because almost a whole millennium has passed since the last strong earthquake of 1033." (Tel Aviv University Associate Professor Dr. Shmuel (Shmulik) Marco). <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.aftau.org/news-page-environment--ecology?&amp;storyid4703=2015&amp;ncs4703=3">[1]</a></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-IllPreped-261"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IllPreped_261-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IllPreped_261-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Zafrir Renat, <i>Israel Is Due, and Ill Prepared, for Major Earthquake</i>, Haaretz, 15 January 2010. "On average, a destructive earthquake takes place in Israel once every 80 years, causing serious casualties and damage." <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.haaretz.com/israel-is-due-and-ill-prepared-for-a-major-earthquake-1.261497">[2]</a></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-295"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-295">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFRoberts1990">Roberts 1990</a>, p.&#160;60 Although East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights have been brought directly under Israeli law, by acts that amount to annexation, both of these areas continue to be viewed by the international community as occupied, and their status as regards the applicability of international rules is in most respects identical to that of the West Bank and Gaza.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-The_Ethiopian_Population_In_Israel-296"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-The_Ethiopian_Population_In_Israel_296-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Israel_Central_Bureau_of_Statistics" title="Israel Central Bureau of Statistics">Israel Central Bureau of Statistics</a>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/newhodaot/hodaa_template.html?hodaa=201211307">The Ethiopian Community in Israel</a></span></li>
