<li id="cite_note-299"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-299">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.haaretz.com/news/study-soviet-immigrants-outperform-israeli-students-1.238970">"Study: Soviet immigrants outperform Israeli students"</a>. <i>Haaretz</i>. 10 February 2008.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Study%3A+Soviet+immigrants+outperform+Israeli+students&amp;rft.date=2008-02-10&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.haaretz.com%2Fnews%2Fstudy-soviet-immigrants-outperform-israeli-students-1.238970&amp;rft.jtitle=Haaretz&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-300"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-300">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4156781,00.html">"French radio station RFI makes aliyah"</a>. <i>Ynetnews</i>. 5 December 2011.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=French+radio+station+RFI+makes+aliyah&amp;rft.date=2011-12-05&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ynetnews.com%2Farticles%2F0%2C7340%2CL-4156781%2C00.html&amp;rft.jtitle=Ynetnews&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-301"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-301">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Spolsky, Bernard (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ljumbfV_7y0C&amp;pg=PA169&amp;dq=#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Round Table on Language and Linguistics</i></a>. Washington, D.C.: Georgetown University Press. pp.&#160;169–70. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-87840-132-6" title="Special:BookSources/0-87840-132-6">0-87840-132-6</a>. <q>In 1948, the newly independent state of Israel took over the old British regulations that had set English, Arabic, and Hebrew as official languages for Mandatory Palestine but, as mentioned, dropped English from the list. In spite of this, official language use has maintained a de facto role for English, after Hebrew but before Arabic.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Bernard&amp;rft.aulast=Spolsky&amp;rft.btitle=Round+Table+on+Language+and+Linguistics&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DljumbfV_7y0C%26pg%3DPA169%26dq%3D%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=0-87840-132-6&amp;rft.pages=169-70&amp;rft.place=Washington%2C+D.C.&amp;rft.pub=Georgetown+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-302"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-302">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Bat-Zeev Shyldkrot, Hava (2004). "Part I: Language and Discourse". In Diskin Ravid, Dorit; Bat-Zeev Shyldkrot, Hava. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xMzx6xFB0IgC&amp;pg=PA90#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Perspectives on Language and Development: Essays in Honor of Ruth A. Berman</i></a>. Kluwer Academic Publishers. p.&#160;90. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-4020-7911-7" title="Special:BookSources/1-4020-7911-7">1-4020-7911-7</a>. <q>English is not considered official but it plays a dominant role in the educational and public life of Israeli society. ... It is the language most widely used in commerce, business, formal papers, academia, and public interactions, public signs, road directions, names of buildings, etc. English behaves 'as if' it were the second and official language in Israel.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Part+I%3A+Language+and+Discourse&amp;rft.aufirst=Hava&amp;rft.aulast=Bat-Zeev+Shyldkrot&amp;rft.btitle=Perspectives+on+Language+and+Development%3A+Essays+in+Honor+of+Ruth+A.+Berman&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DxMzx6xFB0IgC%26pg%3DPA90%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=1-4020-7911-7&amp;rft.pages=90&amp;rft.pub=Kluwer+Academic+Publishers&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-303"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-303">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Shohamy, Elana (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5mG09P64jzYC&amp;pg=PA72#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Language Policy: Hidden Agendas and New Approaches</i></a>. Routledge. pp.&#160;72–73. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-415-32864-0" title="Special:BookSources/0-415-32864-0">0-415-32864-0</a>. <q>In terms of English, there is no connection between the declared policies and statements and de facto practices. While English is not declared anywhere as an official language, the reality is that it has a very high and unique status in Israel. It is the main language of the academy, commerce, business, and the public space.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Elana&amp;rft.aulast=Shohamy&amp;rft.btitle=Language+Policy%3A+Hidden+Agendas+and+New+Approaches&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D5mG09P64jzYC%26pg%3DPA72%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=0-415-32864-0&amp;rft.pages=72-73&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-304"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-304">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/IsraelExperience/AboutIsrael/Education/Pages/English_programs_Israeli_universities_colleges.aspx">"English programs at Israeli universities and colleges"</a>. Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=English+programs+at+Israeli+universities+and+colleges&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmfa.gov.il%2FMFA%2FIsraelExperience%2FAboutIsrael%2FEducation%2FPages%2FEnglish_programs_Israeli_universities_colleges.aspx&amp;rft.pub=Israel+Ministry+of+Foreign+Affairs&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-305"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-305">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Starr, Kelsey Jo; Masci, David (8 March 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/03/08/in-israel-jews-are-united-by-homeland-but-divided-into-very-different-groups/">"In Israel, Jews are united by homeland but divided into very different groups"</a>. <li id="cite_note-ARWU-339"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ARWU_339-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ARWU_339-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.shanghairanking.com/World-University-Rankings-2016/Israel.html">"Israel"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 January</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.btitle=Israel&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.shanghairanking.com%2FWorld-University-Rankings-2016%2FIsrael.html&amp;rft.pub=Academic+Ranking+of+World+Universities&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-cia2-340"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-cia2_340-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-cia2_340-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2077.html">"Field Listing&#160;— Executive Branch"</a>. <i>The World Factbook</i>. Central Intelligence Agency. 19 June 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 July</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Field+Listing+%94+Executive+Branch&amp;rft.date=2007-06-19&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cia.gov%2Flibrary%2Fpublications%2Fthe-world-factbook%2Ffields%2F2077.html&amp;rft.jtitle=The+World+Factbook&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-341"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-341">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 1996, direct elections for the prime minister were inaugurated, but the system was declared unsatisfactory and the old one reinstated. See <cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2683259.stm">"Israel's election process explained"</a>. BBC News. 23 January 2003<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 March</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Israel%27s+election+process+explained&amp;rft.date=2003-01-23&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F2%2Fhi%2Fmiddle_east%2F2683259.stm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-342"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-342">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.knesset.gov.il/description/eng/eng_mimshal_beh.htm">"The Electoral System in Israel"</a>. The Knesset<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 August</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=The+Electoral+System+in+Israel&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.knesset.gov.il%2Fdescription%2Feng%2Feng_mimshal_beh.htm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-343"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-343">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMazie2006">Mazie 2006</a>, p.&#160;34</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-344"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-344">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Charbit, Denis (2014). "Israel's Self-Restrained Secularism from the 1947 Status Quo Letter to the Present". In Berlinerblau, Jacques; Fainberg, Sarah; Nou, Aurora. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.il/books?id=gThvBAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA167&amp;dq#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Secularism on the Edge: Rethinking Church-State Relations in the United States, France, and Israel</i></a>. New York: Palgrave Macmillan. pp.&#160;167–169. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-137-38115-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-137-38115-6">978-1-137-38115-6</a>. <q>The compromise, therefore, was to choose constructive ambiguity: as surprising as it may seem, there is no law that declares Judaism the official religion of Israel. However, there is no other law that declares Israel's neutrality toward all confessions. Judaism is not recognized as the official religion of the state, and even though the Jewish, Muslim and Christian clergy receive their salaries from the state, this fact does not make Israel a neutral state. This apparent pluralism cannot dissimulate the fact that Israel displays a clear and undoubtedly hierarchical pluralism in religious matters.&#160;... It is important to note that from a multicultural point of view, this self-restrained secularism allows Muslim law to be practiced in Israel for personal matters of the Muslim community. As surprising as it seems, if not paradoxical for a state in war, Israel is the only Western democratic country in which Sharia enjoys such an official status.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Israel%27s+Self-Restrained+Secularism+from+the+1947+Status+Quo+Letter+to+the+Present&amp;rft.aufirst=Denis&amp;rft.aulast=Charbit&amp;rft.btitle=Secularism+on+the+Edge%3A+Rethinking+Church-State+Relations+in+the+United+States%2C+France%2C+and+Israel&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.il%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DgThvBAAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA167%26dq%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-137-38115-6&amp;rft.pages=167-169&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Palgrave+Macmillan&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-345"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-345">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Sharot, Stephen (2007). "Judaism in Israel: Public Religion, Neo-Traditionalism, Messianism, and Ethno-Religious Conflict". In Beckford, James A.; Demerath, Jay. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.il/books?id=vA8edg7bv0kC&amp;pg=PA671"><i>The SAGE Handbook of the Sociology of Religion</i></a>. London and Thousand Oaks, California: Sage Publications. pp.&#160;671–672. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4129-1195-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4129-1195-5">978-1-4129-1195-5</a>. <q>It is true that Jewish Israelis, and secular Israelis in particular, conceive of religion as shaped by a state-sponsored religious establishment. There is no formal state religion in Israel, but the state gives its official recognition and financial support to particular religious communities, Jewish, Islamic and Christian, whose religious authorities and courts are empowered to deal with matters of personal status and family law, such as marriage, divorce, and alimony, that are binding on all members of the communities.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Judaism+in+Israel%3A+Public+Religion%2C+Neo-Traditionalism%2C+Messianism%2C+and+Ethno-Religious+Conflict&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Sharot&amp;rft.btitle=The+SAGE+Handbook+of+the+Sociology+of+Religion&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.il%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DvA8edg7bv0kC%26pg%3DPA671&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4129-1195-5&amp;rft.pages=671-672&amp;rft.place=London+and+Thousand+Oaks%2C+California&amp;rft.pub=Sage+Publications&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-346"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-346">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Jacoby, Tami Amanda (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.co.il/books?id=pr1LJNrlmuIC&amp;pg=PA53#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Women in Zones of Conflict: Power and Resistance in Israel</i></a>. Montreal, Quebec and Kingston, Ontario: McGill-Queen's University Press. pp.&#160;53–54. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780773529939" title="Special:BookSources/9780773529939">9780773529939</a>. <q>Although there is no official religion in Israel, there is also no clear separation between religion and state. In Israeli public life, tensions frequently arise among different streams of Judaism: Ultra-Orthodox, National-Religious, <i>Mesorati</i> (Conservative), Reconstructionist Progressive (Reform), and varying combinations of traditionalism and non-observance. Despite this variety in religious observances in society, Orthodox Judaism prevails institutionally over the other streams. This boundary is an historical consequence of the unique evolution of the relationship between Israel nationalism and state building.&#160;... Since the founding period, in order to defuse religious tensions, the State of Israel has adopted what is known as the 'status quo,' an unwritten agreement stipulating that no further changes would be made in the status of religion, and that conflict between the observant and non-observant sectors would be handled circumstantially. The 'status quo' has since pertained to the legal status of both religious and secular Jews in Israel. This situation was designed to appease the religious sector, and has been upheld indefinitely through the disproportionate power of religious political parties in all subsequent coalition governments.&#160;... On one hand, the Declaration of Independence adopted in 1948 explicitly guarantees freedom of religion. On the other, it simultaneously prevents the separation of religion and state in Israel.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.aufirst=Tami+Amanda&amp;rft.aulast=Jacoby&amp;rft.btitle=Women+in+Zones+of+Conflict%3A+Power+and+Resistance+in+Israel&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.co.il%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dpr1LJNrlmuIC%26pg%3DPA53%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rft.isbn=9780773529939&amp;rft.pages=53-54&amp;rft.place=Montreal%2C+Quebec+and+Kingston%2C+Ontario&amp;rft.pub=McGill-Queen%27s+University+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-347"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-347">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Englard, Izhak (Winter 1987). "Law and Religion in Israel". <i>The American Journal of Comparative Law</i>. American Society of Comparative Law. <b>35</b> (1): 185–208. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.2307%2F840166">10.2307/840166</a>. <a href="/wiki/JSTOR" title="JSTOR">JSTOR</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/840166">840166</a>. <q>The great political and ideological importance of religion in the state of Israel manifests itself in the manifold legal provisions concerned with religions phenomenon.&#160;... It is not a system of separation between state and religion as practiced in the U.S.A and several other countries of the world. In Israel a number of religious bodies exercise official functions; the religious law is applied in limited areas</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Law+and+Religion+in+Israel&amp;rft.aufirst=Izhak&amp;rft.aulast=Englard&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F840166&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F840166&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.jtitle=The+American+Journal+of+Comparative+Law&amp;rft.pages=185-208&amp;rft.ssn=winter&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.volume=35" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-judiciary-348"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-judiciary_348-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-judiciary_348-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Branches%20of%20Government/Judicial/The%20Judiciary-%20The%20Court%20System">"The Judiciary: The Court System"</a>. Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 1 August 2005<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 August</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=The+Judiciary%3A+The+Court+System&amp;rft.date=2005-08-01&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mfa.gov.il%2FMFA%2FGovernment%2FBranches%2520of%2520Government%2FJudicial%2FThe%2520Judiciary-%2520The%2520Court%2520System&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-349">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://bostonherald.com/news_opinion/opinion/editorials/2007/09/israel%E2%80%99s_high_court_unique_region">"Israel's high court unique in region"</a>. <i>Boston Herald</i>. 9 September 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">27 March</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Israel%27s+high+court+unique+in+region&amp;rft.date=2007-09-09&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbostonherald.com%2Fnews_opinion%2Fopinion%2Feditorials%2F2007%2F09%2Fisrael%25E2%2580%2599s_high_court_unique_region&amp;rft.jtitle=Boston+Herald&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-350"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-350">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070516021101/http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/MFAArchive/2000_2009/2002/6/Israel%20and%20the%20International%20Criminal%20Court">"Israel and the International Criminal Court"</a>. Office of the Legal Adviser to the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs">Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a>. 30 June 2002. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/MFAArchive/2000_2009/2002/6/Israel%20and%20the%20International%20Criminal%20Court">the original</a> on 16 May 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 July</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=Israel+and+the+International+Criminal+Court&amp;rft.date=2002-06-30&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mfa.gov.il%2FMFA%2FMFAArchive%2F2000_2009%2F2002%2F6%2FIsrael%2520and%2520the%2520International%2520Criminal%2520Court&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>
<li id="cite_note-351"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-351">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Facts+About+Israel/State/THE+STATE-+Judiciary-+The+Court+System.htm">"The State&#160;— Judiciary&#160;— The Court System"</a>. Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 1 October 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">9 August</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=The+State+%94+Judiciary+%94+The+Court+System&amp;rft.date=2006-10-01&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mfa.gov.il%2FMFA%2FFacts%2BAbout%2BIsrael%2FState%2FTHE%2BSTATE-%2BJudiciary-%2BThe%2BCourt%2BSystem.htm&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-403"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-403">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Pfeffer, Anshel (April 28, 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-1.653988">"The Downsides of Israel's Missions of Mercy Abroad"</a>. <i>Haaretz</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">November 22,</span> 2015</span>. <q>And even when no Israelis are involved, few countries are as fast as Israel in mobilizing entire delegations to rush to the other side of the world. It has been proved time and again in recent years, after the earthquake in Haiti, the typhoon in the Philippines and the quake/tsunami/nuclear disaster in Japan. For a country of Israel's size and resources, without conveniently located aircraft carriers and overseas bases, it is quite an impressive achievement.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael&amp;rft.atitle=The+Downsides+of+Israel%27s+Missions+of+Mercy+Abroad&amp;rft.aufirst=Anshel&amp;rft.aulast=Pfeffer&amp;rft.date=2015-04-28&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.haaretz.com%2Fisrael-news%2F.premium-1.653988&amp;rft.jtitle=Haaretz&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-520"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-520">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120210070052/http://worldmusic.nationalgeographic.com/view/page.basic/country/content.country/israel_36">"Israel"</a>. <i>World Music</i>. <td style="padding:0px;;;;width:10em;">
<table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0">
<tr>
<td class="navbox-image" rowspan="1" style="width:0%;padding:0px 2px 0px 0px;vertical-align:top;">
<div><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg" class="image" title="Land of Israel"><img alt="Land of Israel" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg/100px-Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg" width="100" height="140" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg/150px-Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg/200px-Map_Land_of_Israel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="571" data-file-height="800" /></a></div>
</td>
<td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-even plainlist" style="width:100%;padding:0px;vertical-align:top;line-height:1.45em;">
<div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<div style="padding-bottom:1.2em;"><b>History</b>
<hr />
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Levant" title="Prehistory of the Levant">Prehistory</a>&#160;/ <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Levant" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Levant">History of the Levant</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">History of ancient Israel and Judah</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Laws_and_customs_of_the_Land_of_Israel_in_Judaism" title="Laws and customs of the Land of Israel in Judaism">Laws and customs of the Land of Israel in Judaism</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<b><a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">The Jewish people</a></b>
<hr />
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Jewish_history" title="Timeline of Jewish history">Timeline of Jewish history</a></li>
